title: Coca-Cola to Auction Its First-Ever NFT Collectibles on International Friendship Day
summary: Coca-Cola is launching its first-ever NFT collectibles on International Friendship Day, with all proceeds from the four-day auction on OpenSea going to Special Olympics International. The collection includes a "Friendship Box" containing a custom Coca-Cola Bubble Jacket Wearable, a Sound Visualizer, and a Friendship Card, all inspired by shared moments of friendship and reinterpreted for the metaverse. These multi-sensory NFTs celebrate Coca-Cola's heritage and aim to connect with new audiences in virtual worlds.

title: Coca-Cola Expanding Wabi Digital Ecosystem
summary: Coca-Cola is expanding its Wabi digital ecosystem to improve relationships with retailers and bottling partners, as well as gather valuable consumer insights. The platform, which enables direct-to-consumer and B2B sales, is being used in regions with high densities of mom-and-pop shops and is accelerating the digitization of relationships with bottlers and independent retailers. Coca-Cola is also experimenting with multi-category approaches and leveraging its sales force for account development and in-store activations.

title: Sparkling beverages soar in popularity among young Chinese
summary: Sparkling beverages are rapidly gaining popularity among young Chinese consumers, driven by health consciousness and a preference for low or no-sugar, calorie-free options. Brands like Genki Forest have successfully capitalized on this trend with innovative marketing and product development, leading to significant market growth. Despite challenges, such as a recent setback for Nongfu Spring, the carbonated water market in China is projected to continue its expansion, attracting major beverage companies.

title: Coca-Cola spurs 42% revenue growth after returning to pre-pandemic marketing spend
summary: Coca-Cola reported a 42% increase in net revenues to $10.1 billion in Q2 2021, largely attributed to a return to pre-pandemic marketing spend levels. The company doubled its marketing investment year-over-year, focusing on innovation, effectiveness, and efficiency. This strategy led to significant growth, outpacing Q2 2019 revenues and earnings, with notable success in new product launches, targeted campaigns, and e-commerce.

title: Coca-Cola sees strong results as away-from-home channels recover
summary: Coca-Cola reported strong Q2 2021 results, with concentrate sales up 26% and net income soaring 48%, driven by the recovery of away-from-home channels and robust at-home demand. The company raised its full-year guidance for earnings per share growth to 13-15% and organic sales growth to 12-14%, despite challenges in the supply chain and commodity costs. Management expects to retain some of the at-home gains made during the pandemic while benefiting from the continued recovery of out-of-home consumption.

title: Coca-Cola leans on early pandemic lessons to prepare for Delta variant hit
summary: Coca-Cola plans to combat the potential impact of the Delta variant by focusing on bigger brands and strengthening its supply chain, a strategy learned from the early pandemic. Despite new restrictions in some regions, the beverage giant exceeded second-quarter expectations and increased its full-year sales forecast, though sales in some Asian markets were affected. The company's vulnerability to venue closures makes it riskier than PepsiCo, according to analysts.

title: Energy market thrives during pandemic
summary: The energy drink and shot market experienced significant growth during the pandemic, with total energy drink sales up 9.2% in 2020 to approximately $14.3 billion. This growth is attributed to consumers relying on these products for energy to cope with increased workloads and challenges brought on by the pandemic. The market is also seeing innovation in flavors, functionality, and performance energy variations, although energy shots have experienced a decline due to reduced convenience store traffic and limited innovation.

title: Soft drinks are big business in Alabama
summary: The soft drink industry, particularly Coca-Cola Bottling Company United and Buffalo Rock, has a significant economic impact in Alabama, generating billions in sales and thousands of jobs. Both companies, with histories spanning over a century, are major privately-held bottlers for Coca-Cola and PepsiCo respectively, and continue to make substantial investments in the state despite evolving consumer preferences.

title: Why is Tesla incorporated in Delaware?
summary: This article explains why a disproportionate number of companies, including Tesla, Amazon, and Google, are incorporated in Delaware despite not being headquartered there. Key reasons include flexible corporate law, the efficient Court of Chancery, favorable tax treatment for out-of-state income, and a long-standing state focus on business formation. The article also touches on the challenges this presents for regional data and business coverage.

title: Coca-Cola Is Changing the Flavor of a Soda. Again. (Published 2021)
summary: Coca-Cola is changing the flavor and look of Coke Zero Sugar, aiming for an "even more iconic Coke taste," a move that has already sparked consumer anxiety and comparisons to the 1985 "New Coke" debacle. This change to one of its popular diet spinoffs risks a backlash from consumers who remember the company's past controversial flavor alterations. The company is seeking to deliver a taste that more closely resembles "classic" Coke.

title: John Tonnison Joins US Foods As EVP, Chief Information & Digital Officer
summary: US Foods Holding Corp. has appointed John Tonnison as its new Executive VP, Chief Information and Digital Officer, where he will oversee the company's technology vision, strategy, and all IT functions. Tonnison brings over three decades of experience, including nearly two decades at Tech Data Corporation, and replaces former CIO Keith Rohland. He will report to Chairman and CEO Pietro Satriano and focus on driving best-in-class digital commerce solutions for US Foods' customers.

title: Descartes continues customer-driven acquisition strategy with GreenMile purchase
summary: Descartes Systems Group acquired GreenMile, a cloud-based mobile routing solution specializing in food and beverage, for $30 million upfront plus a potential $10 million earn-out. This acquisition is part of Descartes' customer-driven strategy to enhance its global logistics network and improve customer offerings, particularly in last-mile delivery and supply chain operations. GreenMile's platform provides driver visibility, route optimization, and delivery performance management tools, benefiting clients like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo.

title: Coca-Cola FEMSA publicó su primer informe de bono verde
summary: Coca-Cola FEMSA has published its first green bond report, detailing the use of US$235.48 million, or 33.4%, of the US$705 million raised in September 2020. These funds have been allocated to projects promoting a circular economy, water conservation, and climate change initiatives, aligning with the company's environmental objectives and the UN Sustainable Development Goals. The report highlights progress in using recycled PET, reducing water usage in production, and advancing towards 100% renewable energy in operations.

title: 2021 State of the Beverage Industry: Bottled water bubbling over with growth
summary: This article details the continued growth of the bottled water industry in 2021, highlighting its expansion even during the COVID-19 pandemic. It emphasizes the role of health and wellness attributes, convenience, and the increasing popularity of sparkling and enhanced waters in driving this growth. The report includes sales figures and insights from industry experts on market trends and innovation within the water category.

title: Coca-Cola Great Britain to use fully recycled plastic for 500ml bottles
summary: Coca-Cola Great Britain is transitioning all its 500ml or smaller "on-the-go" plastic bottles to fully recycled plastic content, a move expected to save 29,000 tonnes of virgin plastic annually. This initiative, supported by UK Environment Minister Rebecca Pow, is part of Coca-Cola's global ambition to collect and recycle a bottle or can for each one sold by 2025 and follows similar moves in North America. The company also advocates for a Deposit Return Scheme in the UK to increase the availability of food-grade recycled plastic.

title: CEOs from The Coca-Cola Company and Alibaba Group to Lead The Consumer Goods Forum Board of Directors
summary: The Consumer Goods Forum (CGF) announced the election of Daniel Zhang, Chairman & CEO of Alibaba Group, and James Quincey, Chairman & CEO of The Coca-Cola Company, as its new Co-Chairs for a two-year term. They succeed Özgür Tort and Emmanuel Faber and will lead the CGF in accelerating actions on sustainability, health, and safety challenges, building on the strategic shift with the creation of eight Coalitions of Action. Frans Muller and Alan Jope were also appointed Vice Co-Chairs.

title: Profile: Beverage giant The Coca-Cola Company
summary: This article profiles The Coca-Cola Company, highlighting its history, global presence, and strategic approach to procurement, particularly in supplier diversity and sustainability. It details Coca-Cola's efforts in increasing spending with minority-owned businesses and implementing sustainable agricultural practices, emphasizing their commitment to strengthening local communities and fostering innovation. The company's unique supply chain management through Coca-Cola Bottlers’ Sales & Service (CCBSS) and various awards are also noted.

title: Coca-Cola to double spending on minority-owned media and ramp up empowerment initiatives
summary: Coca-Cola North America announced plans to nearly double its spending on minority-owned media companies by 2024, aiming for 8% of its total annual media budget to go to businesses led by Black, Hispanic, and AAPI people. This initiative is part of a broader commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion, including deepening relationships with diverse media partners and pursuing non-media partnerships and empowerment programs. The company also aims for its workforce to be representative of U.S. census data by race and ethnicity at all job levels by 2030, following increased scrutiny on racial justice and equity.

title: Coke and Pepsi eye new sustainability goals after years of failed promises
summary: Coca-Cola and PepsiCo are under increasing pressure from investors and customers to adopt more ambitious sustainability goals, particularly regarding reusable and refillable packaging, after decades of focusing on plastic recycling with limited success. Both companies have a history of setting and missing recycling targets, leading environmentalists to question the effectiveness of their new commitments. Despite past failures, the pandemic and growing demand for corporate responsibility are pushing these beverage giants to genuinely integrate sustainability into their core operations, beyond just recycling initiatives.

title: Coca-Cola North America Steps up Spending With Minority-Owned Media Companies
summary: Coca-Cola North America announced its plan to nearly double its spending with minority-owned media companies over the next three years, allocating 8% of its annual media budget by 2024 to Black, Hispanic, and AAPI-owned media. This initiative includes a significant boost in 2021 spending and the launch of a pilot certification assistance program to support the growth of these businesses. The commitment aligns with Coca-Cola's broader efforts to foster diversity, equity, and inclusion, and to support diverse suppliers across its supply chain.

title: Coca-Cola, Monster win appeal of $9.6 million verdict over ‘Hansen’s’ rights
summary: A California appellate court has overturned a $9.5 million jury verdict against Coca-Cola Co and Monster Beverage Co related to the alleged misuse of Hubert Hansen's publicity rights for their "Hansen's" brand drinks. The court ruled that the trial judge improperly interpreted evidence that should have been weighed by the jury, leading to a prejudiced outcome for the defendants. The case has been remanded for a new trial, with the appellate court emphasizing that the interpretation of asset transfer agreements regarding intellectual property should have been left to the jury.

title: Coca-Cola loses $4 billion in market value after Cristiano Ronaldo shuns Coke
summary: Coca-Cola's market value dropped by $4 billion after soccer star Cristiano Ronaldo removed its bottles during a Euro 2020 press conference, instead advocating for water. Following his actions, the company's share price fell and its market capitalization decreased from $242 billion to $238 billion. Coca-Cola, an official sponsor of the tournament, stated that everyone is entitled to their drink preferences.

title: Coke market value falls $4bn after Ronaldo snub
summary: Coca-Cola's market value dropped by $4 billion after Cristiano Ronaldo removed two of their bottles from a Euro 2020 news conference, advocating for water instead. The incident, followed by a share price drop, prompted a response from Coca-Cola and Euro 2020 organizers acknowledging diverse drink preferences and the importance of sponsorship. This occurred days before Ronaldo became the leading scorer in European Championship history.

title: Earth Island Sues Coca-Cola Over Greenwashing Claims & False Advertisement
summary: Earth Island Institute has filed a lawsuit against Coca-Cola, alleging the beverage giant is greenwashing its image despite being the world's largest plastic polluter. The lawsuit, filed on World Oceans Day, seeks to hold Coca-Cola accountable for misleading consumers about its sustainability practices, which the environmental organization claims cause significant damage to marine life and coastal communities. Earth Island is represented by Richman Law & Policy and argues Coca-Cola is in violation of the District of Columbia’s Consumer Protection Procedures Act.

title: Coca-Cola Sued for False Advertising Over Sustainability Claims
summary: Earth Island Institute has filed a lawsuit against Coca-Cola, alleging false advertising and greenwashing due to the company's sustainability claims, despite being the world's leading plastic waste generator. The suit, filed in District of Columbia Superior Court, does not seek damages but aims to halt Coca-Cola's deceptive marketing practices and encourage transparency regarding its plastic use. This action highlights a broader issue of corporations, including those in the fossil fuel industry, facing legal challenges over misleading environmental representations.

title: ICEE® Debuts THREE New Products to Kick-Off the Summer Season
summary: The ICEE Company, a subsidiary of J&J Snack Foods Corp., announced the launch of three new frozen novelty products: ICEE Red Cherry Ice Cream Float Tubes, ICEE Blue Raspberry Ice Cream Float Tubes, and mystery flavored ICEE Mermaid & Baby Narwhal Tubes. These new gluten-free, low-calorie treats are available nationwide to kick off the summer season. The expansion aims to offer more fun, frozen options for the whole family, building on ICEE's existing product lines.

title: How Coca-Cola United Streamlined Freestyle Order Management
summary: Coca-Cola Bottling Company United partnered with Happiest Minds Technologies to streamline its Freestyle order management process using Microsoft Power Automate RPA bots. This digital transformation, built on Microsoft Azure and Power Platform, allowed the company to avoid hiring additional full-time employees and freed up existing CRM agents for other projects. The automated system orchestrates the entire order process from purchase order to reconciliation in SAP, securely accessing internal and external systems.

title: Coca-Cola Becomes First Global Implementation Partner to Help Accelerate Cleanup
summary: The Ocean Cleanup and Coca-Cola have partnered to deploy Interceptors in 15 rivers worldwide by the end of 2022, aiming to accelerate plastic cleanup efforts. This partnership leverages Coca-Cola's global network to support deployment logistics, funding, and waste handling, while The Ocean Cleanup provides its technology and data solutions. Both organizations emphasize the importance of industry collaboration to address the global crisis of ocean plastic pollution.

title: The Ocean Cleanup and The Coca-Cola Company Announce Partnership | Press Release
summary: The Ocean Cleanup and The Coca-Cola Company announced a partnership to tackle plastic pollution in rivers, aiming to deploy cleanup systems in fifteen rivers over the next 18 months. Coca-Cola will serve as a Global Implementation Partner for The Ocean Cleanup’s river project, providing its global network and on-the-ground support to help deploy Interceptor™ solutions and develop waste management solutions for collected trash. This collaboration supports Coca-Cola's "World Without Waste" vision, focusing on recyclable packaging, collecting and recycling bottles, and promoting a debris-free environment.

title: The Coca-Cola Company And The Ocean Cleanup Join Forces To Clean Up 15 Of The World’s Most Polluting Rivers Of Plastic Waste
summary: The Coca-Cola Company and The Ocean Cleanup have partnered to clean up 15 of the world's most polluting rivers of plastic waste by the end of 2022. This collaboration involves deploying The Ocean Cleanup's Interceptor technology and utilizing Coca-Cola's global network and waste management expertise to collect and recycle plastics, contributing to a circular economy and Coca-Cola's "World Without Waste" strategy. The initiative aims to tackle rivers primarily in Southeast Asia and Central America, with collected plastic being recycled to make new bottles.

title: Krispy Kreme reveals its plans for an initial public offering trading as DNUT. (Published 2021)
summary: Krispy Kreme, owned by JAB Holding, announced its plans for an initial public offering, with shares set to trade on the Nasdaq under the symbol DNUT. The company reported a 17 percent increase in sales to $1.1 billion in its last fiscal year, but also saw losses nearly double to $60 million as it invested in transformation efforts. This IPO marks Krispy Kreme's second public listing, having previously gone public in 2000 before being acquired by JAB in 2016.

title: Coca-Cola HBC to Digitally Transform its End-to-End Planning with Blue Yonder
summary: Coca-Cola HBC is partnering with Blue Yonder to digitally transform its end-to-end supply chain planning using Blue Yonder's SaaS-based Luminate Planning solutions. This initiative aims to improve demand forecasting, optimize production and resource allocation, enhance sustainability efforts, and enable faster decision-making across its 28 operating countries. The new cloud-based system will integrate data from multiple sources to create an efficient and agile supply chain.

title: PepsiCo: a company profile 1898 - 2021
summary: This article provides a company profile of PepsiCo from its founding in 1898 up to 2021, detailing its history, mergers, and product acquisitions. It highlights significant advertising campaigns, both successful and controversial, and discusses the company's commitment to ESG values and sustainability efforts, such as the PepsiCo BottleLoop recycling initiative.

title: Coca-Cola HBC enables real-time delivery tracking for customers by partnering with Shippeo
summary: Coca-Cola HBC has partnered with Shippeo, a leading real-time transportation visibility solution provider, to enable real-time delivery tracking for its customers. This collaboration aims to streamline logistics operations, improve on-time deliveries, and enhance efficiency by leveraging Shippeo's platform to provide accurate ETAs and reduce administrative tasks. The project's initial rollout has been completed in several countries, with further expansion planned throughout 2021 and 2022.

title: Coca-Cola pulls plug on energy drink
summary: Coca-Cola has decided to discontinue its Coca-Cola Energy product in North America, little over a year after its launch. The company stated the decision is part of its strategy to focus on scaling successful innovations and being disciplined with products that do not gain sufficient traction. Coca-Cola Energy was initially launched in 25 countries and aimed to attract new consumers to the energy drink category.

title: Coca-Cola discontinues energy drink in N.America
summary: Coca-Cola Co announced it would discontinue its energy drink in North America, a product launched last year, as part of a strategy to streamline its portfolio and focus on faster-moving beverages. The decision comes as consumers return to traditional sodas and flavored sparkling waters post-pandemic, though Coca-Cola Energy will remain available in other global markets. The company emphasized a disciplined approach to investment, scaling successful innovations while divesting from products that lack traction.

title: Coke Discontinues Underperforming Energy Drink in North America
summary: Coca-Cola Co. is ceasing the sale of its Coca-Cola Energy drink in North America, little over a year after its launch. This decision is part of a broader strategy by the beverage giant to streamline its product portfolio. This follows earlier announcements regarding the discontinuation of Tab and Zico drink brands.

title: How Does the Coca-Cola Company Plan to Support its Hispanic Partners?
summary: Coca-Cola's Vice President, Alba Castillo Baylin, is leading an initiative to reaffirm the company's commitment to Hispanic community partners following a restructuring that integrated the Office of Latino Affairs into a larger department. This move, initially met with concern, aims to strengthen ties and support the Hispanic community through increased resources, marketing integration, and supplier diversity. The company emphasizes its dedication to diversity and inclusion within its workforce and supply chain, and continues to engage with Hispanic organizations to address their needs.
source: Abasto, Food and Beverage Industry News
source_domain: Abasto, Food and Beverage Industry News

title: Former Coca-Cola Employee Convicted of Stealing Trade Secrets for the Chinese Government
summary: A former Coca-Cola employee, Dr. Xiaorong (Shannon) You, was convicted of stealing trade secrets related to BPA-free coatings for beverage cans, intending to benefit the Chinese government. The trade secrets, valued at almost $120 million, were taken from Coca-Cola and Eastman Chemical Company. This case highlights the importance of strong trade secret protection practices and the risks associated with certain foreign government-backed programs.

title: Monster sees record sales; warns of aluminum can shortage
summary: Monster Beverage Corp. reported record sales in the first quarter of 2021, with net income up 11.5% to $315 million and quarterly sales growing 14.5% to $1.24 billion. Despite this, the company faced supply chain issues, particularly an aluminum can shortage, which impacted gross margins. Monster is seeking to source cans from South America and Asia and is evaluating pricing strategies to maintain market share without disturbing its successful business.

title: Pepsi Apple Pie and Candy Kraft Mac & Cheese: Why food giants are designing extreme new flavors
summary: Food and beverage giants like PepsiCo and Kraft Heinz are increasingly launching novel, extreme flavors, which are often remixes of familiar tastes. This trend, dubbed "new nostalgia," has been amplified by the COVID-19 pandemic as consumers seek both comfort and adventure while spending more time at home. These limited-time offerings often serve as marketing tools to generate social media buzz, even if they don't always result in direct sales, while others aim to drive sales through a blend of familiarity and novelty.

title: Unilever, Coca-Cola and Colgate-Palmolive join AB InBev’s sustainability accelerator
summary: Unilever, Coca-Cola, and Colgate-Palmolive have joined AB InBev's 100+ Accelerator to fund and pilot sustainable supply chain innovations. This collaboration aims to scale existing projects and broaden the accelerator's reach through financial backing and real-world testing of technologies in their own supply chains. The initiative seeks to supercharge the adoption of sustainable solutions for a more sustainable future.

title: Promo Coca Cola 2L Retornables
summary: Coca-Cola Andina launched a digital promotion in Argentina to encourage the use of 2L returnable bottles. Customers can exchange two empty 2L returnable bottles plus a small fee for a new Coca-Cola and another beverage (Sprite, Fanta, or Schweppes) in 2.0L returnable packaging. The promotion is valid until May 15th or while supplies last in specific regions of Argentina.

title: Monster Beverage Corp continues to shine in Q1 but aluminium shortages threaten growth - results data
summary: Monster Beverage Corp reported record first-quarter net sales and profits, with sales climbing 17.1% to US$1.24bn, driven by strong performance in its energy drinks segment, particularly internationally. However, the company flagged concerns over aluminium can supply shortages in North America and Europe, requiring them to source from South America and Asia, which could lead to logistical issues. The Coca-Cola Co, a significant shareholder, continues its involvement with MBC.

title: Coca-Cola appoints new general counsel
summary: The Coca-Cola Company has appointed Monica Howard Douglas as senior vice president and general counsel. She has been with the company for 17 years and will oversee Coca-Cola’s global legal function. Douglas succeeds Bradley Gayton, who is transitioning to a strategic consultant role, focusing on diversity initiatives within the company's legal framework.

title: Saadia Madsbjerg to be Named President of The Coca-Cola Foundation
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced that Saadia Madsbjerg will be named Vice President of Global Community Affairs for The Coca-Cola Company and President of The Coca-Cola Foundation, effective June 1. Madsbjerg, formerly of The Rockefeller Foundation and McKinsey & Co., brings extensive experience in corporate strategy, philanthropy, and impact investing. She will manage the Foundation's operations, including grant making and regulatory compliance, and succeeds Helen Price.

title: AB InBev 100+ Accelerator Partners With The Coca-Cola Company, Colgate-Palmolive, and Unilever For Sustainable Start-Up Innovation
summary: AB InBev's 100+ Accelerator has partnered with The Coca-Cola Company, Colgate-Palmolive, and Unilever to fund and pilot sustainable innovation in supply chains. This collaboration aims to accelerate the adoption of sustainable solutions globally by supporting start-ups focused on challenges like water stewardship, circular economy, sustainable agriculture, and climate action. The initiative combines the global reach and resources of these major corporations to drive environmental and social progress.

title: Coca-Cola FEMSA Announces First Quarter 2021 Results
summary: Coca-Cola FEMSA announced its first-quarter 2021 results, reporting a 0.9% increase in consolidated volumes, driven by growth in several Latin American countries, although offset by declines in Mexico and Uruguay. Total revenues saw a 1.5% decrease due to unfavorable currency translation, despite comparable revenues growing by 5.4%. The company also reported an increase in operating income and a significant 23.7% rise in majority net income, largely due to reduced interest expenses.

title: Chemist convicted of stealing BPA-free can liner trade secrets for a Chinese firm
summary: Xiaorong (Shannon) You, a former R&D chemist, was convicted of stealing trade secrets related to BPA-free can liners from Coca-Cola and seven chemical companies. Prosecutors alleged she intended to sell the intellectual property, valued at $120 million, to a Chinese firm supported by government programs including the Thousand Talents Plan. You was found guilty on 11 charges, including trade secret theft, conspiracy, wire fraud, and economic espionage, with sentencing scheduled for November 1.

title: Why some food and drink companies lost sales during the COVID-19 pandemic
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, some food and drink companies experienced sales declines due to factors like reliance on already struggling categories (e.g., soda, meat), dependence on "on-the-go" consumption, and failure to adapt to changing consumer preferences for premium or value products. Companies with diversified portfolios or those that innovated into growing segments like plant-based foods and sparkling water fared better. The article highlights that while some sales may rebound post-pandemic, companies need to focus on innovation and relevance to maintain growth.

title: AB InBev 100+ Accelerator partners with The Coca-Cola
summary: The AB InBev 100+ Accelerator has partnered with The Coca-Cola Company, Colgate-Palmolive, and Unilever to fund and pilot sustainable innovations specifically within supply chains. This collaboration aims to accelerate solutions in areas like water stewardship, circular economy, sustainable agriculture, and climate action, leveraging the combined global reach of these major corporations. The program provides funding and "hands-on" support to startups, with a strong focus on addressing both environmental and social challenges.

title: CEO Alison Watkins to exit Coca-Cola Amatil after Coca-Cola European Partners takeover
summary: Coca-Cola Amatil CEO Alison Watkins will depart the company following its acquisition by Coca-Cola European Partners, expected on May 10th. Watkins led CCA for nine years, overseeing significant operational changes and the negotiation of the CCEP takeover. Coca-Cola European Partners will also change its name to Coca-Cola Europacific Partners to reflect its expanded geographic footprint.

title: Monica Howard Douglas Elected Senior Vice President and General Counsel of The Coca-Cola Company
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced the election of Monica Howard Douglas as Senior Vice President and General Counsel, effective immediately. Douglas, a 17-year veteran of the company, will oversee global legal functions and report to Chairman and CEO James Quincey. Additionally, the board elected two other officers, Jeffrey Gilbert and Lucy Reid, and declared a regular quarterly dividend of 42 cents per common share.

title: Coca-Cola sees progress toward recovery | 2021-04-20
summary: Coca-Cola reported positive signs in the first quarter of 2021, with volume trends improving, though recovery remains uneven globally due to the pandemic. The company saw a return to March 2019 volume levels by March 2021, but warned of challenges from rising COVID-19 cases impacting away-from-home business. Coca-Cola introduced new products and initiatives, including smartwater+, Coca-Cola with Coffee, and Topo Chico Hard Seltzer, while maintaining its full-year guidance for organic revenue and EPS growth.

title: Home Depot to face boycott over Georgia voting curbs
summary: Religious leaders in Georgia are calling for a boycott of Home Depot due to the company's silence on the state's new voting restrictions. Activists argue that the new laws make it harder for Black people and other racial minorities to vote, and Home Depot has not joined other corporations in opposing the measures. Home Depot stated its belief that "all elections should be accessible, fair and secure and support broad voter participation."

title: Georgia religious leaders call for boycott of Home Depot over silence on voting laws
summary: A group of prominent Georgia clergy members is calling for a nationwide boycott of Home Depot. They criticize the company for its silence on the state's new voting restrictions and its refusal to meet with activists, contrasting its stance with other Georgia-based companies like Delta and Coca-Cola. The religious leaders are urging Home Depot to speak out against the new voting laws and meet with them to discuss changes.

title: Procter & Gamble Will Raise Prices On Baby And Feminine Care Products In September
summary: Procter & Gamble announced it will raise prices on baby care, feminine care, and adult incontinence products starting in September to offset rising commodity prices. This move follows similar announcements from competitors Kimberly-Clark and Coca-Cola, as companies expect a short-term bump in inflation as the economy recovers. The price increases will be mid-to-high single-digit percentages and will vary by brand.

title: Former Coca-Cola CEO, Neville Isdell On Courage, Conviction, And Respect
summary: This article highlights three key leadership lessons from former Coca-Cola CEO Neville Isdell: courage, conviction, and respect. It details how Isdell exemplified these traits through inspiring others, building alignment for growth, and deeply respecting traditions and individuals. The piece uses examples from his career, including the Coca-Cola turnaround, to illustrate these principles.

title: Georgia’s Voting Laws and Coca-Cola’s Complicated History
summary: This article examines Coca-Cola's complicated history with social and political issues, particularly in Georgia, its home state. It delves into the company's past dealings with racial justice movements and compares them to its recent, belated statement on Georgia's "Election Integrity Act." The piece explores the reactions from politicians, both Republican and Democrat, and discusses the challenges Coca-Cola faces in navigating these controversies while preserving its brand image.

title: How The Mastermind Behind LaCroix Puts The Fizz In Business
summary: The article profiles Nick Caporella, the CEO of National Beverage, detailing his unconventional approach to business that led to the success of LaCroix sparkling water. Despite competing with industry giants like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo, Caporella's unique marketing, innovative products, and strong leadership have driven significant growth and shareholder value for National Beverage. It also touches upon his personal journey from humble beginnings to becoming a successful entrepreneur.

title: Coca-Cola CEO says company will raise prices to offset higher commodity costs
summary: Coca-Cola announced it will raise prices on its beverages to counteract increasing commodity costs, following similar moves by other consumer goods companies. CEO James Quincey indicated that while the company is hedged for 2021, price increases will be necessary for 2022. The company plans to implement these changes intelligently, considering package sizes and optimizing price points for consumers, having last raised prices in 2018 due to aluminum tariffs.

title: Heres Why Keurig Dr Pepper Stocks 80% Rally Is Not Surprising
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP) stock has seen an 80% rally since March 2020 lows, reaching almost $36 per share. This surge is attributed to the company's resilience during the pandemic, driven by its revenue mix focused on bottled beverages and coffee brewing systems, which benefited from increased at-home consumption. Despite the stock being 40% above its 2018 level, its valuation is considered fair, and continued revenue and earnings growth are expected to maintain its current price.

title: The Coca-Cola Co. unveils oat milk line
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. is expanding its plant-based dairy alternatives portfolio with the introduction of Simply Oat milk under its Simply brand. This new line includes original, vanilla, and creamy varieties, all of which are lactose-free, vegan, gluten-free, and non-GMO. The launch of Simply Oat follows the brand's previous introduction of Simply Almond in February, marking its second milk alternative offering.

title: Taste the Transformation: How Coca Cola is Building a Digital-First Business
summary: Coca-Cola is undergoing a significant digital transformation to reverse declining revenues, focusing on experience, operational, business, and cultural changes. Key initiatives include AI-powered vending machines that personalize experiences and organizational shifts to increase agility and leverage data during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company aims to become a digital-first business by integrating technology into all aspects of its operations and customer engagement.

title: A look at origin, trade secrets and owner of soft drink company Dr Pepper dubbed better than Coca-Cola
summary: This article delves into the origins, trade secrets, and ownership of the soft drink company Dr Pepper, following a tweet by Ann Coulter claiming it to be superior to Coca-Cola. It explores the drink's creation by Charles Alderton in 1885, the various theories behind its name, and the legal battles that helped it achieve national distribution. The article also discusses the closely guarded secret formula of Dr Pepper and its current ownership by Keurig Dr Pepper.

title: Delta and Coca-Cola face backlash from Republicans after opposing Georgia voting law. (Published 2021)
summary: Delta Air Lines and Coca-Cola are facing strong backlash from Republicans after publicly opposing a new voting law in Georgia, which critics argue makes it harder for people to vote. Following the companies' statements, Georgia's governor accused Delta's chief executive of spreading false attacks, and state Republicans suggested increasing taxes on Delta as retribution. This situation highlights the contentious nature of corporate involvement in partisan politics, with other major Georgia companies, like UPS, opting for more neutral statements.

title: After calls to boycott Coca-Cola, CEO says the company has always opposed new Georgia voting law
summary: Coca-Cola CEO James Quincey stated the company has always opposed Georgia's new voting law, choosing to speak publicly after its passage. Critics have called for boycotts due to the law's perceived disenfranchisement of people of color, despite Coke's private lobbying efforts. Quincey used stronger language against the law, calling it "wrong" and needing change, after earlier expressions of disappointment from other company executives.

title: Charting market cross currents: S&P 500 pulls in from record close
summary: U.S. stocks are lower on Monday, with the S&P 500 and Dow Industrials pulling back from record closes. The decline is partly attributed to concerns over a hedge fund's forced liquidation. The Nasdaq Composite is striving to maintain support at its 2020 peak.

title: Snapple is getting a huge makeover, owner Keurig Dr. Pepper CEO reveals
summary: Keurig Dr. Pepper CEO Bob Gamgort announced a complete makeover for the iconic Snapple brand, focusing on new sustainable packaging made from 100% post-consumer recycled plastic. The company is refreshing its existing brands as part of a broader strategy following a strong financial year, which included market share gains and reduced financial obligations. This redesign will also save on shipping costs and reduce its carbon footprint, while maintaining the brand's great taste.

title: Who will replace Procter & Gamble's CEO David Taylor?
summary: This article discusses the potential succession planning for Procter & Gamble's CEO David Taylor, who is nearing retirement age. While there's no immediate pressure for a change given P&G's strong performance, the article identifies Jon Moeller, the current COO, as a frontrunner and also highlights several other key executives, including three women and two Asia-born leaders, who are being groomed for top positions. It also details the recent financial performance of various P&G business units and touches on Taylor's tenure and the company's past challenges and successes.

title: Vita Coco Won the Coconut Water Wars, but an Old Rival Is Planning a New Battle
summary: Mark Rampolla, founder of Zico coconut water, reacquired the brand from Coca-Cola after its discontinuation, aiming to revive it and challenge longtime rival Vita Coco. The article details Rampolla's determination to rebuild Zico Rising into a leading coconut water company, revisiting his fierce rivalry with Vita Coco's co-founder Michael Kirban, which characterized the early growth of the coconut water market in the U.S.

title: Kimberly-Clark Names Robert Long as Chief Research and Development Officer
summary: Kimberly-Clark Corporation announced the appointment of Robert Long as its new Chief Research and Development Officer, effective March 15, 2021. In this newly created role, Long will oversee global research, development, innovation, and quality functions, reporting directly to CEO Mike Hsu and serving on the executive leadership team. Long brings over four decades of experience from companies like The Coca-Cola Company and Procter & Gamble, where he held senior R&D and innovation leadership positions.

title: Hershey unveils new goals to address climate change
summary: Hershey has announced new environmental and carbon emission goals, aiming to reduce direct and indirect emissions by over 50% by 2030 compared to 2018. The company also plans to make all its plastic packaging recyclable, reusable, or compostable by 2030 and invest in energy efficiency. These initiatives align Hershey with a growing trend among food and beverage companies to enhance sustainability and address consumer demand for eco-friendly practices.

title: Heineken, The Coca-Cola Company and the Coca-Cola System in Brazil Announce Redesigned Distribution Partnership
summary: Heineken N.V., The Coca-Cola Company, and the Coca-Cola System in Brazil have agreed to redesign their distribution partnership in Brazil. This agreement will transition Heineken® and Amstel brands to HEINEKEN Brazil's distribution network, while Coca-Cola System in Brazil will focus on Kaiser, Bavaria, Sol, Eisenbahn, and other international brands, with an initial term until December 31, 2026. The new partnership offers both companies more flexibility and allows for exploration into non-alcoholic and alcoholic segments respectively, benefiting Brazilian consumers with wider options.

title: Smucker to cut 80 jobs closing Virginia coffee plant in 2022
summary: J.M. Smucker will cut 80 jobs by closing its liquid coffee plant in Suffolk, Virginia, in spring 2022. This closure is part of a broader corporate restructuring and follows an announcement of a partnership with JDE Peet's for its liquid coffee business. While the company reported strong overall sales growth, particularly in coffee and retail consumer foods, it is seeking a leaner organization and focusing its portfolio.

title: Coca-Cola Co. reduces virgin plastic use by 20 percent in North America
summary: Coca-Cola Co. has announced a 20 percent reduction in virgin plastic use across its North America portfolio compared to 2018, driven by its recycled-content initiatives. The company is actively introducing 100-percent recycled PET bottles for several brands in select markets and plans to transition Sprite to clear plastic bottles nationwide by 2022 to improve recyclability. These efforts are part of Coca-Cola's World Without Waste goals, emphasizing the importance of consumer recycling and infrastructure investment.

title: Covid-19 afecta ventas de Coca Cola FEMSA, caen 5.6% en 2020
summary: Coca Cola FEMSA (KOF) reported a 5.6% decrease in sales in 2020, reaching 183,615 million pesos, primarily due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic's lockdown and social distancing measures. Despite the challenges, the company's CEO, John Santa Maria, highlighted resilience and operational excellence, resulting in an increase in operating flow by 5% to 37,345 million pesos, though net profit decreased by 17.9%. KOF aims to continue its strategic and digital advancements to become a total beverage platform.

title: PepsiCo Halted From Selling Electrolyte Drink Amid TM Claim
summary: A Texas federal judge has issued a temporary restraining order preventing PepsiCo Inc. from launching its new Gatorade product, Gatorlyte, on February 21st. The halt comes after a Mexican sports drink manufacturer claimed that Gatorlyte is a clone of its own electrolyte beverage. This legal action targets PepsiCo and specifically its Quaker Oats Company and The Gatorade Company subsidiaries.

title: AB InBev files lawsuit against Constellation over use of Corona brand name
summary: AB InBev's Mexican arm, Grupo Modelo, has filed a lawsuit against Constellation Brands, alleging a violation of a brand licensing agreement regarding the use of the Corona name for hard seltzer. Grupo Modelo claims Constellation was only permitted to use the Corona brand for beer in the U.S., while Constellation maintains it has fully complied with the agreement. This legal dispute highlights the increasing competition and product category expansion within the alcohol sector, particularly in the rapidly growing hard seltzer market.

Origin Materials, a startup creating sustainable plastic from sawdust, is going public through a SPAC merger with Artius Acquisition in a $1.8 billion deal. The company aims to replace petroleum-based plastics with carbon-negative materials, having already secured partnerships with major brands like Danone, Nestle, and PepsiCo. This transaction is expected to fully fund Origin Materials until it achieves EBITDA and free cash flow positive status by 2025, enabling the construction of its first full-scale commercial plant.

title: Dollar Tree and Family Dollar Donated $2.7 Million to Charitable Partners in 2020
summary: Dollar Tree, Inc. and its Family Dollar brand, along with associate contributions, donated $2.7 million in 2020 to Boys & Girls Clubs of America, Operation Homefront, and United Way of South Hampton Roads. Vendor partners and customers also contributed millions, including a $1 million gift from The Coca-Cola Company. These funds supported youth programs, military families, and COVID-19 relief efforts in local communities.

title: IFF gives activist investor seat on board
summary: International Flavors & Fragrances (IFF) has offered Sachem Head Capital Management's Scott Ferguson a seat on its board, expanding it to 14 directors. This decision follows Sachem Head's reported $1 billion stake in IFF, with the activist investor aiming to improve financial performance and integrate DuPont Nutrition & Biosciences successfully. The move comes after concerns about IFF's integration challenges from previous acquisitions and its stock performance lagging competitors.

title: Lockdown living helps PepsiCo through pandemic, vaccine paves path to growth
summary: PepsiCo Inc. is predicting revenue growth in 2021, expecting pre-pandemic lifestyles to resume as economies reopen and COVID-19 vaccines are rolled out. The company navigated the health crisis better than Coca-Cola due to its reliance on grocery and retail channels, reporting an 8.8% rise in fourth-quarter revenue to $22.46 billion. PepsiCo anticipates a mid-single digit rise in annual organic revenue and a high-single digit increase in adjusted earnings, with some pandemic-driven changes like increased online shopping likely to persist.

title: Coca-Cola Transitions Brands to 100% rPET, Unveils New ‘Sip-Size’ Bottle
summary: Coca-Cola is transitioning several of its U.S. beverage brands to 100% recycled PET (rPET) bottles, excluding caps and labels, and introducing a new 13.2-oz "sip-size" bottle. These innovations aim to reduce new plastic use by over 20% compared to 2018, cutting greenhouse gas emissions. The company is also switching Sprite's packaging from green to clear plastic to improve recyclability and moving away from bioplastics for its Dasani brand in favor of 100% rPET.

title: ‘Aunt Jemima’ becomes ‘Pearl Milling Company,’ Salesforce announces permanent remote workforce, and Heineken to lay off 8,000
summary: This article covers several major corporate news items: the rebranding of "Aunt Jemima" to "Pearl Milling Company" amidst broader DEI initiatives, Salesforce's announcement of a permanent "work-from-anywhere" policy, and Heineken's plans to lay off 8,000 employees as part of its "EverGreen" strategy. It also touches on a viral Zoom court incident, a survey of catchy brand jingles, and Coca-Cola's new 100% recycled plastic bottles.

title: Coca-Cola Shares Recycled Bottle Redesign
summary: The Coca-Cola Company is transitioning to 100% recycled PET plastic bottles across several brands, including Coke, Coke Zero Sugar, Diet Coke, and Fanta, starting February 2021. This move is part of the company's "World Without Waste" initiative, aiming for 100% recyclable packaging by 2025 and 50% recycled content by 2030. The shift is expected to reduce new plastic use by over 20% across its North America portfolio and cut GHG emissions by 10,000 metric tons annually.

title: The Coca-Cola Company Introduces Bottles Made from 100% Recycled Materials* in the United States
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced the introduction of new 13.2oz bottles made from 100% recycled plastic material (rPET) in the United States, starting with its Coca-Cola brand, and expanding to DASANI and smartwater. This move is a significant step towards addressing plastic waste, aiming to reduce new plastic use by over 20% in North America compared to 2018 and supporting the company's World Without Waste goals. The company will also implement extensive on-package messaging to encourage consumers to recycle these new bottles.

title: Beer Run: As Budweiser Leaves Super Bowl, Rival Brews Battle For Attention
summary: As Budweiser opts out of a national Super Bowl ad for the first time in 37 years, rival brewers like Diageo, Boston Beer, and MolsonCoors are seizing the opportunity to market their brands. They are utilizing local ad inventory, digital campaigns, and social media to circumvent Anheuser-Busch InBev's long-standing national ad exclusivity during the game. This shift reflects a broader trend of advertisers seeking more cost-effective and targeted ways to reach consumers beyond expensive national Super Bowl spots.

title: Super Bowl Still Means Big Q1 Beer Volumes, But Full Year Impact Lessens
summary: The Super Bowl continues to drive significant beer sales volumes in Q1, topping $1.2 billion in traditional beer sales in 2020, along with substantial hard seltzer and FMB sales. However, its overall impact on annual beer sales volume has been declining since 2016, with Super Bowl week falling to 39th in sales volume ranking in 2020. Despite this, major beer companies like Anheuser-Busch InBev, Molson Coors, Constellation Brands, Heineken USA, and Diageo are investing heavily in regional advertising and marketing campaigns during the game to capture consumer attention.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper permanently closes Green Mountain Coffee Roasters Café, lays off employees
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper has permanently closed its Green Mountain Coffee Roasters Café in Waterbury, Vermont, which had been shut since March, leading to employee layoffs. The company stated that affected employees had been paid since March and would receive ongoing support, including severance packages. The number of layoffs is expected to be fewer than 50, representing less than 1% of the company's 26,000-person workforce, and the company is looking to fill 30 positions at other facilities.

title: Monster Unveils 2021 Product Slate But No Hard Seltzer Yet
summary: Monster Beverage Corporation did not announce a hard seltzer product during its 2021 Virtual Investors Meeting, despite rising speculation and previous reports of trademark filings. Instead, the company announced new products including slim cans of existing SKUs, line extensions, and redesigns, along with a co-CEO appointment. Monster also reported strong sales growth for the first nine months of 2020 but acknowledged being outpaced by some competitors in dollar sales growth.

title: Valero, USAA among San Antonio companies that donated to Republicans who voted to overturn presidential election results
summary: Two major San Antonio employers, Valero and USAA, are re-evaluating their political spending after the Jan. 6 Capitol assault, having donated significant sums to Republicans who voted to overturn the 2020 presidential election results. Valero has halted all political contributions, while USAA is re-evaluating its criteria. Other local companies like NuStar Energy and iHeartMedia also made substantial donations to these Republicans.

title: Coca-Cola, Tyson Foods and ADM among companies to suspend political donations
summary: Following the violent protests at the U.S. Capitol, major companies like Coca-Cola, Tyson Foods, and Archer Daniels Midland have announced the temporary suspension of political donations. This decision aligns with a broader corporate trend across various industries, prompted by the events and a growing consumer expectation for companies to reflect certain values. Companies are re-evaluating their political action committee activities and future contribution decisions in light of recent events.

title: Get High Dividend Exposure with the HDEF ETF
summary: The article discusses the Xtrackers MSCI EAFE High Dividend Yield Equity ETF (HDEF) as an option for investors seeking high dividend exposure with international diversification. HDEF offers exposure to developed markets outside the U.S., focusing on high-dividend stocks while hedging against currency risk. This strategy aims to provide stable dividend payments, exemplified by its top holding, Unilever PLC.

title: The Coca-Cola Co. acquiring BodyArmor for $5.6 billion
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. is acquiring full ownership of the sports nutrition company BodyArmor for $5.6 billion, adding to its previous 30% stake. BodyArmor will operate as a separate business unit within Coca-Cola North America, with its co-founder and president remaining involved. This acquisition aims to further Coca-Cola's innovation in hydration and health-and-wellness products.

title: The story behind Starbucks’ newest latte
summary: Starbucks introduced its new Pistachio Latte in 2021, a spin-off of the Starbucks Reserve Pistachio Latte first developed in 2019. The beverage, which features pistachio flavor with Starbucks espresso and steamed milk, was brought to market despite pandemic-related challenges during its development. Starbucks also launched other new items, including a Honey Almondmilk Cold Brew and Kale and Portabella Mushroom Sous Vide Egg Bites, and brought back seasonal favorites.

title: McCormick buys natural flavorings company FONA International for $710M
summary: McCormick & Co. has acquired natural flavorings provider FONA International for $710 million, significantly expanding its reach into growing categories like performance nutrition and health and wellness. This acquisition follows McCormick's purchase of Cholula hot sauce for $800 million in November, showcasing its strategy to broaden its portfolio of flavors, spices, seasonings, and condiments. FONA, with annual sales of about $114 million, is expected to see mid-to-high-single-digit growth and will play a role in McCormick's focus on health and wellness ingredients.

title: Agribusiness giants ADM, Bunge trading in ‘conflict’ palm oil, report says
summary: A report by Global Witness alleges that agribusiness giants ADM and Bunge are sourcing palm oil from Indonesian mills linked to land and human rights violations and environmental destruction. The report claims that these companies are not adequately addressing these allegations through their grievance processes, thereby passing "conflict" palm oil to major consumer brands. Both ADM and Bunge have denied failing to police suppliers but have pledged to investigate the claims.

title: Coca-Cola UNITED manages rapid growth with Microsoft Power Platform
summary: Coca-Cola UNITED successfully leveraged Microsoft Power Platform to manage rapid growth, expanding operations and sales significantly. The low-code platform enabled quick development of applications for order processing and event management, streamlining operations and improving customer satisfaction. This adoption allowed Coca-Cola UNITED to move away from time-consuming custom coding and innovate faster.

title: What advertising can do, markets can see, hear and consume
summary: Colgate-Palmolive dominates the Kenyan toothpaste market with a 59 percent share, largely due to increased advertising spend and effective marketing strategies that have driven brand awareness and consumer advocacy. The company's success is also attributed to its global strategy of adapting to local tastes, strong in-store execution in emerging markets, and early adoption of online shopping trends. These efforts have earned Colgate a high global penetration rate and a strong position among the world's top brands.

title: Coca-Cola to cut 2,200 jobs — most in the US — as part of restructuring
summary: Coca-Cola is cutting 2,200 jobs globally, with 1,200 in the U.S., through buyouts and layoffs as part of a restructuring plan accelerated by the pandemic. The company expects severance costs to range from $350 million to $550 million. This move is part of a larger strategy initiated by CEO James Quincey to streamline operations, focus on faster-growing brands, and adapt to evolving consumer tastes, including reducing its business units and discontinuing about 200 brands.

title: Coca-Cola cutting 2,200 jobs as coronavirus pandemic hurts sales
summary: Coca-Cola is laying off 2,200 workers globally, accounting for 17% of its workforce, as part of a restructuring accelerated by the coronavirus pandemic. The layoffs, costing $350 million to $550 million in severance, aim to streamline operations by reducing business units and brands, including ditching slow-selling products like Tab and Zico. The company plans to reinvest savings into growing brands and new product launches like Topo Chico Hard Seltzer.

title: Coca-Cola to cut 2,200 jobs globally
summary: Coca-Cola announced a global reduction of approximately 2,200 jobs as part of a reorganization effort, with 1,200 cuts in the U.S. and 500 in Atlanta. The company cited the pandemic as a "catalyst" for accelerating these organizational changes, which include an estimated $350 million to $550 million in severance expenses. This reorganization also involves cutting several brands like Odwalla juices and Zico coconut water.

title: Coca-Cola to Lay Off 2,200 Workers as it Pares Brands
summary: Coca-Cola announced layoffs for 2,200 workers, or 17% of its global workforce, as part of a restructuring effort to streamline its business units and brands. The pandemic accelerated these changes, with the company aiming to reduce its brand portfolio by half to 200, shedding slow-selling products and investing in growing brands and new launches. This move is expected to save the company money, with severance programs costing between $350 million and $550 million.

title: The Story of Taylor California Cellars, Coca-Cola’s Forgotten Foray Into the Wine Industry
summary: This article details Coca-Cola's ambitious but ultimately short-lived venture into the wine industry with Taylor California Cellars in the late 1970s and early 1980s. It covers how Coca-Cola acquired the established Taylor Wine Company, leveraged aggressive marketing tactics and innovative packaging to rapidly grow Taylor California Cellars, and the reasons behind its eventual divestment due to low profit margins and fierce competition from E. & J. Gallo. The article also explains how subsequent ownership changes and poor management led to the decline and near disappearance of the Taylor brand in American winemaking.

title: Why Kraft Heinz leaders say their new strategy will drive growth beyond the pandemic
summary: Kraft Heinz leaders are confident their new business strategy, rolled out in September 2020, will drive growth beyond the pandemic, despite initial delays and shifts in consumer behavior. The strategy focuses on reinvesting in brands, using a platform-based approach, and prioritizing consumer needs, which executives believe will lead to sustained success. This approach has already seen positive results in sales growth and consumer rediscovery of trusted brands during the pandemic.

title: Coca-Cola to Cut 2,200 Jobs Worldwide Amid Covid Challenges
summary: Coca-Cola Co. is implementing widespread job cuts, affecting 2,200 employees globally and 1,200 in the U.S., as part of deeper restructuring efforts. These reductions, representing 2.5% of the total workforce, are a response to the ongoing challenges posed by venue shutdowns impacting soft-drink sales amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The company aims to navigate a tough business environment through a combination of voluntary buyouts and layoffs.

title: Coca-Cola is cutting 2,200 jobs
summary: Coca-Cola is cutting 2,200 jobs globally, including 1,200 in the United States, due to declining sales during the pandemic. The company expects severance packages to cost between $350 million and $550 million. Coca-Cola is also streamlining its operating units and canceling 200 brands as it focuses on its most popular beverages.

title: Coca-Cola will cut 2,200 jobs worldwide as part of restructuring plan
summary: Coca-Cola announced cuts of approximately 2,200 jobs globally as part of a restructuring plan accelerated by the coronavirus pandemic. The beverage giant expects to incur $350 million to $550 million in severance costs from these job reductions. This move follows a strategic shift to slim down its portfolio and build new regional operating units, after seeing a 9% slide in net sales in the third quarter due to declining away-from-home consumption.

title: Coca-Cola to cut 2,200 jobs globally, including 1,200 in U.S.
summary: Coca-Cola Co announced it will cut 2,200 jobs globally, including 1,200 in the United States, as the COVID-19 pandemic accelerates its business restructuring efforts. The company had previously offered voluntary separation packages and stated that the pandemic acted as a catalyst to speed up planned changes. Approximately 500 job cuts will impact its metro Atlanta headquarters.

title: Coca-Cola Bottling Company United dispenses streamlined order management with RPA in Microsoft Power Automate
summary: Coca-Cola Bottling Company United implemented robotic process automation (RPA) using Microsoft Power Automate to streamline order and invoicing processes for its Freestyle vending machines. This solution, developed with Happiest Minds, automates an 11-step manual process, freeing up CRM agents and allowing the company to scale its Freestyle initiative more effectively. The RPA solution, dubbed "Asa," handles order entry, PO creation, supplier interaction, invoice processing, and data storage, significantly reducing labor costs and potential errors.

title: Coca-Cola kicks off massive agency review to 'fundamentally transform' its marketing
summary: Coca-Cola has launched a comprehensive global review of its media and creative planning and buying practices, along with its agency appointments. This initiative aims to enhance effectiveness and efficiency across various marketing investments, including media, creative, and production, as part of the company's digital transformation. While expected to generate cost savings, the primary goal is a fundamental redesign of its marketing model and consolidation of third-party agencies.

title: Companies Can Address the Impact of Single-Use Plastics in the Era of COVID-19
summary: Despite a temporary surge in single-use plastic consumption due to the COVID-19 pandemic, companies like Kimberly-Clark are continuing to push forward with long-term commitments to reduce plastic waste. The article highlights the significant environmental and economic costs of marine plastic pollution and details the strategies companies are employing, including product innovation, partnerships, and maintaining a long-term sustainability vision. It emphasizes the urgent need for collaboration between industry leaders, NGOs, and consumers to address the global plastic crisis.

title: Public relations agency Ogilvy Africa bags 11 wins at SABRE awards
summary: Ogilvy Africa and its clients secured 11 wins at the 2019 African SABRE Awards for their public relations campaigns. The awards recognized campaigns for clients like Safaricom, Coca-Cola, and Kenya Airways across various categories, highlighting the firm's integrated communications approach and ability to achieve earned media for clients. The awards will be presented in Kigali, Rwanda in May.

title: Coca-Cola sells bottling plant to Niagara Bottling
summary: The Coca-Cola Company has sold its water bottling facility in Centre County, Pennsylvania, to Niagara Bottling. The facility was sold to Milesburg Properties LLC, which shares a corporate office address with Niagara Bottling. A local commissioner expressed hope that Niagara Bottling will continue to be a positive community resource and employer.

title: Coca-Cola Sells Centre County Bottling Facility for $5.59 Million
summary: The Coca-Cola Company has sold its water bottling facility in Centre County, PA, to Milesburg Properties LLC for $5.59 million. Milesburg Properties LLC is associated with Niagara Bottling, a family-owned bottled water and soft drink manufacturer. The facility was originally owned by AquaPenn, then Danone, before Coca-Cola acquired majority interest.

title: Coca-Cola sells its Centre County production facility for $5.6 million
summary: The Coca-Cola Company has sold its Centre County water bottling plant to Milesburg Properties, LLC, which is affiliated with Niagara Bottling, for $5.593 million. The sale's impact on the estimated 100 employees at the facility is unclear, as neither company responded to requests for comment. Local commissioners hope Niagara Bottling will continue to be a good community resource and employer.

title: The Coca-Cola Company, PepsiCo, and Nestlé Named Top Plastic Polluters for Third Year
summary: For the third consecutive year, The Coca-Cola Company, PepsiCo, and Nestlé have been identified as the world's top plastic polluters, according to a report by Break Free From Plastic. The report, "BRANDED Vol III: Demanding Corporate Accountability for Plastic Pollution," highlights the continued reliance of these corporations on single-use plastics and the detrimental impact on communities, particularly in the Global South, despite their claims to address the plastic crisis. Activists are calling for these companies to end their addiction to single-use plastics and prioritize robust reuse systems.

title: Coca-Cola funded public health conferences in effort to shift blame for obesity: New study
summary: A new study reveals that The Coca-Cola Company sponsored international public health conferences to divert blame for the obesity epidemic from its products, focusing instead on physical activity and individual choice. Documents obtained by U.S. Right to Know show Coca-Cola collaborated with sponsored researchers to promote its messaging at these conferences, fostering relationships with public health leaders. The study argues for stronger protection of scientific knowledge dissemination from corporate influence, suggesting a model similar to the tobacco industry sponsorship ban.

title: Coca-Cola CFO prefers ‘scenario management’ to ‘scenario planning’
summary: John Murphy, CFO of The Coca-Cola Company, emphasizes "scenario management" over "scenario planning," advocating for adaptable strategies with multiple contingency plans rather than fixed projections. He highlights the evolving role of the CFO as a strategic business partner and the importance of understanding consumer trends, building a broad beverage portfolio, and maintaining a competitive edge through global reach and local ownership. Murphy also notes the pandemic as a catalyst for rapid change and stresses the company's commitment to social responsibility through the Coca-Cola Scholars Program.

title: Coca-Cola commits $500 million in additional spending with Black-owned suppliers
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced a commitment to increase spending with Black-owned suppliers by an additional $500 million over the next five years. This initiative aims to support Black entrepreneurs who have been significantly impacted by the coronavirus pandemic and systemic racial injustice. The company also expanded its Supplier Development training program and partnered with organizations like the National Minority Supplier Development Council to foster growth and economic empowerment for minority-owned businesses.

title: Coca-Cola Is Open to Inorganic Growth in Still Beverages
summary: Coca-Cola is looking towards inorganic growth, specifically acquisitions, to expand its presence in the high-growth still beverages market. This strategy is in response to the continued underperformance of carbonated soft drinks compared to categories like bottled water, ready-to-drink coffee, and energy drinks. The company has already made strategic moves, including the acquisition of Innocent Drinks and a stake in Suja Juice and Monster Beverage.

title: Coca Cola Brings Marketing Muscle to the Dairy Case
summary: Coca-Cola is partnering with Select Milk Producers to launch fairlife fluid milk nationally, aiming to revitalize the declining fluid milk category. This initiative is part of Dairy Management, Inc.'s $500 million effort with seven major companies to boost fluid milk sales through innovation and marketing. Fairlife milk offers increased protein and calcium, reduced sugar, and is lactose-free, showing promising results in test markets.

title: Teamsters Local 20 reaches agreement with Coca-Cola, ends Toledo strike
summary: Teamsters Local 20 workers in Toledo, Ohio, reached an agreement with Coca-Cola Consolidated, ending a two-week strike. The union ratified a new contract on Wednesday morning, November 18th, and workers returned to their jobs on Thursday, November 19th. The revised deal includes higher wages to offset increased health care coverage rates for the workers.

title: National businesses that got their start in Wilmington. Recognize any of these names?
summary: This article highlights several successful national businesses that originated in Wilmington, North Carolina, demonstrating the city's impact across various industries. Featured companies include Freaker USA (beverage insulators), Live Oak Bank (small business lending), KWIPPED (online equipment marketplace), PPD (pharmaceutical research), and Fuzzy Peach (frozen yogurt franchise). These businesses showcase Wilmington's entrepreneurial spirit, from a unique product on Shark Tank to a global pharmaceutical giant contributing to COVID-19 research.

title: San Diego firm Realty Income buys Coca-Cola building in Apopka for big price
summary: San Diego-based Realty Income has purchased the Coca-Cola building in Apopka, Florida, for a significant price. The acquisition is part of Apopka's Mid-Florida Logistics Park, which is currently the largest industrial development under construction in Central Florida, with potential for further expansion. This purchase highlights the growing real estate activity in the region, particularly driven by e-commerce.

title: Coke terminates agreement with recycling technology firm Loop Industries
summary: Coca-Cola Co. has terminated its agreement with Loop Industries Inc., a recycling technology firm, due to Loop's failure to meet a production milestone at a joint venture facility. This termination follows a report from Hindenburg Research questioning Loop's technology and a subsequent SEC subpoena, leading to a significant drop in Loop's stock price. Despite the termination, Coke expressed interest in exploring a new framework agreement with Loop.

title: Our agreement to acquire Coca-Cola Amatil
summary: Coca-Cola Europacific Partners (CCEP) announced a binding agreement on February 14, 2021, for a best and final offer to acquire Coca-Cola Amatil Limited (CCL). This acquisition is described as a strategic opportunity to combine two major bottlers, driving faster and more sustainable growth and solidifying CCEP’s position as the largest Coca-Cola bottler by revenue. The transaction aims to unlock enhanced value for shareholders and strengthen CCEP's partnership with The Coca-Cola Company.

title: Louisville's KFC Yum Center awards PepsiCo Inc. pouring rights in 10-year contract
summary: PepsiCo Inc. has secured a 10-year contract for pouring rights at Louisville's KFC Yum Center, replacing The Coca-Cola Co. The agreement also includes exclusive marketing rights and the transformation of the arena’s outdoor plaza into Pepsi Plaza. The partnership will also involve community programs through Pepsi's "Pepsi Stronger Together" initiative, focusing on education and youth in Louisville.

title: Coca-Cola and AWS reimagine the future of contactless experiences
summary: Coca-Cola Freestyle partnered with Amazon Web Services (AWS) to develop a "pour by phone" contactless experience for its beverage dispensers in response to evolving consumer behaviors during the pandemic. This innovation allows users to operate the machines via their smartphones by scanning a QR code, eliminating the need for physical contact. The solution was rapidly developed and deployed, and over 30,000 machines now have this touchless capability, with a full U.S. rollout planned by the end of 2020.

title: Coca-Cola works with bottlers to convert operations as it cuts 200 product lines
summary: Coca-Cola is cutting approximately 200 product lines, halving its brand portfolio, as part of a new operating plan accelerated by the coronavirus pandemic. The company will consolidate 17 operating units into nine and work with bottlers to convert operations, focusing on bigger, more scalable bets and a "fail fast" approach to innovation. This move aims to streamline its supply chain and enhance efficiency, with decisions on product lines largely finalized.

title: Say goodbye to San Francisco's iconic Coca-Cola sign
summary: San Francisco's iconic Coca-Cola billboard, a fixture in the South of Market area since 1937, is slated for removal by the Coca-Cola company. The removal, estimated to cost $100,000, is reportedly due to soaring rents. The sign was one of the longest actively operated commercial signs in the city.

title: Coca-Cola to Cut 200 Beverage Brands
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. is cutting more than half of its beverage brands, reducing its portfolio to about 200 products to focus on those with the greatest growth potential. This move includes retiring brands like Tab soda and Zico coconut water, freeing up resources to invest in stronger brands and new product launches. The decision, partly accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, aims to streamline the company's offerings and enhance profitability despite a recent decline in net revenues.

title: 'Our world needs more Black attorneys': New program aims to shake up lack up diversity
summary: Ford Motor Co., through its charitable arm and in collaboration with the Henry Ford Learning Institute, is launching the Ford Law Career Academy to address the lack of diversity in the legal profession. This four-year program will start in high schools, exposing students from working-class backgrounds to various aspects of law and encouraging more Black students to pursue legal careers. The initiative is a response to the static 5% representation of Black attorneys in the U.S. over the past decade, despite the strong interest in social justice among today's youth.

title: Coke bids adieu to 200 drink brands, slashing portfolio in half
summary: The Coca-Cola Company is cutting its beverage portfolio in half by discontinuing at least 200 brands by the end of the year to focus on more profitable products and emerge stronger from the pandemic. This move follows the discontinuation of Tab and includes other underperforming brands like Odwalla and ZICO, allowing Coke to streamline its offerings and invest in promising new ventures like Topo Chico Hard Seltzer.

title: Coca-Cola emerges from lockdown blues as out-of-home demand recovers
summary: Coca-Cola reported better-than-expected revenue and profit in the third quarter as the reopening of theaters and restaurants boosted "away-from-home" demand, which had significantly declined during earlier lockdowns. Despite concerns about potential regional lockdowns due to rising COVID-19 cases, the company is streamlining its product portfolio and noted increased consumer purchases of sparkling soft drinks and juices from grocery stores.

title: Coke is canceling 200 drink brands
summary: Coca-Cola is eliminating 200 brands, or half of its portfolio, to focus on more profitable offerings and higher-growth drinks. This move includes discontinuing beloved brands like Tab, Zico, and Odwalla, with further cuts expected in the "hydration" category. The company aims to reallocate resources to better-performing products, especially after a challenging period during the pandemic which saw net revenues decline by 9% in the third quarter.

title: Ecolab Partners With Water.org to Improve Access to Clean, Safe, Sustainable Water
summary: Ecolab has partnered with Water.org to improve access to clean, safe, and sustainable water for 100,000 people in at-risk watersheds in India. This collaboration aims to provide equitable access to water, sanitation, and hygiene solutions while contributing to positive recurring water benefits in high-stress river basins. The partnership aligns with Ecolab's 2030 Impact Goals and its involvement in the Water Resilience Coalition, emphasizing social responsibility and community well-being.

title: Can shortage affects Milwaukee's brewers unevenly
summary: The pandemic, combined with the summer beer boom, has led to a significant aluminum can shortage in the U.S., affecting beverage sectors nationwide. Milwaukee brewers are experiencing this shortage unevenly, with some facing higher prices and limited supply, while others are less impacted due to their size or proactive measures. The article highlights how larger companies often receive preferential treatment from suppliers during shortages, leaving smaller craft breweries to bear the brunt of the issue, though some hope for future improvements in production.

title: Keurig is a machine: How the beverage giant is leveraging A.I. to fuel growth
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP) has shown impressive market share growth in the beverage industry, leveraging a broad product portfolio and strategic use of AI to adapt to changing consumer habits during COVID-19. CEO Bob Gamgort's vision of combining hot and cold beverage segments and utilizing data from connected Keurig brewers allowed KDP to rapidly identify and respond to shifts in demand, such as increased at-home coffee consumption and preferences for large packs of canned soft drinks. This strategy has resulted in strong revenue and profit growth, positioning KDP for future acquisitions and continued expansion.

title: Coca-Cola retiring Tab, Zico brands
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. is discontinuing Tab diet soda and Zico coconut water, among other brands, as part of a portfolio refresh aimed at focusing on products with higher growth potential. This move, which was accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, seeks to free up resources for more scalable brands and streamline their offerings due to changing consumer behaviors and supply chain challenges. The company plans to invest more in brands like Minute Maid, Simply, and Topo Chico.

title: Coca-Cola discontinues TaB diet soda in the US
