summary: Coca-Cola is discontinuing TaB, its first-ever diet soft drink launched in 1963, in the US as part of a larger plan to streamline its SKUs and prioritize brands with greater growth potential. The company is retiring underperforming products, including Odwalla, Zico coconut water, and Coca-Cola Life, to focus resources on stronger brands like Diet Coke and Coke Zero Sugar. This move, accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, aims to free up investments for burgeoning categories such as hard seltzer.

title: Coca-Cola to end production of Tab soda
summary: Coca-Cola announced it will discontinue its iconic Tab soda, originally introduced in 1963 as the company's first diet cola. This move is part of the beverage maker's broader strategy to streamline its brand portfolio, focusing on products with significant growth potential, and follows the closures of other brands like Odwalla and Zico. The company plans to cut more than half of its 500 brands, reinvesting saved R&D and marketing dollars into growing brands like Aha sparkling water and Topo Chico.

title: Coca-Cola will stop making Tab diet soda, company announces
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced it will retire Tab diet soda and other "underperforming products" by the end of the year as part of a portfolio rationalization. Tab, Coke's first diet soda launched in 1963, has seen declining sales, accounting for less than 0.03% of Coca-Cola's sales by 2017. The company plans to reallocate resources from these discontinued brands to growing brands like Diet Coke and Coca-Cola Zero Sugar, and to fund promising innovations.

title: Coca-Cola to retire Tab, its first diet soda, as it trims its portfolio
summary: Coca-Cola is retiring Tab, its first diet soda, and several other less popular beverages by the end of the year to streamline its portfolio. This move is accelerated by the coronavirus pandemic, allowing the company to focus on larger brands and products with higher growth potential. Tab, introduced in 1963, saw its popularity decline after the launch of Diet Coke in 1982.

title: Coca-Cola is discontinuing Tab after nearly 60 years
summary: Coca-Cola is discontinuing Tab, its first-ever diet soda, after nearly 60 years, as part of a broader effort to streamline its product lineup and focus on bestsellers. The decision, though hastened by the pandemic, was already underway to allow the company to invest more in powerhouse brands like Diet Coke and Coke Zero. Tab had maintained a small but devoted following despite its growth being largely cannibalized by Diet Coke's introduction in 1982.

title: Sempra Energy Named to Forbes JUST 100 List
summary: Sempra Energy was named to the Forbes JUST 100 list, ranking 96th among U.S. publicly traded corporations for its performance on issues important to the American public. The list evaluates companies based on factors such as fair wages, human rights, worker training, ethics, diversity, and worker health and safety. Lisa Alexander, Sempra's senior vice president of corporate affairs, expressed honor at the recognition for creating long-term sustainable value.

title: Loop Industries (LOOP) stock: Tapping into infinite plastic recycling
summary: Loop Industries aims to overcome the limitations of mechanical recycling through its patented chemical recycling technology, which allows for unlimited plastic recycling and substitutes virgin plastics. The company, which is pre-revenue, has already secured packaging deals with major consumer brands like PepsiCo and Coca-Cola, aligning with global sustainability targets. Loop Industries plans to expand its operations globally through partnerships and eventually license its technology as a key growth driver.

title: ARKO / GPM Expands to Almost 3,000 Combined Company Operated and Wholesale Sites Across 33 States
summary: ARKO Holdings, Ltd. / GPM Investments, LLC announced the closing of its acquisition of Empire Petroleum Partners' fuel distribution business and retail locations, expanding its network to nearly 3,000 sites across 33 states and doubling its annual fuel distribution to over 2 billion gallons. This strategic acquisition is a significant milestone for Arko, especially as it moves forward with its business combination with Haymaker Acquisition Corp. II, which is expected to result in the combined company being publicly listed on NASDAQ under the ticker ARKO. The deal enhances GPM's scale, diversifies its business mix, and significantly increases its cash flow with the addition of approximately 1,500 independently operated fueling stations and 85 company-operated convenience stores.

title: Kevin Smith
summary: This article profiles Kevin Smith, Chief Marketing Officer at Rollins Inc., highlighting his circuitous career path through global brands like Coca-Cola and the NFL before joining Rollins. It details how his diverse experiences prepared him for his current role, particularly in managing the 120-year-old Orkin brand and adapting it to modern times. The piece also emphasizes Smith's commitment to family, his data-driven marketing approach, and Rollins' focus on talent acquisition as keys to success.

title: Coca-Cola to discontinue Zico coconut water and consider other cuts
summary: Coca-Cola is discontinuing its Zico coconut water brand and considering cutting other less-popular versions of Coke and Diet Coke as part of an effort to streamline its portfolio. This move follows ongoing efforts by the beverage giant to focus on offerings with large-scale potential and improve operational efficiency during the pandemic. Brands like Diet Coke Feisty Cherry, Coke Life, and Hubert's Lemonade are under review, while the company also plans buyouts for 4,000 employees as part of a broader restructuring.

title: Coca-Cola is discontinuing Zico, its coconut water brand
summary: Coca-Cola is discontinuing its Zico coconut water brand as part of a broader strategy to streamline its beverage lineup and focus on best-selling products. This move follows an earlier decision to discontinue the Odwalla juice and smoothie brand, and is part of an ongoing effort to eliminate "zombie brands" that are not growing. The company aims to cut costs and ease strain on supply chains amid declining beverage sales during the pandemic.

title: La Colombe Coffee Roasters Signs 10-Year Distribution Pact with Molson Coors
summary: La Colombe Coffee Roasters has signed a 10-year exclusive distribution agreement with Molson Coors Beverage Company for its ready-to-drink coffee products, initially targeting drug and convenience channels with plans for broader expansion. This partnership aims to significantly boost La Colombe's market presence, particularly in retail sectors where it currently has limited reach, building on its strong sales growth that has outpaced the RTD coffee category. Molson Coors benefits by adding an "above-premium" non-alcoholic offering to its expanding portfolio, marking another step in its strategy beyond traditional alcoholic beverages.

title: PepsiCo (PEP) Locks Distribution Deal for evian in Canada
summary: PepsiCo's subsidiary, PepsiCo Beverages Canada, has signed an exclusive distribution agreement with Danone Waters of America to distribute evian natural spring water across Canada starting January 2021. This partnership aligns with PepsiCo's hydration strategy and is expected to expand evian's reach and accelerate its growth. The deal comes as beverage companies like PepsiCo, Coca-Cola, Molson Coors, and Boston Beer are revamping their product portfolios to meet altered consumer preferences, particularly focusing on health and wellness offerings.

title: Will Pepsi’s Driftwell ‘ScaleWell’?
summary: The article analyzes the market viability of PepsiCo's new sleep aid beverage, Driftwell, examining its pricing, placement, product attributes, and promotional strategy. It contrasts Driftwell's approach with Pepsi's traditional mass-market successes like Bubly, highlighting the challenges of scaling a niche functional beverage. The author suggests that for Driftwell to succeed, Pepsi will need patience, effective consumer learning, and a focus on building credibility for its active ingredients to eventually target the broader market of OTC sleeping pills.

title: How Coca-Cola Is Using an Authentic Voice to Make a Difference
summary: This article highlights how Coca-Cola is leveraging an authentic voice to drive change and connect with consumers, especially through its sustainability efforts and social justice initiatives. Bea Perez, Coca-Cola's chief public affairs, communications, sustainability and marketing assets officer, discusses the company's evolution in communicating sustainability as a growth story and its commitment to values like transparency and action regarding social issues. The piece emphasizes the ongoing journey for brands in these areas, advocating for industry-wide collaboration.

title: Compromiso y solidaridad de Industria Mexicana de Coca-Cola con las tienditas
summary: Dino Troni, VP at Coca-Cola de México, elaborates on how the Mexican Coca-Cola Industry (IMCC) collaborates with small shops and businesses to boost their sales and improve security for both the businesses and their customers. The article highlights the commitment and solidarity of the Mexican Coca-Cola Industry in supporting these local establishments.

title: Campbell’s soup? Canned pumpkin? What’s missing from your grocery store shelves during the pandemic, and why
summary: This article explores why certain grocery items like Campbell's soup, canned pumpkin, and popular soft drinks have been missing from store shelves during the coronavirus pandemic. Manufacturers like Campbell Soup Co. and Frito-Lay streamlined their product offerings to focus on high-demand items, while issues with processing and timing affected other categories. The situation highlights shifts in production priorities and consumer purchasing behavior during the pandemic.

title: NHRA drag racing series files lawsuit against Coca-Cola for terminating sponsorship
summary: The NHRA has filed a lawsuit against Coca-Cola, the parent company of its title sponsor Mello Yello, for prematurely terminating a sponsorship deal that was set to run through 2023. The drag racing series alleges Coca-Cola used the COVID-19 pandemic as an excuse to break the contract, leading to significant financial impact on the racing community. Coca-Cola has stated that the NHRA's allegations are unfounded and that they will defend the lawsuit.

title: J&J Snack Foods names Walmart, Coca Cola, Home Depot veteran Ken Plunk as CFO
summary: J&J Snack Foods Corp. has appointed Ken Plunk as senior vice president and CFO, effective September 21, 2020. Plunk brings extensive corporate and operational finance experience from leadership roles at Walmart, Home Depot, and Coca-Cola, having previously overseen financial planning and analysis for Walmart's international portfolio. He also served as CFO for Walmart China and held senior finance positions for Sam's Club and U.S. finance.

title: Coca-Cola United to invest $5M to expand warehouse, affecting 65 jobs
summary: Coca-Cola Bottling Company United Inc. plans to invest $5 million to convert its Birmingham production facility into additional warehouse and loading space to optimize its distribution system. This strategic move, aimed at improving customer service and fleet solutions, will affect 65 employees who will be offered other opportunities within the company in the Southeast. Production will shift to other United plants in Alabama, Georgia, and Tennessee, with a goal to retain all affected employees.

title: Academy Sports + Outdoors Gives Back to St. Jude
summary: Academy Sports + Outdoors has significantly contributed to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital through its annual holiday campaigns. Starting in 2020 by selling long-sleeved T-shirts, the company expanded its efforts to include lounge pants, raising over $2.7 million for St. Jude to ensure families never receive bills for treatment, travel, housing, or food.

title: PepsiCo is launching a drink to get a piece of the $1 billion sleep aid industry
summary: PepsiCo is entering the $1 billion sleep aid industry with a new drink called Driftwell, an "enhanced water" designed to promote relaxation and ease stress. The drink contains L-theanine and magnesium, targeting the growing functional beverage category. This move aims to diversify PepsiCo's portfolio beyond carbonated soft drinks and capitalize on the consumer demand for health and wellness products.

title: Coca-Cola FEMSA recauda más de 700 millones de dólares con bono verde
summary: Coca-Cola FEMSA, the largest Coca-Cola bottler by sales volume, successfully issued its inaugural green bond in the international market, raising $705 million. This issuance, with a 12-year term and a coupon rate of 1.850%, is noted as the largest of its kind for a Latin American issuer and will fund green projects related to climate change, water care, and circular economy initiatives. Legal counsel for the transaction included Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton for the issuer and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, alongside Galicia Abogados, for the underwriters BofA Securities, J.P. Morgan Securities, and Morgan Stanley.

title: The Coca-Cola Company Announces New Senior Appointments
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced new senior appointments as part of its restructuring into nine new operating units and five global category teams, supported by Platform Services. These changes, effective January 1, 2021, aim to streamline operations, reduce duplication, and accelerate new product scaling. New presidents were named for various geographical operating units, global categories, and key marketing roles, with leadership reporting to President and COO Brian Smith and CMO Manolo Arroyo.

title: Boston Beer Founder Jim Koch Makes Forbes’ Rankings of Wealthiest Americans in 2020
summary: Jim Koch, founder of The Boston Beer Company, has made Forbes' "definitive ranking of the wealthiest Americans in 2020" for the first time with a net worth of over $2.6 billion, ranking at No. 327. His inclusion follows a significant increase in Boston Beer's stock value, driven by strong sales of Samuel Adams beer and Truly hard seltzer during COVID-19 lockdowns. The article also highlights several other individuals with ties to the beer industry who made the Forbes list, including the Reyes brothers, Gayle Benson, and the Santo Domingo brothers.

title: Last Call: New Generation Steps Up at Schell’s Brewery; Virginia Craft Brewers Guild Elects New Chair; NBWA Beer Purchasers’ Index Expands in August
summary: This article covers several updates in the beer industry, including a new generation taking over management at Schell’s Brewery, the Virginia Craft Brewers Guild electing its first female chair, and the NBWA Beer Purchasers’ Index expanding significantly in August 2020 due to increased off-premise sales. Other industry news includes Molson Coors' investment to quadruple Blue Moon Light Sky production, Anheuser-Busch's new VP of marketing for its beyond beer division, and the FDA's updated labeling regulations for gluten-free and gluten-reduced beer.

title: Coca-Cola announces leaders of new operating units | 2020-09-03
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. announced a series of leadership appointments as part of its restructuring efforts, affecting its nine new operating units and five global category teams. These changes, effective Jan. 1, 2021, aim to streamline operations and reduce complexities. Key appointments include Henrique Braun for Latin America, Nikos Koumettis for Europe, Nancy Quan as chief technical and innovation officer, and several others leading new geographic and category units.

title: The Coca-Cola Company Announces Leaders for New Operating Units and Beverage Categories
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced new leadership appointments for its nine operating units and five global beverage categories as part of a broader reorganization first announced on August 28th. These changes, effective January 1, 2021, aim to streamline operations, eliminate redundancies, and accelerate new product scaling. The company also detailed operational leaders within its largest units and senior vice presidents of marketing.

title: Califia Farms names CPG veteran Dave Ritterbush as CEO
summary: Califia Farms has appointed Dave Ritterbush as its new CEO, with founder Greg Steltenpohl retiring from the role but remaining on the board as an executive director. Ritterbush brings extensive CPG experience, most recently serving as CEO of Quest Nutrition, which was acquired by Simply Good Foods for $1 billion. This leadership change comes after a period of significant growth for Califia Farms, which recently launched new products and completed a $225 million funding round.

title: Plant-based food maker Laird Superfood files for $40M IPO
summary: Laird Superfood, a plant-based superfood company, has filed for a $40 million IPO with the SEC under the ticker symbol LSF. The company reported revenues of $13.1 million in 2019 and $11.1 million in the first half of 2020, aiming to capitalize on increased consumer demand for natural, organic, and functional foods, especially during the pandemic. Danone Manifesto Ventures, the corporate venture arm of Danone, currently holds a 13.4% stake in Laird Superfood.

title: Plastic Waste Management Market Business Strategies
summary: The article covers the Plastic Waste Management Market's business strategies, forecasting its growth to 2027 and analyzing the impact of COVID-19. It details market segmentation by service, polymer type, source, and end-use, highlighting key players and factors driving market expansion, such as the increasing adoption of recycled plastic and the need to address overfilled landfills. The report provides a comprehensive analysis for stakeholders to make informed business decisions.

title: Coca-Cola to offer buyouts to 4,000 employees, with layoffs to follow
summary: Coca-Cola announced it would offer buyouts to approximately 4,000 employees in the United States, Canada, and Puerto Rico as part of a restructuring effort to streamline its business. The company expects global severance programs to cost between $350 million and $550 million and will reduce its 17 business units to nine. This move is part of CEO James Quincey's strategy to transform Coca-Cola into a "total beverage company" and adapt to changing consumption habits and sales hits due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Coca-Cola to cut business units from 17 to 9
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. is reorganizing its business structure, reducing its 17 business units to nine. This restructuring aims to streamline operations, enhance marketing, and focus on innovation within five global beverage categories, and will involve employee buyouts and layoffs. The company expects global severance programs to cost between $350 million to $550 million.

title: The Coca-Cola Company Announces Strategic Steps to Reorganize its Business for Future Growth
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced strategic steps to reorganize its business for future growth, including establishing new operating units and global beverage category leads, supported by a new Platform Services organization. The reorganization aims to streamline operations, enhance marketing effectiveness, and align the workforce to new priorities, which will involve both voluntary and involuntary employee reductions with anticipated severance costs ranging from $350 million to $550 million. These changes are designed to better pursue its "Beverages for Life" strategy and capture growth in a fast-changing market.

title: Coca-Cola Co. restructuring business
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. is undergoing a significant reorganization, reducing its operating units from 17 to 9 and creating a platform services group to improve scale and expertise. This restructuring aims to drive growth, prioritize strong brands, and includes a voluntary separation program for approximately 4,000 employees in the US, Canada, and Puerto Rico, with similar programs internationally, incurring an estimated cost of $350 million to $550 million. A portfolio review is also underway to focus on global, regional, and local brands with growth potential across five key categories.

title: Coca-Cola to Reorganize its Business, Realign Workforce for Future Growth
summary: The Coca-Cola Company is reorganizing its business to pursue a "Beverages for Life" strategy, creating a networked global organization with new operating units and five marketing category leadership teams. This restructuring aims to streamline operations, enhance marketing effectiveness, and will involve significant changes to its workforce, including voluntary and involuntary reductions, with severance expenses estimated between $350 million and $550 million.

title: Coca-Cola says it will cut thousands of workers
summary: Coca-Cola announced it will eliminate thousands of jobs globally, offering buyouts to 4,000 employees in the U.S. and Canada, with similar offers for international divisions. The company frames these "strategic" cuts as part of its "Beverage for Life strategy," despite the significant impact of the pandemic on its sales from venues that have been largely closed. Revenue tumbled 28% in its most recent quarter, and its shares are down about 13% this year.

title: Investor, Philanthropist Warren Buffett Turns 90
summary: The article celebrates Warren Buffett's 90th birthday, highlighting his career as a renowned investor and philanthropist. It delves into his early life, his journey to becoming CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, and his investment philosophy which emphasizes value investing, patience, and emotional control. The piece also acknowledges his substantial philanthropic contributions and shares several of his famous quotes on investing and life.

title: Whirlpool Corporation Names Winn Everhart Senior Vice President of U.S. Operations
summary: Whirlpool Corporation announced the appointment of Winn Everhart as Senior Vice President of U.S. operations, effective October 1, 2020. Everhart, previously with Coca-Cola Company, will oversee U.S. commercial and business operations, including Brand and Strategy, Product Marketing, Sales, Consumer Services, and Integrated Supply Chain. This new role aims to enhance leadership capacity for market growth opportunities within the company.

title: Why R&D is ‘the wind beneath marketing’s wings’ at Coca-Cola: AI, analytics, and more
summary: Coca-Cola, despite being a global brand, continuously innovates using AI and analytics to stay relevant. The company is streamlining its brand portfolio and leveraging technology for consumer insights, such as using image recognition for targeted advertising and AI-powered analytics with NetBase Quid to understand consumer behavior and preferences. This integration of R&D and marketing, driven by technology, is critical for future growth and brand enhancement.

title: Rivera to lead Coca-Cola North America
summary: Alfredo Rivera has been appointed president of Coca-Cola North America, succeeding James L. Dinkins. Rivera, who joined the company in 1997, previously led Coca-Cola's Latin America group since 2016. Dinkins will serve as a senior adviser until his retirement in February.

title: August 24, 2020 - - 8-K: Current report filing
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced that Alfredo Rivera will become president of Coca-Cola North America, effective immediately. Rivera, a 23-year veteran of the company who previously led the Latin America group, replaces James L. "Jim" Dinkins, who is retiring after more than three decades with the company. Dinkins will serve as a senior advisor until his retirement on February 28, 2021.

title: Alfredo Rivera Named New President of Coca-Cola North America
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced Alfredo Rivera as the new president of Coca-Cola North America, succeeding Jim Dinkins who is retiring. Rivera, a 23-year company veteran, previously led the Latin America group. Dinkins will serve as a senior advisor until his retirement in February 2021.

title: Top 100 Food and Beverage Company Highlights: The Coca-Cola Company
summary: The Coca-Cola Company experienced a 28% decline in Q2 revenue but also saw improved global sales volume as lockdowns eased. The company announced the discontinuation of its Odwalla juice brand and fully acquired dairy brand Fairlife. Coca-Cola is also investing €1 billion in France for development goals and unveiled sample bottles made from recycled marine plastics as part of its sustainability efforts.

title: AB InBev y Coca-Cola se alían para la distribución de sus productos
summary: AB InBev and Coca-Cola have partnered in Chile for a five-year agreement to improve their production and distribution processes. This alliance aims to boost AB InBev's production capacity in Chile and diversify Coca-Cola's business into alcoholic beverages. The article also touches on other regional news like Knorr's solidarity campaign in Argentina, Starbucks' special edition cup in Mexico, and Facebook's integration of messaging services.

title: Assurant Acquires Fixt Onsite Mobile Device, Smartphone, Tablet Repair Company
summary: Assurant ($AIZ) has acquired Fixt, an on-demand mobile device support and repair services provider for smartphones and tablet computers. Financial terms were not disclosed for this M&A deal. Fixt's platform allows consumers to schedule local, onsite repairs and manages logistics for employee devices, with a network of over 1,500 repair technicians.

title: Luis Vives por acuerdo Coca-Cola Embonor S.A. y AB InBev: “Estamos dando un gran paso en la estrategia de crecimiento sostenible, orgánico y consistente que venimos desarrollando en los últimos años”
summary: Coca-Cola Embonor S.A. and Embotelladora Andina S.A. have reached a commercial agreement with Cervecería Chile S.A. (AB InBev) for the distribution of AB InBev's beer brands in Chile. This 5-year renewable contract, starting in late 2020, includes popular brands like Corona, Stella Artois, and Budweiser. The agreement is expected to increase Coca-Cola Embonor's annual sales volume in Chile by over 10%, aligning with its strategy to diversify its product portfolio.

title: Andina y Cervecería Chile firman contrato para venta, comercialización y distribución
summary: Embotelladora Andina S.A. and Coca-Cola Embonor S.A. have signed a five-year distribution contract with Cervecería Chile S.A. to handle the sale, commercialization, and distribution of Cervecería Chile's main brands in specific regions of Chile. This move is part of Andina's strategy to grow and diversify its product portfolio, aiming for an approximate 5% EBITDA margin on revenues from this operation. The contract includes popular brands like Corona, Stella Artois, and Budweiser, with anticipated volumes of 28.3 million unit cases in the designated territories.

title: Why BlackLine founder-CEO Therese Tucker—who broke some of tech’s toughest gender barriers—is stepping down
summary: Therese Tucker, founder and CEO of financial software company BlackLine, is stepping down from her CEO role in January 2021, transitioning to executive chair. She will be succeeded by Marc Huffman, current president and COO. Tucker discusses the transition, how the company is addressing racial justice, and her perspective on having a male successor, emphasizing her focus on the company's best interests and continued involvement in product development.

title: 'Space cola wars' at 35: When Coca-Cola, Pepsi tested soda in space
summary: This article revisits the "space cola wars" of 1985, detailing how Coca-Cola and Pepsi developed specialized cans to dispense carbonated beverages in the microgravity environment of space aboard the space shuttle Challenger. Astronauts, including John-David Bartoe who initially found the experiment frivolous, evaluated the functionality of these cans, leading to observations about "wet burps" due to unreleased gas. Both companies leveraged this historic event for promotion, with Coca-Cola continuing efforts to develop space-friendly soda dispensers.

title: Dr Pepper is the latest pandemic shortage
summary: Dr Pepper has become the latest product to experience widespread shortages in some parts of the U.S. due to increased demand during the pandemic. Keurig Dr Pepper, the company owning the brand, stated that sales have consistently risen over the past four years, and they are working with distributors to address low inventory levels, while also not commenting on aluminum can shortages impacting other beverage producers. This shortage, similar to other household items during the pandemic, is attributed to a shift in consumer behavior towards at-home consumption of canned beverages.

title: Our response to Coronavirus (COVID-19)
summary: Coca-Cola Europacific Partners outlines its comprehensive response to the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on protecting its people, serving customers, supporting communities, and securing the business's long-term future. The company implemented stringent health protocols, adjusted production to meet demand, provided financial aid and product donations, and is working towards a sustainable recovery. This response includes collaborating with governments for science-based climate solutions and leveraging digital tools for efficiency.

title: Zuckerberg was right: Ad boycotts won't hurt Facebook that much
summary: Despite a major advertiser boycott in July 2020 via the "#StopHateForProfit" campaign, Facebook's revenue was largely unaffected, with the company projecting continued ad revenue growth. While many corporations like Coca-Cola, HP, and CVS Health extended their ad pauses, Facebook's diverse advertiser base, primarily small businesses, mitigated the financial impact from larger companies. Mark Zuckerberg had predicted advertisers would return, and several companies did resume spending, though many are continuing to monitor Facebook's efforts to combat hate speech.

title: Coca Cola Re-enters the Booze Business
summary: Coca-Cola is re-entering the alcohol market with a Topo Chico hard seltzer, slated to debut in Latin America this year and the US in 2021. This move comes after a prior attempt in the 1970s with wine, which proved unsuccessful, but the company believes hard seltzer aligns better with its expertise in sparkling drinks. The hard seltzer market is booming, with sales up 142 percent and projected to reach nearly $3 billion in 2020, making it an attractive sector for Coca-Cola.

title: Coca-Cola to launch hard seltzer and Coca-Cola With Coffee
summary: The Coca-Cola Company is set to launch a hard seltzer under its Topo Chico brand later this year and introduce Coca-Cola With Coffee in the US in 2021. These launches demonstrate Coca-Cola's strategy of exploring new products in dynamic beverage categories and scaling successful innovations across markets. The move into hard seltzer marks a significant entry into the alcoholic beverage category, while Coca-Cola With Coffee aims to pioneer a "refreshment coffee" segment.

title: Coca-Cola to debut coffee-flavored cola in the US
summary: Coca-Cola is launching its coffee and soda hybrid drink, Coca-Cola with Coffee, in the U.S. in January 2021, after having piloted it internationally since 2018. This move is part of Coca-Cola's strategy to diversify its product portfolio beyond traditional sodas and tap into the growing coffee market. The company is using a "test-and-learn approach" by first offering it to its Insiders Club before a wider public release, aiming to gather valuable consumer feedback.

title: Coke to launch Coca-Cola with coffee in the U.S.
summary: Coca-Cola is set to launch its iced-coffee infused drink, Coca-Cola with Coffee, in the United States in January 2021. The product, which combines the taste of Coca-Cola with Brazilian coffee, has already been successful in over 30 international markets since its 2018 pilot in Japan. This launch is part of Coca-Cola's "lift and shift" strategy to scale successful beverage innovations globally.

title: Polar Beverages goes nationwide in blockbuster deal with Keurig Dr Pepper
summary: Polar Beverages has entered a long-term franchise agreement with Keurig Dr Pepper to expand its seltzer distribution nationwide, leveraging Keurig's direct-to-stores delivery and manufacturing networks. This deal allows Polar to maintain ownership while gaining national reach for its quirky-flavored seltzers, aiming to elevate its market position from third nationally in the nearly $2 billion sparkling water category. The partnership builds on an existing 30-year relationship where Polar distributed KDP brands, and now KDP will manufacture and distribute Polar seltzers in new territories, sharing marketing costs.

title: Coke is killing ‘zombie’ brands and shrinking its workforce
summary: Coca-Cola is actively divesting from underperforming "zombie" brands and shrinking its workforce to prioritize more popular products and navigate the current market. The company aims to cut approximately 200 more brands, primarily those confined to single-country markets and growing slower than average, following the discontinuation of Odwalla. This conservative shift, accelerated by the COVID-19 crisis, is reflected in a significant drop in job listings.

title: How Coca-Cola BIG Capped its HR Transformation
summary: Coca-Cola Bottling Investments Group (BIG) faced significant challenges in standardizing its HR strategy across 15 separate legal entities due to varying technological adoption and existing systems. To overcome this, BIG partnered with Sodales Solutions for an extension app for SAP SuccessFactors, which enabled a rapid, cost-effective, and customized HR solution. This initiative aimed to improve employee experiences, drive consistent brand practices, and leverage data analytics globally, ultimately leading to a more contemporary HR experience.

title: Home Depot drops Ego power equipment brand, which lands deal with Lowe's
summary: Home Depot has decided to cease carrying the Ego brand of cordless outdoor power equipment as part of a "reset" of its inventory. Following this decision, Ego, developed by Chervon, has secured a new deal with Lowe's. This move indicates a significant shift in retail partnerships for the power equipment brand.

title: Coca-Cola cleaning up portfolio, approach to innovation
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. is reorganizing its brand portfolio and innovation processes to improve efficiency in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic, aiming to shed underperforming "zombie brands" and focus on more scalable and enduring propositions. The company reported a significant drop in net income and sales for the second quarter, attributing this to the pandemic's impact on consumer mobility and away-from-home channels, and did not issue full-year earnings guidance due to market uncertainty. This strategic shift includes prioritizing global and high-potential regional bets, as well as functional beverages and contactless solutions like touchless Freestyle machines.

title: Coca-Cola to Phase Out More 'Zombie' Brands
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. is set to discontinue several underperforming "zombie" brands to prioritize larger, stronger brands and more scalable innovations. This strategic shift follows the decision to exit the Odwalla juice brand and its chilled direct-store delivery network. The company aims to reallocate resources to growth areas like Minute Maid, Simply, and Topo Chico, while also focusing on reduced-sugar offerings and emerging brands like Aha sparkling water.

title: Coca-Cola expands ‘ruthless’ SKU rationalization strategy to cut entire product lines
summary: Coca-Cola is expanding its SKU rationalization strategy from individual products to entire brands, a move inspired by the supply chain challenges of the coronavirus pandemic. This aims to improve operational execution, margins, and sales by prioritizing fewer, stronger brands and discontinuing underperforming ones like Odwalla. The company plans to cut 300 staff and 230 trucks by ceasing Odwalla operations, freeing up resources for growing brands like Minute Maid and Simply.

title: Coca-Cola to cut ‘zombie brands’ as it looks to ‘weed out’ the poor performers
summary: Coca-Cola is planning to eliminate numerous "zombie brands" that are underperforming to concentrate resources on its most profitable lines, aiming to recover faster from the pandemic. The company will streamline its innovation pipeline and rigorously assess brands within its three-tier system (leaders, explorers, challengers) to ensure only those with significant growth potential receive investment. This strategic shift comes after a challenging quarter, with Coca-Cola aiming to emerge stronger by winning more consumers, gaining market share, and boosting marketing effectiveness.

title: Coca-Cola’s Fairlife dairy brand expands into ice cream
summary: Coca-Cola's Fairlife dairy brand is expanding into the frozen dessert market with the launch of Fairlife Light Ice Cream in partnership with Boardwalk Frozen Treats. This move diversifies Coca-Cola's portfolio beyond beverages, capitalizing on Fairlife's successful high-protein, lactose-free, and low-sugar profile, which was developed in response to consumer demand. The new ice cream will be sold nationwide, aiming to capture a share of the competitive $14 billion ice cream market previously dominated by brands like Halo Top.

title: Bradley Gayton Elected Senior Vice President and General Counsel of The Coca-Cola Company
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced Bradley Gayton has been elected senior vice president and general counsel, effective September 1. Gayton brings nearly 30 years of experience from Ford Motor Company, where he most recently served as group vice president, chief administrative officer and general counsel. He will be based at Coca-Cola headquarters in Atlanta and replaces Bernhard Goepelt, who retired in February.

title: Coke adds contactless tech to Freestyle machines to meet COVID-19 challenges
summary: Coca-Cola is integrating contactless mobile technology into its Freestyle soda fountains in response to consumer concerns about COVID-19. This new QR-code based system allows users to select drinks via their smartphone without touching the machine, with a rollout planned for 10,000 machines by the end of summer and all U.S. machines by year-end. The initiative aims to reassure customers and support restaurant partners as the pandemic continues.

title: Coca-Cola is shutting down Odwalla juice
summary: Coca-Cola is discontinuing its Odwalla juice and smoothie brand by the end of July due to a "rapidly shifting marketplace" and efforts to improve efficiency. The company acquired Odwalla in 2001 and had been assessing its business for several years, noting a decline in consumer interest in smoothies and the complexity Odwalla's distribution network added to its supply chain. This decision aligns with Coca-Cola's broader strategy to prioritize core products and key brands, especially during the pandemic, to maximize system efficiency.

title: Coca-Cola to close Odwalla juice business
summary: Coca-Cola is discontinuing its Odwalla juice business and a refrigerated trucking network, a move that follows a review of the business's performance. This decision will lead to the elimination of approximately 300 jobs. Odwalla will cease deliveries by the end of July, with unsold inventory collected through August.

title: Canadian companies Lululemon, MEC and Arc'teryx join Facebook ad boycott
summary: Lululemon Athletica, Mountain Equipment Co-op (MEC), and Arc'teryx have joined a growing list of international brands boycotting Facebook advertising in July due to the platform's handling of hateful content. This move, part of the #StopHateForProfit campaign, highlights concerns about misinformation, racism, and calls for violence on Facebook, prompting calls for stronger content moderation policies. The boycott has already impacted Facebook financially, with its stock dropping and billions erased from its market value and founder Mark Zuckerberg's net worth.

title: Coca-Cola halts all paid social media advertising for 30 days
summary: Coca-Cola is pausing all paid social media advertising globally for at least 30 days, citing a need to reassess policies and demanding greater accountability from its social media partners regarding racism and misinformation. This move follows similar announcements from other major brands like Hershey's, Verizon, and Unilever, amid a broader boycott targeting platforms like Facebook over their content moderation practices. Facebook has responded by outlining its efforts to combat hate speech and misinformation while acknowledging the need for further work.

title: Coca-Cola pauses advertising on all social media platforms globally
summary: Coca-Cola announced it would pause advertising on all social media platforms globally for at least 30 days to reassess its policies and demand greater accountability from its partners. This decision comes amidst a growing advertiser boycott, #StopHateForProfit, against platforms like Facebook and Instagram over their handling of hate speech and misinformation. Other major companies, including Unilever, Levi's, Dockers, and Hershey's, have also announced similar advertising pauses or spending cuts.

title: Dow leaves Plastics Industry Association
summary: Dow Inc. has announced its departure from the Plastics Industry Association, following similar moves by major consumer product makers like Coca-Cola Co. and PepsiCo Inc. While previous departures were linked to environmental pressure regarding plastics waste and lobbying, Dow stated its decision was to focus on other industry supply chain relationships. The Plastics Industry Association expressed hope for continued collaboration with Dow.

title: Aseguran que en la distribuidora de Coca Cola en Santo Tomé no hay trabajadores con síntomas de coronavirus
summary: Coca Cola Andina issued a statement confirming no confirmed or suspicious cases of Covid-19 at its Embotelladora del Atlántico S.A. plant in Santo Tomé, despite recent positive cases among workers of Logística del Paraná S.R.L. in Paraná, which also operates in Santa Fe and Santo Tomé. The company asserts it complies with all health protocols, which were verified by the Ministry of Labor, Employment and Social Security. Journalists also observed strict hygiene protocols in place at the Santo Tomé facility.

title: A Famed SoCal Soda Family Just Scored Big Bucks in a Case Against Coca-Cola
summary: The heirs of Hubert Hansen, founder of Hansen’s beverages, were awarded $9.6 million in damages and $7.4 million in legal fees against Coca-Cola and Monster Beverage Corp. This ruling by a San Diego Superior Court judge stems from the unauthorized use of Hubert Hansen's name and likeness for commercial purposes, marking it as one of the largest right of publicity awards in U.S. history. The case centered on California’s Celebrities Rights Act after the Hansen’s brand, but not the publicity rights, was sold to Coca-Cola.

title: Coca-Cola, Samford Sign New 10-Year Exclusive Agreement
summary: Samford University Athletics and Coca-Cola Bottling Company UNITED have announced a new 10-year partnership, making Coca-Cola the exclusive beverage provider for the Bulldogs. This agreement builds on a 50-year relationship and includes the establishment of a Coca-Cola scholarship fund and investment in stadium upgrades. The partnership aims to serve Samford students, faculty, and staff, and enhance the gameday experience.

title: This Tiny ETF Is Fighting Racism and Beating the Market
summary: This article highlights an exchange-traded fund (ETF) that focuses on companies actively fighting for racial justice. The ETF has reportedly performed well, outperforming the S&P 500 even during the coronavirus crisis. It suggests that Juneteenth is an opportune time for investors to consider such socially conscious investments.

title: This Tiny ETF Is Fighting Racism and Beating the Market
summary: This article highlights an exchange-traded fund (ETF) that focuses on companies actively involved in fighting for racial justice. It notes that this particular ETF has performed better than the S&P 500, even amid the coronavirus crisis, making Juneteenth an opportune time for investors to consider such companies.

title: Did You Know The Coca Cola Company Owns Topo Chico?
summary: The Coca-Cola Company acquired Topo Chico, a popular sparkling water brand primarily consumed in Texas, for $220 million to expand its own sparkling water division. Topo Chico has a long-standing connection with Coca-Cola, having been its first bottler in Mexico in 1926, and its acquisition aligns with Coke's strategy to invest in growing and trendy beverage brands. The brand's strong heritage, loyal Hispanic consumer base, and growing millennial following were key factors in the acquisition, with Coca-Cola aiming to extend its reach while preserving its authentic roots.

title: How Coca-Cola HBC is driving digital transformation in the drinks industry
summary: Coca-Cola HBC, one of the world's largest bottlers, is undergoing a significant digital transformation to become a total beverage company. Group CIO Alain Brouhard details their strategies, including leveraging SAP Hybris for B2B connections, launching consumer-facing apps like WOAH, and implementing smart manufacturing and logistics. The company also focuses on cybersecurity, data analytics, strategic partnerships, and initiatives like Youth Empowered to support community development.

title: Coca-Cola bottlers produce millions of COVID-19 test tubes
summary: Coca-Cola bottlers are producing millions of COVID-19 test tubes by repurposing PET preforms normally used for soda bottles. These preforms are an ideal shape for test kits and are being manufactured in vast quantities to address a global shortage. Federal labs and testing companies are collaborating to sterilize and utilize these tubes, with Coca-Cola Consolidated Inc. playing a key role in supply.

title: Coca-Cola Bottler to Invest $55M in New Facilities
summary: Coca-Cola Consolidated Inc. announced a $55 million investment to build a new 400,000-square-foot distribution and automated warehouse facility in Whitestown, Indiana. The North Carolina-based company, the nation's largest Coca-Cola bottler, will begin construction this month, creating 450 positions, including new jobs and transfers from an Indianapolis plant. This expansion is necessary to meet demand and enhance distribution capabilities, despite a previous $15 million investment in the Indianapolis facility.

title: Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Bacardí y otras empresas forman alianza para subsistir en la pandemia
summary: Coca-Cola, PepsiCo, Kellog's, Mars, and Mondel formed an alliance to support neighborhood stores and maintain economic activity during the COVID-19 pandemic. This collaboration extends to logistical support, with Coca-Cola's trucks delivering sanitizing solutions produced by companies like Bacardí and José Cuervo, who shifted operations from beverages due to the crisis. The initiative aims to help small businesses adapt to new sanitary measures and ensure a steady supply of essential goods.

title: Rodney Sacks Biography
summary: This article provides a comprehensive biography of Rodney Sacks, the Chairman and CEO of Monster Beverage Corp. It details his legal background, the acquisition of Hansen Natural, and the company's transformation into an energy drink powerhouse, emphasizing Monster's marketing strategies and growth in the competitive beverage market. The article also touches upon the regulatory challenges faced by energy drink companies and Sacks's business philosophy.

title: Coca-Cola: solving business challenges with technology
summary: This article discusses how The Coca-Cola Company (TCCC) leverages technology to address business challenges, focusing on its digital transformation program 'Digitizing for Growth'. Damiano Marabelli, Central & Eastern Europe Business Unit CIO, details IT's role in consumer and customer engagement, enterprise digitalization, and collaborations with bottling partners to enhance revenue growth management and consumer-facing applications. The company emphasizes a shift in IT's role from technology builders to architects of possibility, integrating technology into all aspects of the business to support its 'Total Beverage' strategy.

title: The Soviet Union Paid Pepsi With Vodka and Warships in Decades-Long Barter
summary: This article details the unusual decades-long business relationship between PepsiCo and the Soviet Union, which began in 1959 with a handshake deal facilitated by Richard Nixon. Due to the non-convertibility of the ruble, PepsiCo initially received Stolichnaya vodka as payment, and later, an astounding agreement involved PepsiCo accepting Soviet warships, briefly making them the "6th largest military in the world." The partnership highlights a unique chapter in Cold War-era commerce.

title: Coca-Cola Announces $5B Investment with Africa Bottling Partners
summary: The Coca-Cola Company has announced a new $5 billion investment in its African operations, partnering with its bottling and distribution partners. This investment, which brings their total commitment between 2010 and 2020 to $17 billion, will focus on new manufacturing lines, job creation, and sustainability initiatives across the continent. The company aims to refresh citizens, build its business, and create economic value in Africa, leveraging programs like Source Africa to promote sustainable agriculture and improve local ingredient sourcing.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper to acquire drink maker Core Nutrition for $525mn
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper has agreed to acquire Core Nutrition LLC, a company known for its bottled waters and hydration drinks, for $525 million. This acquisition highlights a growing trend among beverage companies to diversify beyond traditional sugary soft drinks. Core Nutrition, with its premium and organic hydration options, has been an allied brand partner with Keurig Dr Pepper since 2016 and has seen significant growth in net sales.

title: FROM FACTORY TO FRIDGE: INSIDE COCA-COLA'S SUPPLY CHAIN
summary: This article provides an in-depth look at Coca-Cola Enterprises' (CCE) supply chain operations in Western Europe, highlighting how the company manages to distribute over 600 million cases of product annually. It emphasizes CCE's commitment to local sourcing and manufacturing, rapid production, and continuous investment in technology and sustainability to ensure efficiency and meet consumer demand. The piece also details the crucial role of its logistics team and strong retailer relationships in getting products from factory to fridge seamlessly.

title: Inside Eastman’s moonshot goal for endlessly circular plastics
summary: Eastman, a legacy chemical company, is pursuing a "moonshot goal" for endlessly circular plastics through two breakthrough technologies: Carbon Renewal Technology (CRT) and Polyester Renewal Technology (PRT). These processes aim to turn all types of waste plastics, including hard-to-recycle multi-material items, back into new, high-quality plastics numerous times without degradation. The initiative seeks to address climate change, plastic waste, and resource efficiency, potentially making Eastman a leader in the circular economy.

title: Insights for bakers from Coca-Cola’s leader
summary: James Quincey, CEO of The Coca-Cola Co., shared insights on navigating the uncertain economic landscape due to the COVID-19 pandemic, emphasizing strategies applicable to the baking industry. He discussed potential recovery scenarios (V, U, L-shaped), the importance of revenue growth management, and shifts in consumer behavior impacting merchandising and e-commerce. Quincey highlighted Coca-Cola's adaptations in marketing, innovation, and package sizes, suggesting these can offer valuable lessons for bakers.

title: Tim Blanchard
summary: This article profiles Tim Blanchard, a Partner at Slaughter and May since 2020, specializing in global investigations and contentious regulatory practices. It details his extensive experience advising major corporations and financial institutions on antitrust, consumer protection, bribery, and regulatory investigations, as well as competition litigation. The profile also highlights his recognition as a leading individual in legal directories like Who's Who Legal and Legal 500.

title: Coca-Cola FEMSA anuncia resultados del primer trimestre 2020
summary: Coca-Cola FEMSA (KOF) announced its consolidated results for the first quarter of 2020, navigating currency volatility and initial COVID-19 impacts to achieve stable consolidated volume and comparable revenue growth. Despite a slight decrease in total revenue due to unfavorable currency conversion, comparable revenues grew 3.6% and comparable operating income increased by 6.3%, driven by efficiency and tax recovery in Brazil. The company also took measures to strengthen its financial position through debt refinancing and short-term credit.

title: Coca-Cola taps Microsoft for 5-year multicloud, software deal
summary: The Coca-Cola Company has signed a five-year deal with Microsoft for its software and cloud products to enhance data insights, replace fragmented systems, and facilitate remote work for its 86,000 employees. This move aims to boost efficiency amidst a challenging economic forecast and the widespread shift to remote work due to the pandemic. The deal includes Microsoft Azure, Dynamics 365, Microsoft 365, Power Platform, and Microsoft Teams.

title: How is Coca-Cola dealing with the coronavirus crisis?
summary: Coca-Cola CEO James Quincey discusses the company's strategy for navigating the coronavirus crisis, emphasizing flexibility, long-term vision, and adapting to sharp changes in consumption habits, particularly the decline in away-from-home channels and a predicted "seismic shift" to e-commerce. The company is observing China for insights into recovery phases, implementing employee redeployment, and managing its global supply chain to avoid major disruptions despite border challenges.

title: Walmart Poaches Its New Marketing Chief from Rival Target
summary: Walmart Inc. has hired William White, a senior vice president of marketing at rival Target Corp., to be its new marketing chief. White, formerly a Coca-Cola executive, will start his new role at Walmart on May 11 and will report to Chief Customer Officer Janey Whiteside. This move fills a marketing leadership vacancy at Walmart that has existed for nearly a year.

title: Coca-Cola FEMSA mejora su cadena de suministro
summary: Coca-Cola FEMSA has accelerated the implementation of a demand-oriented, customer-focused supply chain model, completing the integration of its KOF Logistics Services into the Supply Chain Planning platform across all operations in 2019. The company has also been deploying its Digital Distribution 1.0 and 2.0 platforms, with plans to launch Digital Distribution 2.0 in Mexico next year. Coca-Cola FEMSA, the largest Coca-Cola bottler by sales volume, is also developing its Digital Manufacturing 2.0 platform to optimize its asset management system across its entire supply chain.

title: 17 Stocks With Fortress Balance Sheets
summary: This article identifies 17 stocks with strong balance sheets, dubbed "fortress balance sheets," that are well-positioned to withstand economic downturns and are currently undervalued. It highlights three specific companies—Coca-Cola, Honeywell, and Public Service Enterprise Group—providing detailed analyst commentary on their financial resilience and market positioning amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. The piece serves as a guide for investors looking for sturdy companies during market uncertainty.

title: Coke goes big with COVID social distancing in Times Square
summary: Coca-Cola is using its iconic Times Square billboard to promote social distancing amidst the COVID-19 pandemic by extending spaces between letters in its name. This initiative is part of broader operational changes by Coke to protect staff and customers, including enhanced sanitization, remote work for office employees, and significant donations for relief efforts through The Coca-Cola Foundation.

title: The Coca-Cola Foundation Awards Additional $13.5 Million in Grants to Support Non-Profit Organizations Responding to the Coronavirus Pandemic Across the United States and Canada
summary: The Coca-Cola Foundation announced $13.5 million in grants to five non-profit organizations in the U.S. and Canada to support humanitarian response efforts during the coronavirus pandemic. These grants will fund initiatives such as food provision, support for families of first responders, and community services for those most impacted by the crisis. This is in addition to previous grants made in Atlanta, China, and Italy, as the Foundation continues to expand its global COVID-19 relief efforts.

title: Why and How to Index in U.S. Large Caps
summary: This article argues for indexing in U.S. large caps due to the difficulty for active managers to outperform in this efficient market segment, citing broad diversification, low fees, and data from Morningstar's Active/Passive Barometer. It highlights several highly-rated funds like Vanguard S&P 500 ETF (VOO), Vanguard Large Cap ETF (VV), and iShares Russell 1000 ETF (IWB) as excellent options for investors seeking indexed exposure. The author also discusses the subtle differences between the underlying indexes tracked by these funds, such as their selection criteria and market capitalization coverage.

title: Investcorp acquires Coca-Cola Belgium HQ for €88 million
summary: Investcorp's European Real Estate business has acquired The Bridge, Coca-Cola's Belgian headquarters, for €88 million in a sale and 10-year leaseback transaction. This acquisition marks Investcorp's entry into the Belgian market and is part of its expansion strategy in the Benelux region, increasing its European real estate platform to approximately €750 million in AUM. The property, located in Brussels, includes 35,300 square meters of office and R&D space and will remain 100% occupied by Coca-Cola and its sub-tenants.

title: 4 Reasons Not to Sell Keurig Dr Pepper Stock
summary: This article provides four reasons why investors should not sell Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP) stock despite market downturns. The reasons include the company's market-beating performance, profitable merger synergies, diversified product portfolio, and healthy dividend. It emphasizes that KDP offers both value and growth potential, making it a compelling hold for long-term investors.

title: PepsiCo is buying Rockstar energy drink maker for $3.85 billion
summary: PepsiCo announced its acquisition of Rockstar Inc., the energy drink maker, for $3.85 billion to expand its beverage range amidst declining soda sales. This strategic move, led by CEO Ramon Laguarta, aims to capture a larger share of the fast-growing energy drink market, a segment where PepsiCo and Coca-Cola have previously had weaker presences. The deal also includes an additional $700 million in payments for future tax benefits and is expected to close in the first half of 2020.

title: Pepsi enters energy drink market with $3.85bn Rockstar deal
summary: PepsiCo has acquired Rockstar Energy Beverages for $3.85 billion to enter the growing energy drink market and diversify its offerings. This move positions PepsiCo to compete directly with Coca-Cola, which has a stake in Monster, and builds on an existing distribution deal between Pepsi and Rockstar since 2009. The acquisition is a significant strategic step for PepsiCo amidst market volatility and its shares were down slightly in pre-market trading following the announcement.

title: Global Functional Drinks Market 2020-2024 | Evolving Opportunities with Archer Daniels Midland Co. and Danone SA | Technavio
summary: The global functional drinks market is projected to grow by USD 179.28 billion during 2020-2024, at a CAGR of over 11%. This growth is primarily driven by the health benefits offered by functional drinks and increasing consumption among millennials. Key companies in the market include Archer Daniels Midland Co., Danone SA, Monster Beverage Corp., Nestlé SA, and NextFoods Inc.

title: PepsiCo aims for energy boost with $3.85 billion Rockstar deal
summary: PepsiCo announced a $3.85 billion deal to acquire Rockstar Energy Beverages, significantly expanding its presence in the energy drink market. This move is part of CEO Ramon Laguarta's strategy to diversify away from sugary drinks and salty snacks and intensify competition with Coca-Cola in the growing energy beverage sector. The acquisition is expected to give PepsiCo a broader portfolio of energy drinks, though it is not expected to impact its revenue or EPS in 2020.

title: PepsiCo (PEP) to Buy Rockstar Energy Drinks for $3.85 Billion
summary: PepsiCo Inc. has agreed to acquire Rockstar Inc., the energy-drink maker, for $3.85 billion. This strategic move aims to expand PepsiCo's beverage range amidst declining soda consumption and marks one of the first major actions by CEO Ramon Laguarta. Pepsi and Rockstar have maintained a distribution agreement in North America since 2009.

title: PepsiCo nears $3.85B deal for energy-drink maker Rockstar
summary: PepsiCo is reportedly nearing a $3.85 billion deal to acquire Rockstar Energy Beverages, a move that would significantly expand PepsiCo's presence in the growing energy-drink market. This potential acquisition would mark the first major strategic move under CEO Ramon Laguarta and address a weak spot for PepsiCo in the energy-drink category. The deal would also allow PepsiCo to expand its own energy drink brands and Rockstar's distribution, avoiding legal issues similar to those faced by rival Coca-Cola.

title: WW CEO Mindy Grossman Talks Brand Transformation [Interview]
summary: WW CEO Mindy Grossman discusses the company's transformation from Weight Watchers into a technology company with a human-centric overlay, focusing on personalization and holistic wellness. She highlights strategic initiatives like the myWW program, the Oprah 2020 Vision tour, and partnerships with companies such as Fidelity Investments and Kohl's to expand WW's reach and impact. Grossman emphasizes the importance of customization and community in addressing changing consumer demands and promoting a healthier lifestyle.

title: BlackLine is Solving Accounting, One Fortune 500 Company at a Time
summary: BlackLine is a cloud-based accounting software company capitalizing on the digital transformation of accounting practices, counting 36% of Fortune 500 companies as customers. The company shows strong financial results, including 98% Q4 2019 renewal rate and 29% revenue growth, and is expanding its market reach through a significant partnership with SAP. BlackLine is considered an attractive acquisition target for larger ERP companies like SAP or Oracle due to its market position and integrated solutions.

title: Has LaCroix found 'vindication' from the withdrawal of a consumer lawsuit over its 'natural' claim?
summary: A class action lawsuit accusing LaCroix of false advertising over its "100% Natural" claim has been withdrawn by the plaintiffs. While LaCroix's parent company, National Beverage Corp., hailed the dismissal as vindication, the brand still faces another similar lawsuit, increased competition, and has yet to fully recover from prior reputational and financial damage. The withdrawal, however, avoids setting a legal precedent and could be a win for companies using "natural" on product labels.

title: What the Aflac Duck can teach marketers about taking creative risks
summary: This article explores how the Aflac Duck, after 20 years, continues to offer valuable lessons to marketers regarding experimentation, brand evolution, and achieving widespread recognition. It details the origins of the Aflac Duck campaign, a risky but successful move that significantly boosted the company's brand awareness from single digits to over 90%. The piece also highlights the principles behind Aflac's creative decisions, the duck's evolving role in marketing, and its influence on the insurance industry.

title: Cinemark Brings the Movies Back to Salem, New Hampshire
summary: Cinemark introduced a new 12-screen theatre in Salem, New Hampshire, adjacent to The Mall at Rockingham Park. The theatre features luxury recliners, advanced sound systems, enhanced food and beverage options, and an XD premium large format auditorium. This marks Cinemark's first location in New Hampshire, aiming to enhance the entertainment experience for local guests.

title: Tar Heels, Ball Corp. introduce recyclable aluminum cups at sporting events
summary: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Department of Athletics and Ball Corporation have partnered to introduce infinitely recyclable aluminum cups at Tar Heel sporting events as part of a pilot program. Carolina is the first university in the ACC to feature these cups, which contain over 70% recycled content and aim to reduce the university's carbon footprint. This initiative highlights UNC's ongoing commitment to sustainable practices in its athletic venues.
source: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
source_domain: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

title: Keurig Dr Pepper acquires sparkling water brand Limitless
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper has acquired Limitless, a Chicago-based caffeinated sparkling water brand, for an undisclosed sum. This strategic move aims to expand Limitless's distribution, primarily found in Walmart, and strengthen Keurig Dr Pepper's water portfolio, particularly in the growing market for caffeinated beverages. The acquisition highlights Keurig Dr Pepper's focus on trending drinks like sparkling water to adapt to changing consumer demands and streamline its product offerings.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper Acquires Limitless Sparkling Water
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP) has acquired Chicago-based sparkling water company Limitless to expand the distribution of its products and enhance KDP's water category portfolio. Limitless sparkling water contains caffeine, no sugar, and no calories, offering several flavors, and the acquisition reflects the growing trend in the sparkling water market. This move follows a similar expansion by The Coca-Cola Co. into caffeinated sparkling water.

title: Centerplate, Ball and Bud Light to Present Infinitely Recyclable Aluminum Cups at Super Bowl LIV
summary: Centerplate, Ball Corporation, and Bud Light have partnered to introduce infinitely recyclable aluminum cups at Hard Rock Stadium for Super Bowl LIV. This initiative aims to align with sustainability goals, reduce plastic waste, and enhance the fan experience with a more environmentally friendly beverage option. The aluminum cups will continue to be used at the stadium for various events throughout the year.

title: Monster Concerned About Losing Shelf Space to Coke Energy
summary: Monster Beverage Corp. executives are worried about losing shelf space and bottler focus due to Coca-Cola Energy's U.S. launch. Despite these concerns, analysts note that Coke Energy hasn't disrupted international market share, and many retailers are not placing it in the core energy drink aisle alongside Monster. Monster is working with Coke and bottlers to protect its presence, as cooler space is limited.

title: Here's why stocks such as Procter & Gamble and Coca-Cola are included in ESG ETFs, according to industry leaders
summary: Stocks like Procter & Gamble and Coca-Cola are included in ESG ETFs despite environmental concerns because fund issuers aim to provide benchmark-like returns while reflecting values. Industry leaders from DWS Group and BlackRock explain that the goal is to offer performance and risk profiles investors are used to, requiring representation from all industries, with a focus on companies that exhibit strong ESG values within their sectors. They emphasize the need for investor education to define what ESG means and distinguish between different types of ESG investment vehicles.

title: How Coke and Pepsi compare when it comes to social media
summary: This article compares Coca-Cola ($KO) and Pepsi ($PEP) based on their social media presence, specifically Facebook and Instagram likes, rather than traditional financial metrics. It highlights Coca-Cola's significantly larger following on these platforms, suggesting that its brand resonates more strongly online. The analysis also briefly mentions UBS's positive outlook on Coca-Cola's stock due to stable earnings growth and innovation.

title: Energy drink puts Chatsworth man behind the wheel of a ‘Monster’ car
summary: A 24-year-old Chatsworth resident, Trevern Pown Kumar, won a Ford Mustang 5.0 GT Fastback RTR automatic, valued at R750,000, through a promotion run by Monster Energy and Coca-Cola Beverages South Africa. The competition, in its second year, involved consumers SMSing a unique code from Monster Energy drink cans. Kumar expressed his excitement about winning a muscle car, highlighting the partnership between The Coca-Cola Company and Monster Energy which has seen growth in their brands across the African market.

title: Diet Dr Pepper doesn’t make false weight loss promises, court rules
summary: A U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that Dr Pepper Snapple Group did not mislead consumers into believing Diet Dr Pepper promises weight loss or healthy weight management, upholding that the use of "diet" on labels does not constitute false advertising. This decision is consistent with previous rulings against PepsiCo and Coca-Cola in similar lawsuits, reinforcing that "diet" denotes fewer calories rather than health benefits. The ruling may deter future lawsuits unless plaintiffs can present stronger legal arguments, while beverage manufacturers are increasingly shifting away from artificial sweeteners and the term "diet."

title: Slideshow: The big brand mashups of 2019
summary: In 2019, numerous companies collaborated to introduce co-branded products, bringing familiar flavors into new formats. Key players like Coca-Cola, Mars, Inc., and General Mills, Inc. partnered on various innovative products, from flavored mints and gels to snack foods and cereals. These mashups included Coca-Cola flavored Tic Tacs, Snack Pack Fanta Gels, Snickers and Dove Dark Chocolate Almond flavored creamers, Twix Candy Pop, Starburst flavored Yoplait yogurt, and Cinnamon Toast Crunch creamer, with plans for Hershey's, Jolly Rancher, and Reese's Puffs cereals in 2020.

title: PepsiCo Boss Donald Kendall, Who Started the Cola Wars, Has Died
summary: Donald M. Kendall, the former CEO of PepsiCo Inc., who built the company into a snack-and-beverage giant and initiated the "cola wars" with Coca-Cola, has died at 99. Kendall served as CEO from 1963 to 1986, during which sales grew nearly 40-fold and he introduced Pepsi to the Soviet Union. He famously launched the "Pepsi Challenge" marketing campaign against rival Coca-Cola.

title: Diet Dr Pepper does not promise weight loss or deceive consumers - U.S. appeals court
summary: A U.S. federal appeals court ruled that Diet Dr Pepper does not deceive consumers by using "diet" in its name, stating that reasonable consumers understand it refers to calorie content rather than promising weight loss. This decision could impact similar lawsuits against other diet soft drink manufacturers, reinforcing that the term "diet" is understood as a relative claim.
banner_image: FILE PHOTO: Dr Pepper soda cans for sale are pictured at a grocery store in Pasadena, California, U.S., February 14, 2018. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni

title: Steelmaker readies itself for a big year
summary: Nucor Corp.'s subisdiary Nucor Steel Florida is on track to open its $240 million micro-mill in Frostproof, Polk County. The plant, which is the largest single capital investment in Polk County in a generation, plans to begin hiring in early 2020 and start production by year-end, creating 250 jobs. The project is progressing as planned despite the challenge of finding time for the plant manager, Drew Wilcox, to enjoy the local outdoors.

title: Coca-Cola Israel fined NIS 39 million for monopoly violations
summary: Coca-Cola Israel has been fined NIS 39 million (reduced from an initial NIS 62 million) by the Israel Competition Authority for violating monopoly laws. The company was accused of using its dominant market position to stifle competition, including preventing rival products from being displayed in its refrigerators provided to retailers and violating a merger agreement with Neviot mineral water company. Coca-Cola Israel's local operator, Central Bottling Company, plans to appeal the decision, confident that the claims will be canceled.

title: Hard Rock International Announces Global Partnership with the Coca-Cola Company
summary: Hard Rock International and The Coca-Cola Company (NYSE: KO) have announced a global partnership that will introduce Coca-Cola's brand portfolio to Hard Rock Cafe locations worldwide starting in 2020. The collaboration aims to enhance Hard Rock's beverage platform and accelerate growth for both brands, allowing guests to pair Coca-Cola products with Hard Rock's menu items. The announcement was celebrated with a guitar smash and Coke Toast at the newly remodeled Hard Rock Cafe Atlanta.

title: Hard Rock International Announces Global Partnership With The Coca-Cola Company
summary: Hard Rock International and The Coca-Cola Company announced a global partnership that will introduce Coca-Cola's beverage portfolio to all Hard Rock Cafe locations worldwide starting in 2020. This collaboration aims to enhance the beverage platform for both brands and allow Hard Rock Cafe guests to pair Coca-Cola products with their menu items for the first time. The announcement was made at the newly remodeled Hard Rock Cafe Atlanta.

title: Can Coca-Cola escape the shadow of deceptive marketing campaigns in its past?
summary: A new report reveals Coca-Cola's past marketing strategies for the 2016 Olympics specifically targeted teenagers and mothers, despite public pledges against marketing unhealthy products to children. This is the third report this year spotlighting the company's efforts to influence perceptions about its beverages' healthiness and promote exercise over dietary changes. In response, Coca-Cola is highlighting current transparency efforts, including sugar reduction and a policy against marketing to children under 12, while emphasizing its shift towards being a "total beverage company."

title: Coke PR Campaigns Tried to Influence Teens’ Views on Health Impacts of Soda
summary: A new study reveals internal Coca-Cola documents showing the company's public relations campaigns aimed to influence teenagers' perceptions of the health risks associated with sugary soda. The study, co-authored by U.S. Right to Know and Deakin University, highlights how Coke sought to "Increase Coke brand health scores with teens" and "Cement credibility in the health and well-being space," despite public pledges to reduce marketing of unhealthy products to children. Researchers are calling for investigations into Coca-Cola's PR tactics that may harm the health of children and teenagers.

title: Live Nation ‘bullied’ church, pocketed Met landlord’s share of cash from Madonna, Sting shows, lawsuit says
summary: Live Nation is facing a lawsuit from its landlord at the Met Philadelphia, an affiliate of developer Eric Blumenfeld, and Holy Ghost Church. The suit alleges Live Nation cheated them out of proceeds from concerts by artists like Madonna and Sting, and breached an agreement regarding the church's Sunday services. Furthermore, the lawsuit claims Live Nation also failed to pay the landlord their share of revenue from corporate sponsorships and treated the church disrespectfully.

title: Coca-Cola launches $10/month subscription service
summary: Coca-Cola has launched a new subscription service called the Coca-Cola Insiders Club, offering subscribers exclusive access to new and unreleased beverages. For $10 a month, the first 1,000 "insiders" will receive monthly shipments of 20-plus new beverages for six months, along with other surprises. This pilot program aims to engage loyal customers and gain insights from early product feedback, building on the success of limited-time offerings like Coke Cinnamon.

title: Francisco Crespo to Retire as Chief Growth Officer of The Coca-Cola Company
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced the retirements of Senior Vice President and Chief Growth Officer Francisco Crespo and Senior Vice President and General Counsel Bernhard Goepelt, both in 2020. Crespo will be succeeded by a restructured global growth organization where integrated global marketing, corporate strategy, and customer and commercial operations will report to Manolo Arroyo, John Murphy, and Brian Smith, respectively. Manolo Arroyo will assume the role of Chief Marketing Officer while also continuing as president of the Asia Pacific Group.

title: Coca-Cola Loses Initial Trial In ‘Right Of Publicity’ Brawl Over Use Of Juice Seller’s Image
summary: A California state court judge ruled that the heirs of juice-maker Hubert Hansen control the rights to his name and image, not Coca-Cola, setting the stage for a damages trial with more than $14 million potentially at stake. Coca-Cola had acquired the Hansen's juice products from Monster Beverage Corporation but did not obtain the rights to use Hubert Hansen's name and likeness. The judge rejected Coke's argument that the publicity rights were transferred through the acquisition, stating that those rights were inherited by Hansen's family.

title: Understanding PepsiCo’s Business Segments and More
summary: This article provides an in-depth look at PepsiCo's business segments, its product portfolio across beverages and snacks, and its financial performance. It highlights PepsiCo's strategy to address declining carbonated soft drink volumes by expanding into healthier options and international markets, while comparing its performance and strategies with competitors like Coca-Cola and Mondelez International. The article also details the profitability of its snack food business versus its beverage business and the importance of branding and productivity initiatives.

title: Pepsi to sell coffee-cola drink that has twice as much caffeine
summary: PepsiCo Inc. is launching Pepsi Cafe in April, a new coffee-cola blend with nearly double the caffeine of a regular Pepsi, available in original and vanilla flavors. This move responds to changing beverage preferences and increasing competition in the market. Rival Coca-Cola Co. is also expanding its presence in the canned coffee market after acquiring Costa.

title: Coca-Cola leadership rings NYSE opening bell, donate $1M to female-focused nonprofit (Video)
summary: Coca-Cola celebrated 100 years since its initial public offering by ringing the New York Stock Exchange opening bell. Chairman and CEO James Quincey was among the executives and board members present. The company also made a $1 million donation to a female-focused nonprofit as part of the celebration.

title: Coca-Cola CEO says the beverage giant waited too long to make a sparkling water brand
summary: Coca-Cola CEO James Quincey admitted that the company waited too long to launch a dedicated sparkling water brand, despite the growing popularity of the category.
