Coca-Cola is set to launch its new sparkling water brand, AHA, on March 2 in the United States, aiming to compete with rivals like PepsiCo's Bubly and National Beverage's LaCroix. This launch marks Coca-Cola's first new brand in over a decade, though it has previously ventured into the sparkling water market with Dasani and Smartwater variations, and the acquisition of Topo Chico.

title: Coca-Cola CEO: Wall Street plays catch-up rewarding firms for socially responsible investments
summary: Coca-Cola CEO James Quincey states that Wall Street investors are increasingly recognizing and rewarding companies for their long-standing sustainability efforts, aligning with the growing trend of ESG (environmental, social, and governance) investing. He highlights Coca-Cola's ambitious sustainability goals, including plastic bottle recovery and recycling targets, carbon footprint reduction, and water neutrality. Quincey also noted the company's strong third-quarter financial performance, partly due to healthier product options, and its plans to address weaker bottled water sales by introducing aluminum packaging for Dasani.

title: Executive of the Year: James Quincey, Coca-Cola
summary: James Quincey, CEO of Coca-Cola since May 2017, has been named Executive of the Year by Food Dive for transforming the company into a "total beverage company." Through strategic acquisitions like Costa Coffee and innovations in its core brands, Quincey has diversified Coca-Cola's portfolio into coffees, sports drinks, and sparkling waters, while also focusing on sustainability. These efforts have led to significant growth in Coca-Cola Zero Sugar and mini cans, and a 5% increase in organic revenue during the third quarter.

title: These new Coke and Bud packages ditch plastic six-pack rings for cardboard carriers
summary: Coca-Cola and AB InBev are introducing KeelClip, a new cardboard carrier designed to replace plastic six-pack rings, starting in Europe next year. This shift is driven by growing consumer sentiment against plastic and upcoming single-use plastic bans, despite the KeelClip being slightly more expensive initially. The design offers brands extra marketing space and is compatible with existing high-speed production lines, making it a viable solution for large beverage companies.

title: Coke CEO: Why we have an award for projects that fail
summary: Coca-Cola CEO James Quincey explains that the company has an award for projects that fail to encourage innovation and overcome the fear of failure in large organizations. He emphasizes that "the only true failures are situations in which we fail to learn" and that learning strengthens their innovation efforts. The company also "kills zombie" products that aren't performing to redeploy resources more effectively, with 700 such products discontinued in 2018.

title: Top 100 Consumer Goods Companies of 2019
summary: This article provides a detailed ranking of the top 100 publicly traded consumer goods companies in 2019, based on fiscal 2018 revenue. It highlights the trend of growth primarily driven by acquisitions rather than organic means and delves into the strategies of the top 10 companies with the highest year-over-year sales growth. The report also includes key executive information for each company listed.

title: If You Invested $1,000 in Berkshire’s IPO, This Is How Much Money You'd Have Now
summary: This article illustrates the immense power of long-term compounding by examining an investment in Berkshire Hathaway's IPO. It details how a hypothetical $1,000 investment in 1964, when Warren Buffett took over, would be worth millions today. The piece showcases Buffett's investment strategy, highlighting the significant growth achieved by focusing on high-quality businesses with strong management.

title: Coca-Cola Battles Juice Seller’s Grandchildren At Trial Over Right Of Publicity
summary: A bench trial is underway in California pitting The Coca-Cola Company against the grandchildren of juice purveyor Hubert Hansen, who claim Coke unlawfully profited from his name and likeness. The grandchildren allege that while Coke acquired trademarks and copyrights associated with the Hansen brand in a 2015 deal, they did not obtain the rights to use Hubert Hansen’s actual name and likeness, which is protected under California's "right of publicity" law. Coca-Cola argues that the use of Hansen's likeness was expressly authorized through previous mergers and ownership changes.

title: J.M. Smucker Co. shakes up leadership structure
summary: The J.M. Smucker Co. is reorganizing its leadership team effectively November 25, 2019, to enhance strategic focus and decision-making. Key changes include the creation of a chief operating officer position, new roles for Geoff Tanner, Jill Penrose, and Amy Held, and the upcoming retirement of CFO Mark Belgya, who will be succeeded by Tucker Marshall. The changes are part of a broader effort to streamline operations and improve focus on strategic initiatives.

title: The Coca-Cola Company: Report on Political Spending Related to Company Values and Policies
summary: A shareholder resolution filed by As You Sow urges The Coca-Cola Company to publish an annual report analyzing the congruency of its political and electioneering expenditures with its publicly stated company values and policies. The resolution highlights perceived inconsistencies, such as spending against container deposit laws despite recycling commitments, and donations to politicians working to erode women's constitutional rights despite commitments to gender equity. Proponents argue that such discrepancies risk damaging the company's brand, reputation, and shareholder value.

title: Executive Seminar Hosts Pittsburgh CEO Charles Bitzer
summary: Pittsburgh CEO Charles Bitzer will be the guest speaker for West Liberty University's fall Executive Seminar. Bitzer is president and CEO of ABARTA, Inc. and chairman and CEO of ABARTA Coca-Cola Beverages, with a long career starting in 1985 at Buffalo Coca-Cola Bottling Company. The seminar, free and open to the public, offers College of Business students an opportunity to learn from successful business leaders.

title: Coca-Cola’s Aha moment: New sparkling water brand debuts in March
summary: Coca-Cola is launching a new sparkling water brand called Aha in March 2020, marking its first major new brand launch since 2006. Aha will replace Dasani's sparkling water in retail and features eight unique flavor combinations, including two with 30 mg of caffeine. This move aims to innovate in the rapidly growing sparkling water market, where Coca-Cola faces stiff competition and seeks to differentiate from existing brands like LaCroix and PepsiCo's bubly.

title: AHA sparkling water line Coca-Cola's first new brand in 13 years
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced Thursday the launch of AHA, its first new brand in 13 years. This sparkling water line, featuring eight flavors, aims to compete in the growing market against rivals like Pepsi's Bubly and targets health-conscious consumers. AHA is set to debut in March 2020.

title: The latest sign we’re in a sparkling water bubble: Coca-Cola is making something called Aha
summary: Coca-Cola announced its biggest brand launch in a decade with a new flavored seltzer line called "Aha," set to debut in March 2020. This move is aimed at competing with LaCroix and Pepsi's Bubly, with some flavors featuring caffeine to tap into another growing trend. The launch signifies the continued expansion in the sparkling water market amidst a perceived "bubble."

title: Snack Pack Partners With Fanta On Debut Of Three New Flavored Gels
summary: Snack Pack, a brand of Conagra Brands, has partnered with Fanta to introduce a new line of flavored gels in orange, grape, and pineapple flavors. This marks Snack Pack's first co-branded partnership and Fanta's first entry into a new category for its iconic fruit flavors. The new Snack Pack Fanta Gels will be available nationwide in late November, offering consumers a convenient treat with authentic Fanta taste.

title: Coca-Cola Named The World’s Most Polluting Brand in Plastic Waste Audit
summary: A recent audit by Break Free From Plastic, involving 848 cleanup events across 51 countries, identified Coca-Cola as the largest plastic polluter globally. The audit collected over 475,000 pieces of plastic waste, with 11,732 items traced back to Coca-Cola. The article highlights the urgent need for smart consumer choices, efficient recycling infrastructure, and innovation in alternative materials to combat single-use plastic pollution.

title: Where Is The Headquarters Of The Coca-Cola Company?
summary: The Coca-Cola Company, a multinational beverage corporation, has its headquarters in Atlanta, Georgia, incorporated in Wilmington, Delaware. The article details its business model, global presence, advertising strategies, and ventures into non-food products, including a brief ownership of Columbia Pictures. It also touches on recent sales declines due to shifting consumer preferences and its financial standing as of 2018.

title: SodaStream to Offer Concentrates for Homemade Pepsi, Mountain Dew
summary: SodaStream announced it will soon offer concentrates for 10 of PepsiCo’s most popular soft drink brands, including Pepsi, 7 Up, and Mountain Dew, for at-home carbonation. While financial savings will be minimal, the primary benefit is expected to be a reduction in disposable plastic bottles. Initially launching in Sweden and Norway, distribution will expand to Germany and France in March 2020.

title: Investing in Smart Water Technology with Xylem
summary: This article discusses the growing importance of smart water technology, driven by increasing water scarcity. It highlights Xylem (XYL), a publicly traded company that is aggressively expanding its footprint in smart water solutions through acquisitions, positioning itself as a leader in digitizing the water economy. The piece also touches on investment strategies like Dividend Growth Investing and showcases smart water technology startups.

title: Leaked Audio Reveals How Coca-Cola Undermines Plastic Recycling Efforts
summary: Leaked audio from a recycling leaders' meeting reveals how Coca-Cola's philanthropic efforts were used to suppress discussions about effective recycling tools like bottle bills. The article details how Coca-Cola, despite being a major plastic polluter, has historically fought against legislation that would hold it accountable for plastic waste, instead funding organizations that shift responsibility to consumers. It highlights how this strategy continues globally, undermining genuine efforts to improve recycling rates and manage plastic pollution.

title: Soda Comeback Drives Sales Gains at Coca-Cola
summary: Coca-Cola Co. reported increased revenue and profit in its latest quarter, driven by a resurgence in demand for carbonated soft drinks, particularly Coca-Cola Zero Sugar in the U.S. CEO James Quincey noted that variations of its namesake cola, including lower-sugar options, were key contributors to the sales growth. This performance indicates a comeback for soda, despite the company's recent diversification into other beverage categories.

title: Coca-Cola earnings preview: Coke Energy is coming to the U.S., and coming for Red Bull
summary: Coca-Cola is set to report third-quarter earnings, with analysts anticipating discussions about the upcoming January 2020 launch of Coca-Cola Energy in the U.S. This marks the company's first energy drink, offering various versions including zero-calorie options, all containing 114 milligrams of caffeine per 12-ounce serving. Evercore analysts have noted some cannibalization in Europe where the product has already launched.

title: How Coca Cola Tried to Buy Off Ray Rogers and End the Campaign to Stop Killer Coke
summary: Ray Rogers, head of the Campaign to Stop Killer Coke for fifteen years, recounts Coca-Cola's alleged attempts to silence his activism. These attempts included getting his invitation to speak at a U.S. Chamber of Commerce luncheon rescinded and later offering significant financial incentives, including funding a large animal shelter, if he would end his campaign. Rogers maintains that he cannot be bought off and the campaign will only end if justice is served regarding Coca-Cola's complicity in human rights abuses.

title: The Recycling Partnership and The PepsiCo Foundation Raise $25 Million for U.S. Recycling -- Reaching Funding Goal One Year into Five-Year Challenge
summary: The Recycling Partnership and The PepsiCo Foundation's "All In On Recycling" challenge has successfully raised $25 million in just over a year, significantly ahead of its five-year goal. This initiative aims to improve residential recycling for over 25 million U.S. families by investing in infrastructure, like curbside carts, and educational programs to combat "wishcycling." The funds are supporting efforts in several states, with plans to expand, and are expected to capture 55 million pounds of new recyclables annually and avoid 5.5 million tons of CO2.

title: Fayard inducted into UA HOF
summary: Gary Fayard, former CFO and executive vice president of The Coca-Cola Co., has been selected for induction into the Alabama Business Hall of Fame. Fayard was instrumental in doubling Coca-Cola's revenues and oversaw a significant acquisition before retiring in 2014. He is also a University of Alabama alumnus and actively involved with the university and other organizations.

title: Coca-Cola Africa Is Investing in a World Without Waste
summary: Coca-Cola Africa is making a substantial investment of almost half a billion rand to boost plastic recycling industries across Southern and East Africa, as part of its "World Without Waste" vision. This initiative aims to reduce packaging waste, create green circular economies, and foster job creation, with goals including making packaging 100% recyclable by 2025 and achieving 50% recycled material in packaging by 2030. The company also commits to collecting and recycling one bottle or can for each one sold by 2030, leveraging partnerships and educational efforts to achieve a debris-free environment.

title: Coca-Cola launches 28 SKUs at NACS: ‘There’s no channel better to start in than convenience’
summary: Coca-Cola North America unveiled 28 new SKUs across its beverage portfolio at the National Association of Convenience Stores (NACS) show, emphasizing its strategy as a total beverage company. A major highlight is the upcoming North American launch of Coca-Cola Energy in early 2020, alongside new flavors for Coca-Cola, Fanta, Sprite, Minute Maid, and expansions in its coffee, tea, and functional beverage lines. The company views convenience stores as an ideal channel for introducing these new products due to the low barrier to trial for single-serve items.

title: Traeger Grills Hires Todd Smith as Chief Marketing Officer
summary: Traeger Grills has announced the appointment of Todd Smith as its new Chief Marketing Officer. Smith, who previously served as CMO for EXOS, brings extensive experience in brand building and storytelling to further elevate Traeger's lifestyle brand and community. He will lead global brand expansion efforts, focusing on engaging Traeger's passionate user base and attracting new audiences to wood-fired cooking.

title: Is The iShares Global Consumer Staples ETF (IXI) A Staple For Your Portfolio?
summary: The article evaluates the iShares Global Consumer Staples ETF (IXI) as a potential investment during a global recession. It highlights that consumer staples businesses, such as those included in IXI, tend to be more resilient during economic downturns as they provide essential products. While the ETF has shown strong historical performance, the author notes its higher management fee and industry-specific concentration as potential downsides, recommending it as a consideration for a diversified portfolio rather than a core holding.

title: Pepsi Says Higher Prices Haven’t Quenched Consumer Demand
summary: PepsiCo Inc. reported strong Q3 results, exceeding Wall Street estimates for sales and profit, driven by consumers' willingness to pay higher prices for its drinks and snacks. Despite concerns about a looming economic slowdown and weak manufacturing numbers, PepsiCo's CFO noted that U.S. consumers are doing well in terms of the company's business. The company expects to meet or exceed its full-year revenue growth thanks to strong performance across its divisions, including Frito-Lay and beverage units.

title: Coca-Cola Unveils 25% Recycled Marine PET Bottle
summary: Coca-Cola has unveiled its first sample bottle made with 25% recycled marine plastic, demonstrating the potential of enhanced recycling technologies for food and drink packaging. This initiative is part of Coca-Cola's broader sustainability goals in Western Europe, aiming for 100% recyclable packaging and increased recycled content in bottles by 2025, with accelerated targets for 2023. The company is investing in innovative solutions, including alternative packaging materials and well-designed deposit return schemes, to achieve a closed-loop economy for plastics.

title: Coca-Cola Energy powers its way to the US next year
summary: Coca-Cola is launching its new Coca-Cola Energy line in the United States in January 2020, following a European debut earlier in the year. This move expands Coke's presence in the energy drink segment, leveraging a loophole in its distribution contract with Monster and aiming to appeal to cola drinkers. The company hopes to capitalize on its brand recognition and previous experience with Monster to capture a share of the energy drink market, despite slowed growth in the overall category.

title: Toll Brothers, Carlyle Group Team on Atlanta Rental Project
summary: Toll Brothers, Inc. and The Carlyle Group have formed a joint venture to develop Osprey, a 320-unit luxury apartment community in Atlanta’s West Midtown neighborhood. The project, managed by Toll Brothers Apartment Living, has secured a construction loan from BB&T Real Estate Funding LLC and Comerica Bank. Osprey will offer various luxury amenities and is projected for leasing and first move-ins in early 2020.

title: Change can be Refreshing to your Bottom Line: Coca-Cola Consolidated Improves its Supply Chain Significantly with Real-time Visibility
summary: Coca-Cola Consolidated implemented FourKites' real-time visibility solution to significantly improve its supply chain operations. Despite initial resistance to change, the company, with $4.6 billion in revenues, enhanced its in-stock position to over 99% and reduced associated costs by improving warehouse scheduling and overall execution. The article highlights that while calculating the exact ROI for the platform is complex due to concurrent process changes, the visibility solution played a crucial role in these improvements and offers further opportunities for optimizing direct store delivery routes.

title: The Makers of Vita Coco & Lonely Whale Launch an Alternative to Single-Use Plastic Water Bottles
summary: Vita Coco and Lonely Whale partnered to launch "Ever & Ever," an aluminum-canned water as an eco-friendly alternative to single-use plastic water bottles. The initiative included the "Question How You Hydrate" campaign, a "Plastic Service Announcement" with celebrities, and a pop-up Museum of Plastic to raise awareness about plastic pollution and promote recycling aluminum. The campaign successfully generated significant impressions and led to Ever & Ever becoming the official water bottle of the United Nations, influencing larger competitors in the beverage industry.

title: Nestle, P&G say they will miss 2020 deforestation goals
summary: Nestle SA and Procter & Gamble Co have acknowledged they will not meet their 2020 goals to source ingredients that do not contribute to deforestation. Both companies, who made these pledges in 2010 at the urging of the Consumer Goods Forum, cite underestimation of demand and lax government regulations as reasons for falling short. Other major consumer goods companies have either declined to provide specifics on their deforestation goals or stated they will not make the 2020 zero deforestation pledges.

title: Reyes Coca-Cola Bottling announces Official Partnership with the Raiders and Allegiant Stadium
summary: Reyes Coca-Cola Bottling has announced an official partnership with the Raiders and Allegiant Stadium. This collaboration names Reyes Coca-Cola Bottling as the official soft drink partner for the team and stadium, aiming to refresh fans and positively impact the Southern Nevada community through joint philanthropic efforts. The partnership was celebrated at a Reyes Coca-Cola Bottling distribution center in Las Vegas.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper-backed firm launches smart nutrition bottle
summary: LifeFuels, backed by Keurig Dr Pepper, has launched what it describes as the first smart nutrition bottle, integrating with an app to track hydration and nutrition goals. The product, while expensive at $180 for the bottle and $12 per FuelPod, aims to appeal to health-conscious consumers seeking natural flavors, portability, and data tracking capabilities, much like Fitbit revolutionized exercise tracking. This investment aligns with Keurig Dr Pepper's strategy to diversify its portfolio beyond coffee and soda, mirroring its successful single-serve coffee platform.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper facility in Lehigh Valley to bring nearly 400 jobs, officials say
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper is opening a new manufacturing and logistics facility in Upper Macungie Township, Lehigh Valley, investing nearly $220 million and projected to create 378 new full-time jobs over three years. This project will add 811,000 square feet of manufacturing and warehouse space, optimizing the company's logistics in the Northeast and providing capacity for its brands. The company will receive state grants for the project and joins other national beverage companies in the area.

title: SMC folds packaging businesses in one entity
summary: San Miguel Corp. (SMC) is consolidating its packaging businesses under its subsidiary, San Miguel Yamamura Packaging Corp. (SMYPC), merging SMYPC and San Miguel Yamamura Asia Corp. (SMYAC) with SMYPC as the surviving entity. SMC will also increase its stake in SMYAC to 65 percent by acquiring an additional 5 percent. This move aims to streamline SMC's packaging operations, which serve a wide range of industries globally.

title: Ascent Industries focuses on the US, with an aim to take on edible and CBD products
summary: Ascent Industries Corp. (CSE:ASNT) is shifting its focus to its US operations in Nevada and Oregon, aiming to develop a varied portfolio of edible and CBD products. The company recently sold its Canadian business for C$41.5 million to address legacy issues and regulatory challenges, including revoked licenses and a trading halt. New CEO Paul Dillman is leading efforts to strengthen the US business, resolve financial and regulatory matters, and relaunch US assets under a new name.

title: 5 ways Coca-Cola is cleaning up its plastic footprint in Africa
summary: Coca-Cola is implementing its "World Without Waste" vision in Africa to address plastic pollution. This involves creating a sustainable collection and recycling model (PETCO), designing better packaging for a circular economy, partnering across various sectors, making collection accessible through consumer education and school programs, and sharing expertise to find solutions. The goal is to collect and recycle the equivalent of every bottle or can sold by 2030 and use 100% recyclable packaging by 2025.

title: False! Coca Cola did not sell 25 bottles only in its first year of sales
summary: A popular meme claims that Coca-Cola sold only 25 bottles in its first year of business. Africa Check investigated this claim and found it to be false. Coca-Cola was initially sold by the glass, averaging nine servings a day, and bottled Coca-Cola was introduced years later.

title: The prohibition of coca leaves is an out-dated, colonial heirloom
summary: This article argues that the prohibition of coca leaves is an outdated colonial relic, contrasting its historical cultural significance with its current ban based on unscientific rhetoric. It highlights the hypocrisy of the ban, noting that the U.S. remains the sole legal importer of coca for Coca-Cola and pharmaceutical purposes. The author criticizes this system as a form of imperialism, depriving indigenous communities of their ancestral plant's economic and cultural value.

title: 'Tis the Season! Coca-Cola Cinnamon and Sprite Winter Spiced Cranberry To Hit Shelves This Fall
summary: Coca-Cola is launching new seasonal flavors this fall: Coca-Cola Cinnamon and Sprite Winter Spiced Cranberry. Coca-Cola Cinnamon has been available in the U.K. previously, but this marks its U.S. debut, while Sprite Winter Spiced Cranberry is a new limited-edition offering. The Sprite flavor will be available from September 30 through December 31, or while supplies last.

title: Report: Chipotle, Sweetgreen bowls contain cancer-linked ‘forever chemicals’
summary: A report from The New Food Economy found that molded fiber bowls from restaurants like Chipotle and Sweetgreen contain cancer-linked "forever chemicals" called PFAS. While the levels don't exceed FDA thresholds and no immediate health threat is suggested for consumers, these chemicals do not biodegrade and can accumulate in the environment and potentially migrate into food. This raises concerns for environmental sustainability and long-term health, despite these bowls often being advertised as compostable.

title: Coca-Cola will sell Dasani in aluminum cans and bottles
summary: Coca-Cola is introducing Dasani in aluminum cans and bottles as part of a larger initiative to meet environmental goals and reduce plastic waste. The move includes new packaging, reduced plastic in existing bottles, and a hybrid bottle with recycled and plant-based materials. These changes aim to support Coca-Cola's environmental commitments and revitalize interest in its Dasani brand amid growing consumer concerns about plastic pollution.

title: Coca-Cola touts new packaging as part of Dasani's 'largest sustainability initiative' ever
summary: Coca-Cola is launching new recycled bottles and aluminum cans for its Dasani bottled water brand as part of its "largest sustainability initiative" ever. The aluminum cans will be available in the Northeastern U.S. later this year and nationwide in 2020, with new bottles following by mid-2020. This move continues Coca-Cola's environmental push, which has included previous efforts like launching "alcopop" in Japan and addressing animal abuse at a dairy supplier.

title: Coca-Cola advertisements featuring gay couples create stir in Hungary
summary: Coca-Cola's "Love is Love" advertising campaign, featuring same-sex couples and slogans like "Zero Sugar, Zero Prejudice," has caused controversy in Hungary. A member of the ruling conservative Fidesz Party called for a boycott, and an online petition gathered over 33,000 signatures in protest. Coca-Cola defended its campaign, citing its commitment to diversity and inclusion, and stated that sales in Hungary have not been significantly affected.

title: The Secret History of Why Soda Companies Switched From Sugar to High-Fructose Corn Syrup
summary: This article uncovers the complex history behind soda companies' shift from sugar to high-fructose corn syrup (HFCS), attributing it not just to corn subsidies but significantly to political maneuvering by Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) and its CEO Dwayne Andreas. It details how Andreas championed sugar import quotas during the Reagan administration, artificially inflating domestic sugar prices and making HFCS the more economical sweetener for beverage giants like Coke and Pepsi. The piece explains that this strategic political intervention, rather than just market forces, solidified HFCS's dominance in the soda industry.

title: Coca-Cola To Present New Line Of Healthy Beverages
summary: Coca-Cola reported increased revenue expectations for the year, attributing the growth to successful new lines of healthier beverages and coffees. Product innovation, including Coca-Cola Plus Coffee and lower-calorie Simply juices, now accounts for 25% of the company's revenue, up from 15% two years prior. The company sees significant growth potential in developing markets and expects full-year organic revenue growth of 5%.

title: More product placements may come to Netflix (but don’t call them ads)
summary: Netflix is increasingly using product placements in its shows, even though it denies being paid for them, especially after losing U.S. subscribers. "Stranger Things" is highlighted as a blueprint, with brands promoting the show in exchange for product visibility. This strategy allows Netflix to boost marketing for its hits without running traditional ads on its service.

title: Coke Shares Hit All-Time High as New Drinks Win Customers
summary: Coca-Cola's shares reached an all-time high after the company reported strong second-quarter earnings and raised its full-year revenue expectations. This success is attributed to its product innovation, particularly low-sugar sodas and iced coffees, which now account for 25% of the company's revenue. CEO James Quincey highlighted significant growth opportunities in developing markets and noted the positive impact of beverages like Coca-Cola Plus Coffee and the acquisition of Costa Coffee.

title: Embotelladora Andina negocia contrato con productores de pisco
summary: Embotelladora Andina, in conjunction with Coca Cola Embonor, is in negotiations with Cooperativa Agrícola y Pisquera Elqui Ltda and Viña Francisco de Aguirre S.A. for a distribution contract of pisco products in Chile. This move is part of Andina's strategy to grow and diversify its product portfolio into alcoholic beverages, a strategy initiated in 2018. The contract's finalization is contingent upon agreement between all parties and corporate approvals, with financial effects to be reported upon signing.

title: Coca-Cola invests $20M in Health-Ade Kombucha
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. has made a $20 million equity investment in Health-Ade Kombucha, continuing its strategy to diversify beyond soda into healthier beverages. This move follows previous investments and aligns with other major food and beverage companies entering the kombucha market, despite legal challenges Health-Ade has faced regarding labeling. The investment is expected to support Health-Ade's innovation and expansion efforts.

title: Coke and Monster settle their dispute over Coke’s energy drinks
summary: Coca-Cola and Monster Beverage Corp. have settled their dispute over Coke's energy drinks, with an arbitration ruling on July 1, 2019, allowing Coke to sell its brand-name energy drinks globally. The ruling stems from a loophole in their 2014 agreement, which prevents Coke from distributing other firms' energy drinks but permits marketing products under the Coca-Cola label. This development is expected to lead to direct competition between Coca-Cola Energy and Monster, potentially straining their relationship, as Coke seeks to diversify its portfolio due to declining soft drink consumption.

title: Donald Knauss, Richard Smucker Honored by Grocery Manufacturers Assoc.
summary: Donald Knauss and Richard Smucker are being honored with the 2019 Hall of Achievement Award by the Grocery Manufacturers Association (GMA) for their significant contributions to the consumer packaged goods industry. Knauss previously served as chair and CEO of The Clorox Company, while Smucker was the CEO and co-CEO of The J.M. Smucker Company. The award will be presented at GMA’s annual Leadership Forum on August 15th.

title: Diet Coke revival helps boost Coca-Cola brand: Brand Finance rankings
summary: Coca-Cola's brand value increased by 19% to $36.2bn, largely due to the successful relaunch and rebranding of Diet Coke. Despite Pepsi's brand value decreasing, PepsiCo maintains a stronger overall portfolio due to its food brands and acquisitions like SodaStream. The article also highlights the challenges faced by soda brands with declining sales, health-conscious consumers, and sugar taxes, emphasizing the need for evolution to maintain market dominance.

title: From Hot Sauce to Pop Gloss, US Products Seep Into Iran
summary: Despite heightened political tensions and sanctions, American brands and products like Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Heinz, and Tabasco are widely available and popular in Iran. Young Iranians particularly embrace U.S. lifestyle and products, although many items are bottled locally or enter the country through indirect channels. This prevalence highlights a cultural divide between official rhetoric and popular consumer choices in Iran.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Cannabis Career Watch | New Hires and Promotions July 12, 2019
summary: This article details new hires and promotions within the cannabis industry as of July 12, 2019. Key movements include leadership changes and new appointments at cbdMD, ONE Cannabis, Caliva, Surterra Wellness, Canopy Growth Corporation, Cresco Labs, Leafly, and Kona Gold Solutions. Noteworthy items include Jay-Z partnering with Caliva and Bruce Linton's departure from Canopy Growth.

title: Always Coca-Cola: World’s Favourite Soda Tops Brand Ranking
summary: Coca-Cola has retained its title as the world's most valuable soft drink brand, with its brand value increasing by 19% to US$36.2 billion, while Pepsi's brand value decreased. Nestlé leads as the most valuable food brand and possesses the largest food & drink brand portfolio globally, surpassing US$70 billion. The report also highlights declines for corporate brands like Kraft, Unilever, and Heinz, significant growth for China's Yili in dairy, and Quaker as the fastest-growing food brand.

title: New Coke is the weirdest pop culture throwback in Stranger Things 3
summary: The article explores the resurgence of New Coke in Stranger Things 3, detailing its history as a major marketing failure by The Coca-Cola Company in 1985. It explains how the show uses New Coke for both comedic effect and plot points, while also reviewing Polygon's taste test of the revived drink. The piece highlights New Coke's role as a nostalgic tie-in for the 1980s-set series.

title: Netflix's 'Stranger Things' revives New Coke. Here's how the failed soda cost Coca-Cola millions in 1985
summary: Netflix's "Stranger Things" is featuring New Coke in its third season, bringing back Coca-Cola's infamous 1985 marketing blunder. The original New Coke launch led to consumer boycotts and significant financial losses, including $4 million on research and marketing and $30 million in unsold inventory. Despite its failure, the New Coke fiasco is now seen as a cautionary business tale and ultimately reinvigorated consumer interest in Coca-Cola's classic formula.

title: James Quincey set to become chairman at Coca-Cola: ‘It’s another step in a process’
summary: James Quincey, CEO of The Coca-Cola Co., is set to become chairman, consolidating his leadership of the beverage company. This move signifies a shift towards a new leadership style focused on risk-taking and a diversified portfolio, moving beyond reliance on the flagship Coke brand. Quincey emphasizes continuous growth, environmental strategy, and maintaining Coca-Cola's strong civic engagement in Atlanta.

title: Coca-Cola heightens competition in Energy drink market, gets green light to sell own drink
summary: Coca-Cola has received approval to market its new trademark energy drink globally, intensifying competition in the energy drink market. This decision came after an arbitration tribunal ruled that Coca-Cola did not violate its 2015 agreement with Monster Beverage Corp. Coca-Cola's new energy drink, launched in April, aims to provide healthier alternatives to consumers and directly competes with market leaders like Red Bull, Lucozade, and Monster.

title: Coca-Cola settles Monster energy drink dispute
summary: Coca-Cola has settled its dispute with Monster Beverage Corporation over the launch of Coca-Cola Energy, following a ruling by an arbitration tribunal that allows Coca-Cola to continue selling and distributing the energy drink. The companies will maintain their partnership despite the disagreement over contractual language. Coca-Cola Energy, featuring additional caffeine and guarana, launched in Australia last month and is targeting the 18-39 age market.

title: The Coca-Cola Company and Monster Beverage Corporation Announce Decision by Arbitration Panel
summary: An arbitration panel has ruled that The Coca-Cola Company is permitted to introduce and sell Coca-Cola Energy products under its contract with Monster Beverage Corporation. The decision allows Coca-Cola to continue selling and distributing Coca-Cola Energy in existing markets and to launch the product in additional markets globally. Both companies respect the decision and appreciate the amicable resolution of the dispute, emphasizing their continued partnership.

title: Netflix’s ‘Stranger Things’ is dangerously close to becoming ‘Sponsored Things’
summary: This article argues that the extensive brand tie-ins for Netflix's "Stranger Things" are diluting the show's charm and overwhelming audiences. It critiques the over-farming of 1985 nostalgia through numerous partnerships, suggesting that only a few authentic marketing efforts truly resonate. The author points out that an excessive number of brand connections makes it difficult for viewers to distinguish between genuine product placement and promotional deals, ultimately leading to indifference.

title: Coca-Cola wins energy drink arbitration case against Monster
summary: Coca-Cola has won an arbitration case against Monster Beverage Corp, allowing it to sell its own brand of energy drinks globally despite holding a 16.7% stake in Monster. The ruling determined that contract language from their 2014 agreement permitted Coca-Cola to market its "Coca-Cola Energy" line, leading to a dip in Monster's shares initially. This move allows Coca-Cola to diversify its portfolio in the growing energy drink market, though it may create competition with Monster.

title: PepsiCo to Switch From Plastic to Cans for Aquafina Water
summary: PepsiCo announced it will begin selling Aquafina water in aluminum cans next year, initially to partners like stadiums and restaurants, and experimenting in retail stores. This move is part of the company's broader sustainability efforts, including transitioning its Lifewatr brand to 100% recycled plastic and discontinuing plastic bottles for Bubly sparkling water, aiming to eliminate over 8,000 metric tons of virgin plastic. The decision comes amidst industry-wide pressure to reduce plastic waste, with aluminum cans offering better recyclability and a higher percentage of reused material compared to plastic.

title: Coca-Cola’s Digital Marketplace, Powered by Omnivore, to Connect Restaurants to Technology Solutions
summary: Coca-Cola North America is launching a digital marketplace, powered by Omnivore, to connect its foodservice customers with over 150 pre-vetted restaurant technologies. This marketplace aims to simplify the process for restaurants to find and integrate best-in-class digital solutions, reducing time and cost for technology adoption. It builds on Coca-Cola's investment in Omnivore and will offer free integration for Coca-Cola customers.

title: American Dream Reveals Multi-Faceted Partnership With Coca-Cola
summary: American Dream has announced a 10-year, multimillion-dollar partnership with The Coca-Cola Company and Liberty Coca-Cola Beverages, integrating Coca-Cola's brands throughout the destination. This alliance will feature bespoke events, a social media storefront, VIP green rooms, and a branded dining destination, creating unique experiences for the projected 40 million annual visitors. The partnership also includes the integration of Coca-Cola beverages in culinary and entertainment, alongside unique artistic collaborations and "American Dream"-flavored beverages.

title: Coca-Cola NA launches digital marketplace for foodservice
summary: Coca-Cola North America is launching a digital marketplace this fall to connect its foodservice customers with pre-vetted restaurant technologies. This platform, powered by Omnivore, aims to simplify the process for restaurants to research, integrate, and deploy digital solutions for front-of-house, back-of-house, and outside-of-house operations. The initiative is part of Coca-Cola's broader strategy to build a digital ecosystem that supports customer business operations and profit growth.

title: The IOC, The Coca-Cola Company and China Mengniu Dairy Company Ltd announce Joint Worldwide Olympic Partnership to 2032
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC), The Coca-Cola Company, and China Mengniu Dairy Company Ltd have announced a pioneering Joint TOP Partnership Agreement, set to run through the Olympic Games 2032. This twelve-year deal combines non-alcoholic beverages and dairy categories, extending Coca-Cola's historic 104-year relationship with the Olympic Movement and bringing Mengniu in as the first Chinese fast-moving consumer goods TOP Partner. The partnership aims to promote Olympic values globally through unprecedented investment in traditional and digital media, supporting Mengniu's international growth ambitions.

title: PHILIP GEIER Obituary (1935 - 2019) - New York, NY - New York Times
summary: Philip H. Geier, Jr., former Chairman and CEO of The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc. (NYSE: IPG), died on June 19, 2019, at the age of 84. He was a prominent figure in the advertising industry, having grown Interpublic into a global enterprise during his 20-year tenure and being inducted into the Advertising Hall of Fame. Geier was also known for his philanthropy, involvement in the arts, and political contributions, serving on numerous corporate and philanthropic boards throughout his life.

title: Packaging drives Enjoy Coca-Cola campaign
summary: The Coca-Cola Company launched its "Enjoy Coca-Cola" campaign, a packaging-driven initiative to enhance summer experiences. The campaign features special summer packaging for Coca-Cola and Coke Zero Sugar, including Sip & Scan labels and peel-away wristbands with summery designs. This initiative also integrates new TV, cinema, social/digital, in-store, outdoor, and radio advertising.

title: Bink’s beverage distributors continue 116-year tradition
summary: Bink's Coca-Cola and Bink's Wines & Beverages continue a 116-year family tradition of beverage distribution in the local area. The business, originally established in 1903, adapted during Prohibition to bottle soft drinks and later re-entered the alcohol distribution market. Today, the companies focus on selling, distributing, and expanding their product lines and service areas for both alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages.

title: Coca-Cola "Opens Happiness" But Shuts The Mouths Of Researchers
summary: Recent research has uncovered that Coca-Cola manipulates and suppresses scientific studies funded or partially funded by public institutions, particularly those that show negative health impacts from its products. This practice, revealed through an analysis of over 87,000 documents, contradicts the company's transparency declarations and allows them to control research outcomes to their benefit, often blaming childhood obesity on inactivity rather than high sugar content. The article calls for greater transparency and regulation in scientific research funding and urges consumers to distance themselves from such multinational corporations.

title: Metal packaging leader Ball looks to grow Indian business
summary: Ball, a global leader in metal packaging, is looking to significantly expand its business in India by capitalizing on the low per capita consumption of metal cans and the growing demand for sustainable packaging. With two beverage packaging plants and an aerosol can plant, Ball India aims to address local challenges like excise duties and promote metal cans as a highly recyclable and sustainable option. The company plans to innovate with print technologies and new materials like aluminum cups, while also working to improve the collection of used beverage cans for recycling in India.

title: Coca-Cola Company taking action to address alleged animal abuse at Fair Oaks Farms
summary: The Coca-Cola Company is investigating allegations of animal abuse at Fair Oaks Farms, a dairy supplier for its product Fairlife, following a video released by Animal Recovery Mission. Coca-Cola stated that such cruelty is unacceptable and contrary to their company values, launching an internal investigation alongside increased audits by Fairlife and Fair Oaks Farms. Some retailers, like Rouses Markets, have already started pulling Fairlife products from their shelves due to the unsettling information.

title: Walmart execs talk about taking risks, trade issues at shareholder rally and analyst meeting
summary: Walmart executives discussed their philosophy of taking risks, global trade issues, and future growth strategies at their annual shareholder meeting and subsequent analyst meeting. CEO Doug McMillon emphasized the company's problem-solving culture, commitment to low prices despite tariffs, and offered career advice to aspiring employees. Walmart's stock price saw a positive reaction from Wall Street, trading higher following the executive presentations.

title: Ball Corporation looks to grow Indian business - THE PACKMAN
summary: Ball Corporation, a global supplier of metal packaging, is looking to expand its business in India, where it currently has a production capacity of 1.3 billion cans. The company sees significant growth opportunities due to low per capita consumption of metal cans compared to other developing markets and is investing in initiatives to leverage aluminum packaging for dairy and craft brewery markets. Despite challenges like excise duties, Ball Corporation highlights the environmental and logistical advantages of aluminum cans to boost market penetration in India.

title: Coca-Cola offers consumers $10K to create best new drink concoction
summary: Coca-Cola has launched a "Make Your Mix" contest offering $10,000 to the consumer who creates the best new flavor combination using their Freestyle machines. Participants must upload a photo and recipe to social media by June 30, with finalists announced from July 15 to August 25, and the winner revealed on November 11. This initiative aims to leverage consumer creativity for potential new product development and to engage a younger demographic.

title: Vita Coco maker thirsts for aluminum as it enters competitive bottled water space
summary: The maker of Vita Coco coconut water, All Market, is launching a new premium bottled water brand called Ever & Ever, packaged in aluminum, to address consumer demand for sustainable options. This move marks All Market's entry into the competitive bottled water market, leveraging aluminum's high recyclability in contrast to the commonly used plastic bottles. The company aims to differentiate Ever & Ever through its sustainability message and distinctive packaging to gain market share despite the saturated nature of the category.

title: Intuit Acquires Data Analytics Startup Origami Logic
summary: Intuit Inc. has announced its agreement to acquire Silicon Valley-based data analytics startup Origami Logic Inc. for an undisclosed amount, expected to close in Q4 2019. Founded in 2011, Origami Logic provides market performance analytics to major brands and has raised $64.5 million in total funding. This acquisition aims to enhance Intuit's ability to deliver personalized insights to its customers.

title: Drink like it’s 1985: Coca-Cola revives New Coke for Stranger Things 3
summary: Coca-Cola is re-releasing New Coke as a tie-in with Netflix's Stranger Things 3, which is set in 1985. 500,000 cans will be available online and at the World of Coca-Cola in Atlanta, complete with Stranger Things promotional designs and a remake of the original New Coke ad. This promotional event capitalizes on New Coke's historical significance as a major news story in the 1980s due to its consumer backlash.

title: Coca-Cola is bringing back New Coke in honor of ‘Stranger Things’
summary: Coca-Cola is bringing back a limited number of New Coke cans as a promotion for the third season of "Stranger Things," which is set in 1985 when New Coke originally debuted and famously flopped. This partnership with Netflix allows Coca-Cola to engage with consumers in changing media landscapes and aims to "break the internet" with the nostalgic product, which will be available through various promotional channels. Netflix is also partnering with several other companies for show promotion, leveraging physical products to reach wider audiences.

title: Coca-Cola Will Revive New Coke in Alliance With Netflix, ‘Stranger Things’
summary: Coca-Cola is reviving New Coke for a limited time as part of a partnership with Netflix, integrating the infamous beverage into the third season of "Stranger Things," which is set in 1985. This marketing initiative aims to promote both the return of the series and gives Coca-Cola a unique way to connect with streaming audiences, despite New Coke's historical marketing failure. Coca-Cola will make 500,000 cans available online and in select locations, also releasing limited-edition original Coke with "Stranger Things" designs.

title: New Coke Was a Debacle. It’s Coming Back. Blame ‘Stranger Things.’ (Published 2019)
summary: New Coke, the famously failed soft drink from 1985, is making a limited-time comeback due to a promotional partnership with Netflix's "Stranger Things." The vintage beverage will be available starting Thursday and will appear in the show's upcoming third season, which is set in summer 1985. This collaboration is part of Netflix's broader strategy to ramp up corporate partnerships and merchandising to attract new subscribers and generate revenue without commercials.

title: 1985: New Coke and Stranger Things
summary: Coca-Cola is partnering with Netflix's Stranger Things Season 3 to bring back New Coke in a limited promotional run, leveraging the show's 1985 setting. The collaboration involved extensive research into Coca-Cola's archives and includes in-show appearances, a limited release of the original New Coke recipe, and a Duffer Brothers-directed advertisement. This initiative aims to engage fans with a nostalgic pop culture moment and connect Coca-Cola brands to a global audience through non-advertising platforms.

title: Wix buys brand promotion agency Gefen Team
summary: Wix.com Ltd. has acquired Tel Aviv-based brand promotion agency Gefen Team to strengthen its brand and help achieve its goal of becoming one of the world's 100 strongest and best-loved brands. Gefen Team's entire staff will join Wix's marketing department, led by Eran Gefen, and will focus on building an international brand. Financial details were not disclosed, but the acquisition is not considered material given Wix's cash reserves of $789 million.

title: Morgan Stanley upgrades Coca-Cola to overweight: 'Coke is now our top mega-cap staples pick'
summary: Morgan Stanley upgraded Coca-Cola shares to overweight from equal weight, setting a new 12-month price target of $55. The firm believes Coca-Cola is trading at an "unfair discount to peers" given its superior growth outlook, pricing power, and rebounding emerging market trends. Coca-Cola is now Morgan Stanley's top mega-cap staples pick, with analysts raising future EPS estimates.

title: La empresa Coca Cola Andina aclaró que no tiene deudas con los transportistas
summary: Coca Cola Andina Argentina has clarified that it has no outstanding debts with transport providers, despite an ongoing blockade by the Sindicato de Camioneros affecting the supply of its products. The company states that it has paid for all services rendered by its contracted transport providers in a timely manner. Coca Cola Andina expresses regret for the disruption caused to collaborators, clients, and small businesses, and hopes for a quick resolution through dialogue.

title: High Country owners of Coca-Cola Bottling in Missoula break ground on new plant
summary: High Country, owners of the Coca-Cola Bottling plant in Missoula, broke ground on a new 69,000-square-foot facility set to open next spring. This move will nearly double their current space, provide easier access for delivery trucks near Interstate 90, and relocate the industrial operation from a growing residential area to a designated development park. The multimillion-dollar investment will employ approximately 55 people and increase tax revenue for Missoula County.

title: Target rebrands digital-advertising business as Roundel
summary: Target has rebranded its digital advertising business from Target Media Network to Roundel, signaling an aggressive push into the digital advertising sector. The company aims to leverage its customer data and "exceptional branding" to offer personalized ad campaigns for its 1,000 clients, including major brands like Disney and Coca-Cola. This move positions Target to compete more directly with other retailers like Amazon and Walmart, which have also seen success in their advertising businesses.

title: Gartner for Human Resources Leaders
summary: Gartner for Human Resources Leaders provides actionable insights and tools for HR professionals to address their mission-critical priorities. The page highlights resources for CHROs and HR leaders, including benchmarks, expert guidance, and events like the Gartner HR Symposium/Xpo. It also offers insights into top HR priorities and trends, particularly focusing on AI's impact and talent strategy.

title: After brutal year, Kraft Heinz taps AB InBev's Miguel Patricio to replace CEO Bernardo Hees
summary: Kraft Heinz announced that CEO Bernardo Hees will step down on June 30 and be replaced by Miguel Patricio, former chief marketing officer at AB InBev. This executive change follows a challenging period for Kraft Heinz, marked by a significant dividend reduction, brand write-downs, and an SEC investigation. Patricio, who has no affiliation with 3G Capital, is expected to shift the company's focus from cost-cutting to organic growth, brand building, and consumer focus.

title: Genuine Parts CEO picked to be sixth chairman in the company's 91-year history
summary: Genuine Parts Company's board of directors appointed CEO Paul Donahue as chairman on April 22, 2019, making him the sixth chairman in the company's 91-year history. Donahue was previously elected president and CEO on May 1, 2016. This appointment mirrors a similar leadership transition at The Coca-Cola Company, where James Quincey is also assuming the dual role of chairman and CEO.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper partners to deliver an Adrenaline Shoc to the energy drink category
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper has partnered with beverage entrepreneur Lance Collins to launch Adrenaline Shoc, a new energy drink targeted at the after-workout crowd. This sugar-free beverage, containing 300 mg of caffeine and natural energy boosters, aims to compete in the increasingly crowded energy drink market. Despite a slowdown in the category's growth rate, Keurig Dr Pepper hopes to differentiate Adrenaline Shoc with its "better-for-you" ingredients and premium pricing.

title: Third-generation Coca-Cola bottling family helps share best practices with others
summary: The Messinger family, operating Coca-Cola High Country, shares the story of their multigenerational business success, originating from L.E. Messinger in 1927. They highlight communication, defined roles, and the value of the Prairie Family Business Association in their journey. Tura Synhorst, VP of corporate affairs, discusses her motivation as chair of the association's advisory board and the importance of supporting other family-owned businesses.

title: Coca Cola bottler moving to West Memphis
summary: Coca-Cola Consolidated is moving its bottling operations from Memphis to West Memphis, investing $33 million in a 200,000 square foot expansion at its existing West Memphis plant. The Memphis facility will close by the end of 2020 due to lack of expansion room, impacting 79 employees, 60 of whom will be offered transfers. West Memphis secured the investment through a PILOT program, with its mayor expressing enthusiasm for the economic boost.

title: Coca-Cola Consolidated Announces $33M West Memphis Expansion
summary: Coca-Cola Consolidated Inc. announced a $33 million, 200,000-square-foot expansion of its West Memphis production facility, expected to create about 60 new jobs in Arkansas. The project, set to begin construction in August 2019 and finish in late 2020, involves transferring jobs and equipment from its Memphis production facility while maintaining distribution and logistics operations in Memphis. This investment highlights Coca-Cola's commitment to the region and has been welcomed by Arkansas state and local officials for its economic impact.

title: Don’t fall for Kenya ‘Coca-Cola jobs’ scam on Facebook
summary: Africa Check warns Kenyans about a circulating Facebook scam offering fake Coca-Cola job vacancies for an application fee. The Coca-Cola Company has confirmed that these recruitment drives are fraudulent and are not associated with them, urging job seekers to only trust official recruitment channels which do not charge fees. Victims are advised to stop communication with fraudsters and report them to the police.

title: Coca Cola Andina Argentina desmiente retraso de pago
summary: Coca Cola Andina Argentina has issued a statement refuting claims of delayed payments to its employees and transportation providers. The company asserts that all employee salaries are paid on time and operations are normal. They also clarified that the personnel mentioned in some news reports are not affiliated with Coca Cola Andina Argentina.

title: Bang Energy CEO and Monster Energy Corp Engage in Major Legal Battle
summary: Bang Energy CEO Jack Owoc and Monster Energy Corp are embroiled in a significant legal battle, with Monster filing an expanded lawsuit against Bang, and Owoc reciprocating with a trademark infringement suit against Monster and Reign Beverage Corp. Owoc further escalated the conflict with a detailed Instagram post accusing Monster of trying to stifle fair competition and highlighting Bang's superior market growth and Monster's declining stock value. The dispute underscores intense competition in the energy drink market, fueled by accusations of unfair practices and claims of product superiority.

title: The realities of rethinking plastic packaging
summary: This article discusses the complexities of reducing plastic packaging in supply chains, highlighting the challenges manufacturers face in balancing sustainability goals with product integrity and waste prevention. It covers efforts by companies like Walmart, Trader Joe's, and Sonoco Products to reduce plastic use, improve recyclability, and explore alternative materials, while also addressing the limitations and considerations of these substitutes. The piece emphasizes that eliminating plastic entirely isn't a simple solution, as other materials have their own environmental impacts and plastics often play a crucial role in preventing food waste.

title: What Analysts Expect from Monster Beverage’s Sales in 2019
summary: Monster Beverage saw significant sales growth in 2018, primarily driven by its Monster Energy Drinks segment, and analysts project continued growth in 2019, albeit at a slower pace due to market concerns and competition. The company plans to leverage Coca-Cola's distribution network and introduce new products to boost sales, despite facing potential margin pressures from higher costs.

title: Coca-Cola Energy headlines slate of beverage innovation at NACS Show
summary: Coca-Cola showcased numerous new beverage innovations at the 2019 NACS Show, with Coca-Cola Energy leading the introductions. This article details new product launches across various brands including Coke, Sprite, Fanta, Simply Tea, Peace Tea, Smartwater, Odwalla, and the new Gomega line, highlighting the company's strategy to meet evolving consumer preferences and drive category growth.

title: How Coca‑Cola Rolled Out the Red Carpet in a Sea of Blue
summary: This article details how Coca-Cola implemented a unique commercial strategy to dominate its home market of Atlanta during the 2019 Super Bowl, despite a rival company having sponsorship rights. By focusing on local activations and customer engagement, Coca-Cola achieved its strongest January retail sales growth ever in Atlanta and strengthened relationships with partners. The successful campaign demonstrated a "gold-standard partnership example" for future major events.

title: Richard M. Daley to Retire from Coca-Cola Board of Directors
summary: Richard M. Daley will retire from The Coca-Cola Company's Board of Directors after eight years of service, having chosen not to stand for reelection at the upcoming annual meeting in April. Daley, former mayor of Chicago, also serves as executive chairman of Tur Partners LLC and Of Counsel at Katten Muchin Rosenman LLP. His departure will result in the Coca-Cola board having 13 members.

title: Dr Pepper's new home? Frisco set to approve new office building at Dallas Cowboys' Star development
summary: The City of Frisco is poised to approve a deal to provide land for a new corporate office building at the Dallas Cowboys' Star development, which is expected to house Keurig Dr Pepper's local offices. The city plans to sell a 2.49-acre site to Jerry Jones' Blue Star Land at a reduced cost, essentially providing a $2.1 million grant to facilitate the development. This move comes as Keurig Dr Pepper reportedly plans to relocate its offices from Plano's Legacy business park to The Star.

title: The Coca-Cola Company Names New Chief People Officer
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced Lisa Chang has been named chief people officer, effective March 1, 2019. Chang previously served as senior vice president and chief human resources officer for AMB Group LLC and held HR leadership roles at Equifax and Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. She replaces Jennifer Mann, who is now president of Global Ventures for the company.

title: PepsiCo’s stock gains as Q4 results match expectations
summary: PepsiCo Inc. reported fourth-quarter 2018 revenue and earnings that met market expectations, leading to a slight stock gain. The company's net income significantly improved to $6.8 billion, driven by income tax benefits, and it expects organic revenue growth of 4% for full-year 2019. PepsiCo also announced a 3% increase in its annualized dividend per share.

title: Here are the 'headwinds' Coca-Cola CEO James Quincey sees for the company
summary: Coca-Cola CEO and incoming Chairman James Quincey discussed the company's outlook and potential weakening of the U.S. economy in a "First on CNBC" interview. The interview covered the "headwinds" he perceives for the company.

title: Coke stock heads for worst day since 2008, Nvidia looks to capitalize on ‘positive set up’
summary: Coca-Cola Co. (Coke) stock is experiencing a significant downturn, heading for its worst day since 2008, largely due to "softness" in its North America business, a revenue miss, and a disappointing outlook for the year. The company is facing challenges in regions like Argentina and Turkey and plans to increase marketing expenses in 2019, despite some encouraging trends in North America and China. The article also mentions Nvidia looking to capitalize on a positive setup, alongside other earnings watch updates for Six Flags, Avon, and Yeti.

title: Coke Sales Suffer in Southern California Under New Distribution System; Survey Says
summary: The Teamsters Union announced a conference call for Coca-Cola Co. investors and analysts to discuss declining sales and service in Southern California due to Reyes Coca-Cola Bottling's new "static routing" delivery program. A Teamster survey of retailers in metro Los Angeles and San Diego revealed significant disruption, raising questions for investors and impacting Teamster jobs ahead of contract negotiations.

title: Hershey Bans Animal Tests After Working With PETA
summary: The Hershey Company has re-committed to banning animal testing for marketing health claims after PETA identified a violation of a previous pledge. This recommitment follows an incident where Hershey provided cocoa ingredients for an experiment involving mice, which the company confirmed as an "anomaly" and has now formalized its no-animal-testing policy publicly. Hershey joins a growing list of companies that have ended animal experiments for health marketing claims after discussions with PETA.

title: Delta Air Lines, Coca-Cola Apologize For Offensive In-flight Napkins
summary: Delta Air Lines and Coca-Cola have issued apologies for in-flight napkins that were deemed "creepy" by passengers. The napkins, advertising Diet Coke, encouraged passengers to write down their name and number to give to their "plane crush." Both companies stated they are removing the offending napkins and replacing them with other designs.

title: Crónica: Visita a la planta más grande de Coca Cola Femsa
summary: This article details a visit to Coca-Cola Femsa's Toluca plant, which celebrates its 20th anniversary. It highlights the plant's growth from one production line to 12, producing 700,000 cases daily, and its position as the third-largest Coca-Cola bottler globally and the largest for Femsa. The piece also covers its sustainable practices, including achieving "zero waste" certification and utilizing renewable energy and water recycling.

title: Coca-Cola Femsa y el Estado de México anuncian una alianza contra la inseguridad
summary: Coca-Cola Femsa and the State of Mexico have announced an alliance to combat insecurity. This partnership involves sharing video surveillance from Femsa's plants and Oxxo stores with the state's C5 centers, and integrating company trucks into the state's monitoring system for immediate response to incidents. Additionally, Femsa will contribute to crime prevention by developing recreational spaces in areas where the state is investing in lighting infrastructure.

title: Coca-Cola CEO: More uncertainty is the ‘biggest issue’
summary: Coca-Cola CEO James Quincey discussed the company's growth in 2019 and the soft drink sector during an interview on "Squawk Box" in Davos. He identified "more uncertainty" as the biggest issue facing the business. The article highlights his perspective on these challenges.

title: Will Monster Reign with its new performance energy drink?
summary: Monster Beverage Corp. is launching a new performance energy drink called Reign in March, targeting both traditional energy drink consumers and the pre-/post-workout market with zero-sugar, zero-calorie options containing caffeine, BCAAs, and CoQ10. This move attempts to expand Monster's customer base to health-conscious consumers, despite competitive market challenges and recent struggles with international sales and gross margins. Alongside Reign, Monster plans further innovations in tea and coffee to drive growth and leadership in the energy drink sector.

title: Coca-Cola Takes Its Obesity Philanthropy to China
summary: New research reveals that Coca-Cola deliberately undermined China's efforts to address its growing obesity epidemic by shifting the direction of obesity research in its favor. Through financial support of organizations like the International Life Sciences Institute (ILSI), Coca-Cola promoted exercise as the primary solution to obesity, rather than dietary changes. This influence has significantly impacted China's public health policy, entrenching the idea that physical activity is the main solution.

title: January 8, 2019 - EX-99.1 - 8-K: Current report filing | The Coca-Cola Company (KO)
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced the completion of its $4.9 billion acquisition of Costa Limited from Whitbread PLC, following regulatory approvals. This acquisition provides Coca-Cola with a significant entry into the global coffee business, which is growing at 6% annually, offering a scalable platform for future expansion and new product introductions. The move is part of Coca-Cola's strategy to expand its portfolio in the growing coffee category and leverage Costa's capabilities with Coca-Cola's global reach.

title: CBD drinks: Tilray, Anheuser-Busch InBev partner to research cannabis-infused drinks for the Canadian market
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev and medical cannabis company Tilray have partnered in a $100 million deal to research non-alcoholic cannabis-infused drinks for the Canadian market, with each company investing $50 million. This alliance follows Canada's legalization of recreational marijuana and marks the latest entry of a major beer company into the burgeoning cannabis industry. The collaboration will explore drinks containing CBD and THC, building on Tilray's international presence and the overall growth of the North American legal cannabis market.

title: Cannabis Attracts Big Tobacco, Alcohol, and Pharma. Which Big Industries Will Join Next?
summary: The cannabis industry has seen major investments from Big Tobacco (Altria), Alcohol (Constellation Brands, Molson), and Pharma (Novartis, GW Pharmaceuticals), signaling a significant shift as mainstream industries enter the market. As federal prohibition looms for the U.S., other sectors like agriculture, food & beverage, technology, and ancillary service providers are poised to follow suit through partnerships, mergers, and acquisitions. This consolidation and influx of traditional companies will reshape the cannabis landscape once regulatory hurdles are removed.

title: Coca-Cola provides loan to advance PET recycling tech
summary: Coca-Cola Co. is providing a loan to Ioniqa Technologies, a Dutch startup specializing in PET depolymerization technology. This loan aims to accelerate the development and deployment of high-grade recycled content PET for Coca-Cola's bottles. This initiative aligns with Coca-Cola's goal to achieve 50 percent recycled content in its packaging by 2030, marking its second investment in depolymerization technologies within a month.

title: Grading our progress toward a world without waste
summary: The CEO of The Coca-Cola Company discusses the progress of their "World Without Waste" initiative, aiming to collect and recycle bottles and cans, make packaging 100% recyclable by 2025, and use 50% recycled material by 2030. The article highlights the sharing of PlantBottle technology and collaborative efforts to create a circular economy for plastic, citing an example from South Africa. It emphasizes the need for bolder action and cooperation among companies, governments, and NGOs to address global waste challenges.

title: Coca-Cola invests in PET recycling company
summary: Coca-Cola has invested in Ioniqa Technologies, a Netherlands-based recycling company, to advance the processing of hard-to-recycle PET plastics. This move aligns with Coca-Cola's goal to achieve 50% recycled packaging materials by 2030 and address consumer demand for more sustainable products. Ioniqa's technology aims to produce food-grade PET from post-consumer waste, tackling challenges faced by current recycling methods and potentially offering a viable solution for complex plastic waste streams.

title: Coke can maker Ball Corp to sell China manufacturing facilities
summary: Ball Corp, a major soda can manufacturer, announced its plan to sell its manufacturing facilities in China for approximately $225 million due to an excess supply of beverage cans in the country leading to unsustainable business conditions. The facilities will be sold to Chinese metal packaging company ORG Technology Co Ltd, with the proceeds supporting Ball's global expansion and share repurchase program. The company clarified that the sale is unrelated to U.S.-China trade tensions or tariffs on aluminum.

title: Coca-Cola’s Quincey sees acquisition pace slowing in 2019
summary: James Quincey, CEO of The Coca-Cola Co., anticipates a slower acquisition pace in 2019 compared to 2018, as the company focuses on integrating recent investments. He emphasized that the deal-making process is "a very lumpy proposition" and that the previous year's feverish pace, which included agreements with six different brands, is unlikely to continue. Quincey also discussed the strategic implications of the Costa acquisition, particularly its role in expanding Coca-Cola's presence in hot beverages and leveraging Costa's multiple formats within the Coke system.

title: Coca-Cola's new CFO on company's new strategy
summary: Coca-Cola's new CFO, John Murphy, was interviewed by CNBC's Sara Eisen to discuss the company's new strategy. The interview focused on the global growth environment for Coca-Cola, changes within its portfolio, and overall company transformations. This discussion provides insights into the strategic direction under new financial leadership.

title: Coca-Cola Company to sell historic midtown Manhattan building
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. is selling its historic midtown Manhattan building, known as the Coca-Cola Building, which it acquired in 1983 as part of its acquisition of Columbia Pictures. The company has hired Cushman & Wakefield to manage the sale of the 19-story tower.

title: Jury finds Monster Energy drink didn’t cause Texas man’s heart attack
summary: A Riverside County jury found that Monster Beverage Corp. was not liable for a Texas man’s debilitating heart attack, marking a significant legal victory for the energy drink company. This was the first product-liability lawsuit against Monster to go to a jury trial, with the defense successfully arguing that their products are safe and contain less caffeine than many common beverages. The plaintiff plans to appeal the verdict, citing the exclusion of scientific studies linking energy drinks to heart issues.

title: More Americans Struggle, Better Dollar Stores Do
summary: Dollar stores like Dollar General and Dollar Tree are rapidly expanding by targeting low-income, predominantly black, and rural communities, banking on a permanent American underclass. A report by the Institute for Local Self-Reliance (ILSR) highlights that these stores, which sell mostly processed foods, now outsell Whole Foods in grocery sales and actively contribute to food deserts, negatively impacting local grocers. The article also discusses efforts by communities, such as Tulsa, Oklahoma, to counteract their proliferation and encourage healthier food access.

title: James Quincey to Succeed Muhtar Kent as Chairman of The Coca-Cola Company
summary: James Quincey, currently President and CEO of The Coca-Cola Company, has been elected to succeed Muhtar Kent as Chairman after the company's annual meeting in April 2019. Kent will retire after 41 years with the Coca-Cola system. Additionally, Sam Nunn will step down as director, and Maria Elena Lagomasino will become the new Lead Independent Director.

title: Altria in deal talks with cannabis company Cronos Group
summary: Marlboro cigarette maker Altria Group Inc. is in discussions with Canadian cannabis producer Cronos Group Inc. for a possible investment, seeking to diversify its business beyond traditional tobacco as cigarette smoking declines in the U.S. This potential deal would represent a significant combination between mainstream tobacco and the burgeoning marijuana sector, following other major consumer companies' interest in the industry. Cronos shares rose 11 percent on the Nasdaq, while Altria shares increased 1.64 percent on the NYSE following the news.

title: Monopoly and the U.S. Waste Knot
summary: This article discusses the monopolistic control of the U.S. waste and recycling industry by "Big Waste" companies, which prioritize landfills over recycling due to higher profits. It traces the history of the waste industry's consolidation, the rise and stagnation of recycling, and the efforts by local communities to counter this trend. The author proposes strategies for local governments and businesses to decouple from Big Waste and foster more sustainable waste management practices like composting and dual-stream recycling.

title: Cannabis firm confirms investment talks with Marlboro maker
summary: Altria, the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, is in discussions with Canadian cannabis producer Cronos Group for a potential investment. Cronos Group confirmed the talks but stated no agreement has been reached yet. This move follows Altria's strategy to diversify from traditional tobacco products, as other major companies are also investing in the rapidly growing cannabis sector after Canada legalized recreational cannabis.

title: Marlboro-maker Altria is reportedly in talks to buy marijuana producer Cronos Group
summary: Altria, the company behind Marlboro cigarettes, is reportedly in early talks to acquire Canadian marijuana producer Cronos Group. This potential deal would represent the largest tie-up between the tobacco and marijuana sectors, as Altria looks to diversify its business amidst declining cigarette sales. Cronos Group's shares rose significantly on the news, pushing its market capitalization close to $2 billion.

title: Marlboro maker in talks to acquire Canadian cannabis company
summary: Altria Group Inc., the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, is reportedly in early acquisition talks with Canadian cannabis producer Cronos Group Inc. This move signals Altria's strategy to diversify beyond its declining traditional tobacco business, following Canada's legalization of recreational marijuana. The potential deal highlights a growing trend of major consumer companies investing in the burgeoning cannabis sector.

title: Cover Story: A modern day gold rush
summary: The article discusses the burgeoning cannabis industry, likening it to a "modern-day gold rush" due to significant investor excitement and market growth, particularly in North America. It explores the medical potential and recreational legalization of cannabis, detailing market opportunities, investment vehicles like ETFs, and the emergence of private market funding, while also highlighting key risks and stock performance. Both public and private investment perspectives are covered, alongside the evolving regulatory landscape in various countries.

title: Kraft Heinz buys paleo brand Primal Kitchen for $200M
summary: Kraft Heinz is acquiring Primal Kitchen, a paleo condiment and sauce brand, for $200 million, with the transaction expected to close in early 2019. Primal Kitchen will operate autonomously under Kraft Heinz's Springboard division, gaining access to supply chain and distribution channels. This acquisition marks Kraft Heinz's continued effort to innovate and expand its healthier product offerings amidst recent sales struggles.

title: Why Coca-Cola shouldn’t try to ride the CBD high
summary: This article argues against Coca-Cola's potential entry into the cannabis-infused beverage market with Aurora Cannabis, citing legal complexities, potential damage to its family-friendly brand image, and the limited market for CBD products.
