The author suggests that Coca-Cola's existing strategies for health-conscious consumers are already effective and a CBD venture would introduce unnecessary risks and global brand implications.

title: Warren Buffett Bids Farewell to Walmart After 20 Years as Amazon Reigns
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. has sold its remaining shares in Walmart Inc., ending a more than two-decade relationship. This divestment comes as Amazon.com's growing dominance has prompted Berkshire to reduce its stake in the world’s largest retailer. Walmart shares have seen a much smaller increase this year compared to Amazon's significant boost, highlighting the changing landscape of the retail sector.

title: GE Renewable Energy & YPF Luz to build 122-MW wind farm in Argentina
summary: YPF Luz has partnered with GE Renewable Energy to construct the 122-MW Los Teros Wind Farm in Azul, Province of Buenos Aires, Argentina, with construction starting in November. This $144 million project will utilize 32 GE wind turbines and aims to provide renewable energy to customers like Toyota and Coca-Cola FEMSA through the Wholesale Electricity Market. Los Teros will be GE's first turnkey wind farm in Argentina and is expected to significantly reduce CO2 emissions.

title: How Coke Consolidated grew from small distributor to powerhouse — and what's ahead for the Charlotte company
summary: This article details the growth of Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Consolidated from a small distributor to a major powerhouse expecting to approach $5 billion in annual revenue. It highlights the company's significant presence in Charlotte with 2,000 employees and five facilities, and introduces key leadership including Dave Katz and J. Frank Harrison III.

title: John John Florence sues Monster Energy
summary: Two-time World Surf League champion John John Florence is suing Monster Energy for breach of a three-year sponsorship agreement worth $500,000 annually. Florence alleges Monster Energy used his image without payment, while Monster claims Florence hid "material facts" during negotiations. The lawsuit highlights the increasing presence of energy drink companies like Monster and Red Bull as major sponsors in professional surfing.

title: Coca-Cola to boost its caffeine rush with first Coke-branded energy drinks
summary: Coca-Cola is planning to launch its first Coke-branded energy drinks, "Coca-Cola Energy" and "Coca-Cola Energy No Sugar", which will contain naturally-derived caffeine and guarana extract. This move follows Coca-Cola's recent acquisition of Costa Coffee and the introduction of a "Supersoda" in the Philippines, signaling a strong push into the caffeine market. The decision to enter the energy drink sector, however, has led to arbitration with Monster Beverage Corp., in which Coca-Cola holds a significant stake, over potential violations of a 2015 agreement.

title: Monster Beverage’s dispute with Coke will weigh on shares for some time, analysts say
summary: Analysts predict that a dispute between Monster Beverage Corp. and Coca-Cola Co. will negatively impact Monster's shares for the foreseeable future. The disagreement arose over Coca-Cola's plan to launch energy-like drinks, a move Monster contends violates their strategic partnership. The matter has been sent to arbitration, with Coca-Cola delaying its new drink launches until April 2019.

title: Coca-Cola plans to launch energy drinks for the first time
summary: Coca-Cola is planning to launch its first line of energy drinks called "Coca-Cola Energy," which will feature "naturally-derived caffeine and guarana extract," including a sugar-free option. The launch is awaiting resolution of an arbitration filed with Monster Energy, with whom Coke partnered in 2015. The move comes as Coca-Cola increases its bet on the growing energy-drink market, despite previous concerns about highly-caffeinated beverages.

title: Coca-Cola in fight with Monster over new energy drinks
summary: Coca-Cola plans to launch new "Coca-Cola Energy" drinks, leading to a dispute with Monster Beverage, in which Coca-Cola acquired a 16.7% stake for $2.15 billion in 2015. Monster claims these new products violate their agreement, which banned Coca-Cola from distributing other energy drinks with an exception for Coke-branded items. The issue is currently in arbitration, causing Monster's shares to fall and raising questions about Coca-Cola's future acquisition interest in Monster.

title: Coca-Cola plans first Coke-branded energy drinks in a crowded field
summary: Coca-Cola Co is preparing to launch its first energy drinks under the Coke brand name, "Coca-Cola Energy" and "Coca-Cola Energy No Sugar", entering a competitive market. This move could put it in direct competition with Monster Beverage Corp, in which Coke holds a significant stake, leading to an arbitration over a potential violation of their 2015 agreement. Analysts are skeptical about consumers accepting an energy drink under the traditional Coke brand.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper sales surge as soda growth offsets slowdown in coffee
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper reported strong third-quarter sales of $2.86 billion, a 2.9% increase, primarily driven by robust soda sales which offset a slowdown in its coffee division. This was the first earnings report since the merger of Keurig and Dr Pepper, highlighting the benefits of a diverse beverage portfolio. The company continues to expand its offerings through acquisitions and partnerships to cater to evolving consumer demands.

title: Is ‘Zero’ Generic or Descriptive? Coca-Cola Loses Battle on Appeal to Federal Circuit
summary: The Federal Circuit Court ruled against Coca-Cola in its trademark dispute over the term "ZERO" used in products like Coke Zero, stating the Trademark Trial and Appeal Board (TTAB) applied the wrong test. The case is remanded to the TTAB to determine if "ZERO" is generic or descriptive for soft drinks with few or no calories, carbohydrates, or sugar, and whether it has acquired distinctiveness. This decision highlights the importance of consumer understanding in determining trademark genericness and the high standard for proving acquired distinctiveness for descriptive marks.

title: Coca-Cola launches Global Ventures group to integrate acquisitions
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. has established a new Global Ventures group to better integrate its acquisitions, investments, and partnerships, led by Jennifer Mann. This initiative follows major deals like the $5.1 billion acquisition of Costa Coffee and a minority stake in BodyArmor, aligning with Coca-Cola's strategy to become a "total beverage company" beyond sugary soft drinks. The group will focus on maximizing value from existing acquisitions and identifying new growth opportunities, with a systematic M&A accountability process to evaluate performance.

title: Las empresas de la Bolsa viven un octubre lleno de horror
summary: October has been a horrific month for companies on the Mexican Stock Exchange (BMV), with its main index, the IPC, falling 11%, its worst monthly performance since January 2009. Companies like Cemex, OMA, and Genomma Lab saw their stock prices drop by around 20%. This downturn is attributed to global economic fears, US-China trade tensions, anticipated interest rate hikes in the US, and specifically, the cancellation of the new Texcoco airport project in Mexico.

title: Coca-Cola income surges amid strong demand for soda
summary: Coca-Cola reported a surge in net income and strong organic growth in the third quarter of 2018, driven by robust demand for soda and successful portfolio transformation efforts. Despite a decline in net revenues due to refranchising, the company exceeded analyst expectations and saw strong performance in low- and no-calorie offerings, as well as continued expansion into new beverage categories like coffee. CEO James Quincey emphasized the company's evolution into a consumer-centric, total beverage company, while confirming no current plans to enter the cannabis sector.

title: CVS expands Hispanic-focused stores to Texas, including two in SA metro
summary: CVS is expanding its "pharmacy y más" concept stores, which cater to the Hispanic community, into Texas, including two locations in the San Antonio metropolitan area. These stores offer fully bilingual staff and signage, and more than 1,500 popular Hispanic products from various brands. The expansion aims to serve the growing Hispanic market in the region.

title: The CEO of LaCroix infuses his corporate messages with a subtle essence of conservatism
summary: This article reveals how Nick A. Caporella, CEO of National Beverage Corp. (maker of LaCroix), infuses his corporate messages with conservative political commentary, including critiques of former President Barack Obama and support for President Donald Trump. His investor reports often contain cryptic, capitalized declarations that merge spiritual guidance with business success, and he has used corporate statements to subtly express political views on national issues and legal challenges facing his company. The piece highlights specific examples of his political "poetry" dating back to 2009.

title: Kraft Heinz to sell part of India business for about $630 million
summary: Kraft Heinz Co is selling a part of its Indian business, including popular brands like Complan and Glucon-D, for 45.95 billion rupees ($627.18 million) to Zydus Wellness Ltd and Cadila Healthcare Ltd. This move comes as Indian consumers increasingly seek healthier, sugar-free alternatives and aligns with Kraft Heinz's strategy to focus on its core categories globally. The deal will boost Zydus's annual revenue and expand its portfolio in the health-food and nutrition segment, while Kraft Heinz will continue to grow its Heinz sauces and other businesses in India.

title: Kraft Heinz to sell part of India business for about $630 million | Business News
summary: Kraft Heinz announced the sale of a portion of its Indian business, including popular brands like Complan and Glucon-D, for approximately $627.18 million to Zydus Wellness Ltd and Cadila Healthcare Ltd. This strategic move aligns with Kraft Heinz's global growth strategy to focus on core categories, while Zydus expands its health-food and nutrition portfolio with these new acquisitions. The deal highlights a shift in consumer demand towards healthier, sugar-free alternatives in the Indian market.

title: Out of boxes! Colgate-Palmolive suspends operations in Venezuela
summary: Colgate-Palmolive has suspended operations at one of its five factories in Venezuela due to a lack of cardboard for packaging, following the Venezuelan government's expropriation of Smurfit Kappa, the cardboard supplier. This action is part of a larger trend of company closures and production cuts in Venezuela, including Kimberly-Clark and Kellogg's, caused by the country's severe economic crisis and government policies. Mexican bottler Coca-Cola Femsa is also considering significant layoffs and production scale-backs in response to the challenging market conditions.

title: Global survey reveals FMCG companies’ contribution to plastic pollution crisis
summary: A Greenpeace International survey reveals that fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) corporations are major contributors to the plastic pollution crisis, with none planning to reduce single-use plastic production. The report highlights a lack of transparency and commitment from these companies to move away from single-use packaging, instead focusing on recycling solutions that perpetuate the problem. The survey focused on 11 major FMCG companies, including Coca-Cola, PepsiCo, and Nestlé, finding that most are increasing their single-use plastic output.

title: Coca-Cola FEMSA adecuará sus operaciones en Venezuela debido a la crisis
summary: Coca-Cola FEMSA announced plans to "adapt" its operations in Venezuela due to the country's severe economic crisis and hyperinflation, which are impacting production and consumption. This adaptation may include a significant reduction of personnel, with a union leader stating the company indicated a need to cut over 40% of its workforce. The company is in talks with authorities and employees to revise production to suit the current market while reaffirming its commitment to continue operating in Venezuela.

title: Coca-Cola building CIO role with more power, influence
summary: The Coca-Cola Company is expanding the responsibilities of its CIO, Barry Simpson, effective January 1, 2019, by adding the Enabling Services organization to his purview. This move is part of a broader C-suite reshuffle aimed at increasing the CIO's influence and focusing on digital transformation amidst lagging sugary beverage demand. The enhanced role reflects Coca-Cola's investment in technology and its push towards a digital future, including e-commerce experiments.

title: Coca-Cola Makes Leadership Changes
summary: Coca-Cola has announced several top leadership changes, including naming Brian Smith as the new president and chief operating officer. John Murphy will succeed Kathy Waller as executive vice president and CFO, while Nancy Quan was appointed senior vice president and chief technical officer. Additionally, Barry Simpson will expand his duties to become senior vice president and chief information and integrated services officer.

title: Globe Chocolate Craze Hershey's to Send Kisses to India Now
summary: Hershey's is expanding its global presence by introducing its Kisses chocolate brand to the Indian market. The company plans to invest around $50 million over the next five years in India, focusing initially on metropolitan areas and leveraging the festive season for sales. Despite competition from established brands, Hershey's aims to capture a share of the growing Indian chocolate market by offering Milk Chocolate, Almonds, and Cookies and Cream variants of Kisses.

title: Is Coca-Cola really putting pot in its beverages?
summary: This article addresses the widespread rumor that Coca-Cola is adding marijuana to its beverages, clarifying that the company is only exploring non-psychoactive CBD as an ingredient in "functional wellness beverages." It explains what CBD is, its legal status, and its purported health benefits, most of which remain unproven by robust scientific evidence. The author also discusses the broader trend of CBD and potentially marijuana entering the mainstream food and beverage market, urging for more research into its risks and benefits.

title: New Salsa on the Block
summary: Herdez® Guacamole Salsa, a product of MegaMex Foods (a joint venture between Hormel Foods and Herdez del Fuerte, S.A. de C.V.), received the GMA's 2018 Award for Innovation and Creativity. The salsa has seen sales skyrocket, surpassing initial goals by 199 percent and continues to grow rapidly. Its success is attributed to its delicious blend of avocados, tomatillos, and jalapenos, and its appeal to a growing market of Mexican food lovers, including millennials.

title: GE, IBM Brand Values Take Big Hits
summary: The brand values of IBM and GE experienced significant drops in Interbrand's 2018 Best Global Brands study, contrasting with the overall trend of rising brand values. GE's brand value fell by 26% to $33 billion, while IBM's decreased by 8% to $43 billion, reflecting troubles in their respective businesses. Other prominent brands like Coca-Cola, Oracle, Zara, Ikea, Gillette, H&M, and eBay also saw declines in their brand valuations.

title: FEMSA COCA COLA REALIZA AUDITORÍA AMBIENTAL PARA SU CERTIFICACIÓN, EN TABASCO
summary: The Federal Attorney for Environmental Protection (PROFEPA) participated in an environmental audit for Inmuebles del Golfo de R.L. de C.V., a FEMSA Coca-Cola entity, in Tabasco, Mexico. This audit aims for the company to achieve certification within the National Environmental Audit Program (PNAA) by making necessary modifications to comply with environmental legislation. The company is committed to improving waste management, reducing water consumption, treating wastewater, and preventing soil contamination.

title: Coca-Cola takes 45% minority interest in Australian beverage company Made Group
summary: Coca-Cola Amatil and The Coca-Cola Company have jointly acquired a 45% minority interest in Australia's Made Group. Made Group, known for brands like Cocobella and Impressed, will continue to operate independently while leveraging Coca-Cola's market reach and distribution. This follows other recent Coca-Cola acquisitions in the kombucha and craft beer categories.

title: Ex-NBA player Bridgeman ups his game with acquisition of Coca-Cola's Canadian bottling ops
summary: Former NBA player Junior Bridgeman, who already owns a Coca-Cola bottling operation in Lenexa, has expanded his business. Teaming with Canadian businessman Larry Tanenbaum, Bridgeman acquired Coca-Cola Refreshments Canada from The Coca-Cola Co. This acquisition signifies a significant expansion of Bridgeman's bottling empire.

title: Coca-Cola invests in Australian beverage brand, continuing health push
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. is investing in an Australian beverage brand, continuing its push into healthier drink options due to decreasing soda sales. This move is part of a series of investments Coca-Cola has made to expand its beverage portfolio beyond traditional sugary drinks.

title: Coca-Cola concreta compra de Guallarauco al grupo Angelini por cerca de US$70 millones
summary: Coca-Cola del Valle New Ventures, a joint venture of Coca-Cola de Chile, Embotelladora Andina, and Embonor, finalized the acquisition of 100% of Novaverde, the producer of the Guallarauco brand, from Inversiones Siemel (controlled by the Angelini group) for approximately US$70 million. The transaction received unconditional approval from the Fiscalía Nacional Económica (FNE) in July, as it was deemed not to substantially affect competition. The ownership structure of Novaverde after the sale now primarily vests in Coca-Cola del Valle New Ventures, with indirect ownership distributed among Coca-Cola de Chile (50%), Embotelladora Andina (35%), and Embonor (15%).

title: B.C. companies in global race to perfect cannabis-infused beverage technology
summary: B.C. companies like Tilray, Ascent Industries Corp., Emerald Health Therapeutics, and Chemesis International Inc. are actively researching and developing technology to infuse beverages with cannabis. This pursuit is driven by the declining sales of traditional sodas and beers, the surge in legal marijuana sales, and partnerships between beverage makers and cannabis companies. Key challenges include making cannabinoids water-soluble and overcoming the unpleasant taste associated with them.

title: Keurig Dr. Pepper makes premium water play with $525m acquisition of CORE Nutrition
summary: Keurig Dr. Pepper (KDP) has acquired CORE Nutrition for $525 million, marking a significant entry into the premium water category. This acquisition fills a gap in KDP's portfolio and capitalizes on CORE's rapid growth and strong brand appeal, despite some concerns from analysts regarding allied brand relationships post-merger. The deal is expected to close by the end of 2018 and be accretive to KDP's EPS in 2020 and beyond.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper to buy premium water brand CORE Nutrition for $525M
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper is set to acquire premium water brand CORE Nutrition for $525 million, a move that expands its portfolio into healthier beverages following its merger. This acquisition, which includes CORE Hydration and CORE Organic, strengthens Keurig Dr Pepper's position in the growing bottled water market and puts it in direct competition with PepsiCo and Coca-Cola who are also investing heavily in healthier alternatives. The deal is expected to close by the end of the year, further integrating CORE into KDP's distribution network.

title: How a Lawsuit Against Coca-Cola Convinced Americans to Love Caffeine
summary: In 1909, the federal government sued Coca-Cola over its use of caffeine, which it labeled a "risky stimulant," leading to the landmark 1911 trial of United States vs. Forty Barrels and Twenty Kegs of Coca Cola. This case, and the scientific testimony within it, particularly the research by psychologist Harry Hollingworth, played a pivotal role in shaping public perception of caffeine, ultimately helping to establish it as a widely accepted pick-me-up in America. Despite the initial legal challenges and the eventual settlement that reduced caffeine levels in Coca-Cola, the trial's outcome inadvertently burnished caffeine's reputation, paving the way for its integration into the daily lives of Americans.

title: Coca-Cola Gets into the Kombucha Trade
summary: Coca-Cola Australia has acquired Organic & Raw Trading Co., the producer of the Mojo kombucha brand, marking Coca-Cola's entry into Australia's fast-growing kombucha market. The acquisition highlights a trend of major beverage companies investing in the health-conscious drink category, following similar moves by Lion and PepsiCo. Kombucha sales are booming globally, with projections for significant market growth by 2025.

title: Two Big Reasons Why I Believe China Looks Attractive Right Now
summary: Frank Holmes discusses two main reasons why China presents an attractive investment opportunity despite recent trade tensions. He highlights the compelling demographics, particularly the large millennial population in Asia, and ongoing financial reforms aimed at opening up capital markets to foreign investors. Holmes suggests that the recent selloff in emerging markets, especially Chinese equities, is overdone, creating a potential buying opportunity for long-term investors.

title: Coca-Cola to break ground on $250M Houston plant
summary: Coca-Cola Southwest is set to break ground on a $250 million manufacturing and distribution plant in north Houston, a significant investment despite declining soda sales. The 1 million-square-foot facility, slated for completion in Q1 2020, will consolidate existing operations and serve the local market with sparkling drinks and Dasani water. This move reflects Coca-Cola's strategy to diversify its beverage portfolio towards healthier options like water and teas.

title: Coca-Cola buying frenzy continues with French juice company Tropico S.A.S
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. is expanding its portfolio by acquiring Tropico S.A.S, a French juice company. This acquisition aligns with Coca-Cola's strategic goal of becoming a significant player in the still fruit-flavored beverage sector. Tropico, founded in 1982, offers products in cans and PET bottles, bolstering Coca-Cola's presence in the non-alcoholic beverage market.

title: Adobe, Microsoft and SAP announce the Open Data Initiative to empower a new generation of customer experiences
summary: Adobe, Microsoft, and SAP have announced the Open Data Initiative to help companies gain a single, comprehensive view of their customer data. This collaboration aims to eliminate data silos, enabling businesses to leverage AI and advanced analytics for real-time insights and to deliver personalized customer experiences. The initiative enhances interoperability between their platforms and includes a common data model based on Microsoft Azure.

title: Coca-Cola Is Eyeing a Possible Entry Into the Cannabis Market
authors: Jen Skerritt and Craig Giammona / Bloomberg
summary: Coca-Cola is exploring the cannabis drinks market and is reportedly in talks with Canadian producer Aurora Cannabis to develop CBD-infused beverages. This move comes as beverage companies seek new growth opportunities amid slowing traditional sales, with other major players like Constellation Brands and Molson Coors also investing in the cannabis sector. The discussions focus on non-psychoactive CBD to ease pain, inflammation, and cramping.

title: Coca-Cola enters kombucha category with acquisition of Organic and Raw Trading Co
summary: The Coca-Cola Company has acquired Australia's Organic & Raw Trading Co., producer of the MOJO brand of kombucha, marking its first full ownership acquisition in the kombucha category. This move positions Coca-Cola Australia to lead in the emerging premium-probiotic kombucha sector, aligning with consumer demand for low-sugar, functional beverages. The acquisition's value was not disclosed, and MOJO's co-founder and CEO will remain in their roles.

title: Pot stock Aurora says there's no agreement with Coca-Cola, but the shares are rising anyway
summary: Aurora Cannabis stated it has no formal agreement with a beverage company despite engaging in exploratory discussions, yet its stock rallied significantly. This surge followed reports that Coca-Cola was in talks with Aurora to develop weed-infused beverages, a claim Coca-Cola denied, stating they are only watching the non-psychoactive CBD market.

title: Coca-Cola signs 10-year contract with the University of Alabama
summary: The University of Alabama and The Coca-Cola Co. signed a 10-year contract in July, making Coca-Cola the exclusive beverage provider for both campus and athletics programs for $2 million annually. This deal includes new vending machines, beverage options in dining halls, and academic and career opportunities for students such as internships and scholarships. Coca-Cola also created five new job titles in Tuscaloosa to support the partnership and benefit the community.

title: Coca-Cola Is Eyeing the Cannabis Market
summary: Coca-Cola is exploring the cannabis-infused beverage market and is reportedly in discussions with Canadian producer Aurora Cannabis. This move comes as beverage companies look to new product categories amid slowing traditional sales, with Coca-Cola specifically interested in drinks containing CBD, the non-psychoactive component of cannabis.

title: Coca-Cola eyes CBD ‘functional wellness beverages’ as soda market cools
summary: Coca-Cola is exploring the development of CBD-infused "functional wellness beverages" as the traditional soda market experiences a decline. This move follows other beverage companies' interest in cannabis partnerships, particularly in Canada, and is spurred by falling prices of water-soluble CBD isolate. No final decisions have been made by Coca-Cola, though they are reportedly in talks with Aurora Cannabis.

title: Coca-Cola pone U$S 11 millones en Córdoba para crecer con latas
summary: Coca-Cola Andina is investing $11 million in a new can production line at its plant near Malvinas Argentinas, Córdoba, Argentina. This expansion will allow the company to produce 55 million liters of soda annually for both local and export markets, strengthening its strategy of diverse packaging options. The investment is part of a larger national plan by Coca-Cola Argentina and will make the Córdoba plant Argentina's only inland facility for canning beverages.

title: Prologis buys 10-acre Pepsi plant near Mount Baker light rail station
summary: Logistics company Prologis has acquired a 10-acre Pepsi plant situated near the Mount Baker light rail station in Seattle. This purchase aligns with Prologis' strategy to address Amazon.com's increasing demand for in-city distribution space. The acquisition is part of a broader trend of Prologis buying commercial properties with a focus on "last mile" logistics.

title: Just a Kiss Away: Saving the Environment with worldsteel Campaign
summary: The worldsteel association has launched the "#LOVESTEEL" campaign to promote steel beverage cans, highlighting their improved strength, lightness, and various design possibilities. The campaign emphasizes steel's environmental benefits, including its 100% recyclability and significant energy and CO2 savings compared to aluminum. Major steel companies like POSCO and Tata Steel support this initiative, which encourages consumers to choose steel packaging for a more sustainable future.

title: Coca-Cola makes a $5.1-billion bet on the coffee market
summary: Coca-Cola is acquiring British coffee chain Costa for $5.1 billion, marking its largest acquisition in eight years and a significant diversification into the coffee market. This move aims to expand Coca-Cola's growth beyond sugary beverages and compete in the highly fragmented hot beverages sector, leveraging Costa's global presence and retail platform. The acquisition comes as rivals like PepsiCo, Nestle, and JAB also make strategic moves in the evolving beverage industry.

title: Coca-Cola buys Costa Coffee from Whitbread for £3.9bn
summary: Coca-Cola is acquiring the Costa Coffee chain from Whitbread for nearly £4bn, marking its entry into the rapidly growing global coffee market. This acquisition will make Coca-Cola the UK's largest coffee shop player and diversify its portfolio away from sugary soft drinks. The deal highlights a trend of beverage manufacturers adapting to changing consumer preferences.

title: Coca-Cola buys Costa Coffee, British cafe chain, for $5.1 billion
summary: Coca-Cola announced its acquisition of Costa Coffee from British firm Whitbread for 3.9 billion pounds ($5.1 billion) in cash. This deal marks Coca-Cola's entry into the hot beverages market, filling a significant gap in its portfolio and potentially creating stiff competition for Starbucks. Whitbread's shareholders saw a substantial return, with the company's share price soaring 16 percent following the announcement.

title: Coca-Cola buys Costa Coffee for $5.1B
summary: Coca-Cola announced its acquisition of Costa Coffee from Whitbread for £3.9 billion ($5.1 billion), marking its entry into the rapidly growing coffee and hot drinks market. This strategic move aims to expand Coca-Cola's portfolio beyond beverages and capitalize on increasing consumer demand for coffee, especially as sugar-conscious consumers move away from traditional sodas. The acquisition is expected to enable Coca-Cola to grow Costa's presence globally, particularly in Europe, Asia Pacific, the Middle East, and Africa, with potential expansion into the U.S.

title: Coca-Cola Bets on Coffee With $5.1 Billion Deal for Costa (Published 2018)
summary: Coca-Cola announced its acquisition of Costa coffee chain for $5.1 billion, marking its largest brand acquisition ever. This strategic move is a response to declining sugary drink consumption and aims to compete in the growing global coffee market against giants like Nestlé and JAB. The deal positions Coca-Cola with the third-largest player in the coffee shop industry.

title: Coca-Cola takes a plunge into coffee with a $5.1 billion Costa deal
summary: Coca-Cola has agreed to acquire the UK coffee chain Costa for $5.1 billion, including debt. This strategic move aims to diversify Coca-Cola's offerings beyond fizzy drinks and expand into the rapidly growing global coffee market, directly competing with companies like Starbucks and Nestle. The deal, which adds Costa's almost 4,000 outlets, was unanimously approved by Whitbread's board, significantly boosting Coca-Cola's presence in the hot beverages sector.

title: The Coca-Cola Company to Acquire Costa
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced its definitive agreement to acquire Costa Limited for $5.1 billion, aiming to establish a strong global coffee platform. This acquisition will expand Coca-Cola's presence in the fast-growing coffee category with nearly 4,000 retail outlets and potential for future growth in multiple channels and formats. The transaction is expected to close in the first half of 2019 and be slightly accretive in the first full year.

title: Coca-Cola acquires Maine soda Moxie
summary: The Coca-Cola Company is set to acquire Moxie, the official soft drink of Maine, US. Moxie, which predates Coca-Cola, is known for its gentian root extract flavor and will become part of Coca-Cola's Venturing and Emerging Brands unit. Distribution will continue through its current bottling partner, Coca-Cola of Northern New England.

title: Coca-Cola’s Got Moxie, the Quirky New England Soda
summary: Coca-Cola announced its acquisition of Moxie, the oldest bottled soft drink in the U.S. and a beloved New England soda. This move aligns with Coca-Cola's strategy to diversify its portfolio with more low and no-sugar options, despite Moxie containing 25 grams of sugar per can. The acquisition aims to leverage Moxie's nostalgic branding and provide resources for its future evolution.

title: Episode #119: Tom Dorsey, Dorsey, Wright & Associates, “Fundamentals Answer the First Question ‘What Should I Buy?’ The Technical Side Answers the Question ‘When?’”
summary: This article features an interview with Tom Dorsey of Dorsey, Wright & Associates, discussing his approach to investing, which emphasizes Point & Figure charting and relative strength. Dorsey explains how fundamentals answer "what to buy," while technical analysis answers "when to buy," stressing the importance of supply and demand. He also touches on smart indexing, the evolution of ETFs, and applying relative strength to cryptocurrencies, highlighting its potential for automated portfolio management.

title: Coca-Cola acquires beloved Maine soda Moxie
summary: Coca-Cola announced its acquisition of Moxie, a historic New England soda brand and Maine's official state beverage. The soft drink, known for its unique polarizing flavor, will continue to be bottled in New Hampshire, with Coca-Cola aiming to preserve its heritage and regional culture while potentially expanding its audience. The acquisition price was not disclosed, and no noticeable changes for consumers are expected.

title: Coca-Cola acquires beloved Maine soda Moxie
summary: Coca-Cola announced its acquisition of Moxie, a long-standing and beloved New England soda brand and the official state beverage of Maine. The acquisition from an independent bottling partner ensures bottling remains in New Hampshire, with Coca-Cola aiming to protect the brand's heritage while potentially bringing it to a wider audience without changing distribution. The sale price was not disclosed, and the acquisition is expected to close in the fourth quarter of the year.

title: Coca-Cola buys Moxie in a bold beverage exit that only took 142 years
summary: Coca-Cola has acquired Moxie, one of the oldest national sodas, for an undisclosed amount, in a move that suggests a possible shift towards niche products or a national push for the beverage. This follows Pepsi's recent acquisition of SodaStream, indicating a trend of large beverage companies buying long-standing fizzy drink brands. Moxie, known for its bitter taste due to gentian root extract, was previously owned by an independent Coca-Cola bottling company.

title: Coca-Cola becomes presenting partner of the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Torch Relay
summary: Coca-Cola, a long-standing Olympic partner since 1928, has announced its partnership with the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Torch Relay through its Japan subsidiary. This marks their 14th Torch Relay involvement, aiming to bring an unforgettable experience to Japan with the theme "Hope Lights Our Way." The relay will commence on March 26, 2020, in Fukushima Prefecture and travel across all 47 prefectures for 121 days.

title: PepsiCo Learned From Coca-Cola’s Soda Flop
summary: PepsiCo's acquisition of SodaStream for $3.2 billion highlights lessons learned from Coca-Cola's failed venture into the home soda-making market with Keurig Green Mountain. Coca-Cola's "Keurig Kold" machine, launched in 2015, proved to be an expensive flop due to high costs, poor performance, and a misalignment with consumer trends toward healthier, lower-sugar beverages. PepsiCo's strategic move with SodaStream, a well-established company aligned with health-conscious trends, demonstrates a different approach to the at-home beverage market.

title: Coca-Cola UK redesigns Zero Sugar packaging to look like the original Coke
summary: Coca-Cola Great Britain is redesigning its Coke Zero Sugar packaging to more closely resemble the original Coca-Cola, featuring the iconic red and white design with a black "zero sugar, no calories" strip. This change, launching in September, is part of a strategy to encourage more consumption of no-sugar drinks, especially as Britain's sugar tax came into effect in April. The company is actively promoting its non-sugar beverage portfolio as part of a "total beverage" strategy.

title: Pepsi’s SodaStream acquisition won’t solve its biggest problem: fewer people are drinking soda
summary: Wells Fargo analysts suggest that PepsiCo's acquisition of SodaStream, while expanding into healthier categories and the at-home beverage market, won't address Pepsi's fundamental issue of declining soda consumption. They draw parallels between this deal and Coke's prior stake in Green Mountain, implying similar outcomes. The core problem remains fewer people drinking soda.

title: Houston: Coca-Cola SW Beverages Bringing 1-Million SF Plant
summary: Coca-Cola Southwest Beverages is constructing a new 1-million-square-foot manufacturing, warehouse, distribution, and sales facility in Houston's Pinto Business Park GP. This $250 million plant, set to open in early 2020, will be the first new Coca-Cola plant in the U.S. in a decade, consolidating existing operations and significantly expanding production capacity. The project involves a large warehouse, processing area, and fleet and recycling buildings, designed by The Haskell Company, with civil engineering by BGE Inc.

title: If Pepsi’s $3 Billion Acquisition of SodaStream Is a Good Idea, Then It’s Really Screwed
summary: PepsiCo announced its acquisition of SodaStream for $3.2 billion, a move that highlights the soda giant's struggle to adapt to changing consumer tastes. While the acquisition reflects PepsiCo's pivot towards healthier options, the article questions the long-term viability of this strategy, suggesting that if SodaStream's model of home-made soda prevails, it could further undermine PepsiCo's core business. The deal is seen as a capstone for departing CEO Indra Nooyi's strategy to diversify PepsiCo beyond sugar-water and snacks.

title: PepsiCo Enhances Healthier Portfolio With SodaStream Acquisition
summary: PepsiCo is set to acquire SodaStream International Ltd. for $3.2 billion, aiming to strengthen its presence in the water and healthier beverage segments and align with its "Performance with Purpose" vision. This acquisition is seen as a strategic move to offer personalized in-home beverage solutions and expand SodaStream's global reach, despite some analyst comparisons to past challenges in the in-home beverage market. The deal, which has been unanimously approved by both companies' boards, is expected to close by January, pending shareholder and regulatory approvals.

title: Americans Spill the Beans About What Really Makes Them Feel Good in McCafé’s Feelin’ Good Summer Survey
summary: A McCafé's Feelin' Good Summer Survey revealed that coffee is a major factor in Americans' summer happiness, often prioritized even over cuddling pets or brushing teeth. The survey coincided with the launch of bottled McCafé Frappés, a ready-to-drink coffee product manufactured and distributed by The Coca-Cola Company. Key findings highlight the pervasive love for coffee across the U.S., with iced coffee being a year-round favorite and a significant "pick-me-up" for many, especially parents.

title: Coca-Cola Buys Stake in Sports Drink Maker Backed by Kobe Bryant
summary: Coca-Cola Co. is buying a minority stake in Bodyarmor, a sports drink company whose investors include Kobe Bryant. This move helps Coca-Cola diversify its product portfolio beyond sugary beverages. Coca-Cola will become the second-largest shareholder behind co-founder Mike Repole, with an option to eventually take control of the company.

title: The Coca-Cola Company and BODYARMOR Announce New Strategic Relationship
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced it is acquiring a minority ownership stake in BODYARMOR, with a path to full ownership. This strategic relationship will provide BODYARMOR access to Coca-Cola's bottling system, accelerating its growth in the sports performance and premium hydration categories. The investment is part of Coca-Cola North America's Venturing and Emerging Brands portfolio, allowing BODYARMOR to operate independently while leveraging Coca-Cola's extensive network.

title: Coca-Cola’s Corporate Greed Is Leaving Mexicans Thirsty
summary: This article criticizes Coca-Cola and the Mexican government for contributing to water scarcity and health problems in Mexico, particularly in Chiapas. It highlights how communities like San Cristóbal de las Casas are dependent on Coca-Cola products due to lack of potable water access, leading to health issues like diabetes. The piece also details the Mexican government's role in exacerbating the crisis through inaction, budget cuts, and policies that seem to favor corporate interests over citizens' access to water.

title: Coca-Cola piloting Swiss sparkling water in Atlanta
summary: Coca-Cola is testing its Valser sparkling water brand, acquired in 2001, in a pilot project in Atlanta to gauge U.S. consumer interest. This initiative is part of Coca-Cola's strategy to expand its sparkling water portfolio and quickly adapt to changing consumer tastes through innovation, including using crowdfunding platforms for market testing. The company has seen success with Topo Chico, another sparkling water acquisition, and continues to add new flavors to existing water brands, highlighting the competitive and growing nature of the bottled water category.

title: 8 Beverage Leadership Moves We're Watching
summary: This article details eight significant leadership changes within the beverage industry, including the departure of PepsiCo CEO Indra Nooyi and the appointment of Ramon Laguarta as her successor. It also covers executive changes at Monster Beverage, Boston Beer, Wine & Spirits Wholesalers of America, Peet's Coffee, Hoist, Celsius Holdings Inc., and Borden Dairy, highlighting key appointments and new roles.

title: MONSTER ENERGY REACHES $1 BILLION IN SALES
summary: Monster Beverage Company announced record quarterly sales, reaching over $1 billion for the first time in its history. The company saw a 12% increase in overall sales to $1.02 billion, with international sales growing by 18.5% due to expansion into new markets like India, Tanzania, Uruguay, and Belarus. Rodney C. Sacks, Chairman and CEO, highlighted the successful launch of the Monster Energy brand with Coca-Cola bottlers in these regions.

title: Barqs Celebrates 120th Anniversary - News & Articles
summary: Barq's, a beloved root beer brand, celebrated its 120th anniversary in 2018, tracing its origins to Edward Barq in New Orleans and Biloxi. Acquired by The Coca-Cola Company in 1995, Barq's maintains strong regional ties, particularly along the Gulf Coast where it is iconic with local cuisine and festivals like Mardi Gras. The brand continues to reinforce its status as a significant cultural staple in the region.

title: Heinz Red Ketchup Packets Set to Get a Green Makeover
summary: The Kraft Heinz Co. has announced plans to make 100 percent of its packaging environmentally sustainable by 2025, aiming for recyclable, reusable, or compostable designs. This initiative will impact products like Heinz ketchup packets, Capri Sun pouches, and Kraft Singles wrappings, which are currently difficult to recycle. The company will partner with experts like Environmental Packaging International to find solutions that balance sustainability with food safety and shelf life requirements.

title: Pepsi's Indra Nooyi latest high-profile female CEO to exit
summary: Indra Nooyi, a prominent female and minority CEO in the Fortune 500, is stepping down as PepsiCo's chief executive after 12 years. She led PepsiCo during a period of changing consumer tastes, emphasizing "good for you" options while retaining traditional products. Ramon Laguarta, a PepsiCo veteran, will succeed her as CEO in October, with Nooyi remaining as chairwoman until early next year.

title: PepsiCo veteran Ramon Laguarta to replace Indra Nooyi as CEO
authors: Siddharth Cavale and Uday Sampath Kumar
summary: Ramon Laguarta has been appointed to succeed Indra Nooyi as CEO of PepsiCo, with his tenure beginning on October 3. Laguarta, a 22-year veteran of the company, will be tasked with navigating changing consumer tastes away from sugary drinks. Nooyi's departure marks a significant leadership change, leaving only a small percentage of female CEOs in Fortune 500 companies.

title: Indra Nooyi, PepsiCo CEO, is stepping down; Ramon Laguarta to take over as CEO in October
summary: Indra Nooyi, the CEO of PepsiCo for 12 years, is stepping down, with Ramon Laguarta set to take over as CEO in October. Nooyi, a rarity as a woman and minority leading a Fortune 100 company, oversaw the company during a period requiring a shake-up of product portfolios to meet healthier consumer choices. Laguarta, who has been with PepsiCo for over two decades, will become the sixth CEO in the company's history.

title: Indra Nooyi, Pepsi’s First Female CEO, Is Stepping Down
summary: Indra Nooyi is stepping down as CEO of PepsiCo Inc. after 12 years, to be succeeded by Ramon Laguarta in October. Her departure reduces the number of female CEOs in S&P 500 companies and comes as Pepsi's North American beverage unit faces stagnation due to declining soda consumption. Nooyi plans to continue advocating for women in executive positions after leaving Pepsi.

title: Longtime PepsiCo CEO Indra Nooyi is Stepping Down
summary: Indra Nooyi, the longtime CEO of PepsiCo, is stepping down after 12 years at the helm and 24 years with the company. During her tenure, she oversaw a period of significant change in the food and beverage industry, pushing PepsiCo to adapt to healthier consumer choices. Ramon Laguarta will succeed her as CEO in October, becoming the sixth CEO in PepsiCo's history and continuing the company's tradition of promoting from within.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Pepsi's first female CEO to end 12-year run, replaced by insider
summary: Indra Nooyi is stepping down as CEO of PepsiCo Inc. after 12 years, to be replaced by Ramon Laguarta. Nooyi, the first foreign-born and female CEO of Pepsi, will remain chairman until early 2019. Her departure highlights the scarcity of female CEOs in corporate America and comes as Pepsi navigates challenges in the North American beverage unit.

title: Woman, minority, trailblazer: Indra Nooyi is leaving Pepsico
summary: Indra Nooyi, a notable woman and minority leader on Wall Street, is stepping down as CEO of PepsiCo after 12 years at the helm and 24 years with the company. During her tenure, Nooyi emphasized "good for you" options and resisted calls to spin off the beverage business. Ramon Laguarta, a long-time PepsiCo executive, will succeed her as CEO in October.

title: Coca-Cola's Asia business isn't expecting any price shocks to its supply chain, executive says
summary: Coca-Cola's Asia Pacific president, John Murphy, stated that the company's Asian market is not expected to face the same cost pressures impacting the U.S. supply chain, particularly regarding aluminum prices. The region also presents significant opportunities for portfolio diversification into products like tea and healthier alternatives, capitalizing on the relatively underdeveloped state of the industry there. Murphy emphasized the stability of aluminum prices for the rest of the year in Asia Pacific, indicating no anticipated pricing changes beyond normal cycles.

title: Coca-Cola results beat on higher Diet Coke, Zero Sugar demand
summary: Coca-Cola Co exceeded Wall Street's quarterly sales and profit estimates, driven by increased demand for its Zero Sugar brand and a new version of Diet Coke. The company's focus on healthier drink options, including new Diet Coke flavors and other product launches, contributed to a 5% rise in organic revenue and a 2% volume growth. Despite North American sales slightly missing estimates, Coca-Cola reaffirmed its 2018 profit outlook.

title: Coca-Cola CEO says company sees cost pressures from Trump's tariffs
summary: Coca-Cola CEO James Quincey stated the company is experiencing cost pressures due to President Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum, leading to price increases in sparkling beverages. Despite these challenges, Quincey noted that Coca-Cola's local production model might offer a slight advantage. The comments followed Coca-Cola's better-than-expected second-quarter earnings.

title: The Coca-Cola Company Reports Continued Strong Results in Second Quarter 2018
summary: The Coca-Cola Company (KO) reported strong continued results in Q2 2018, with organic revenues growing 5% despite an 8% decline in net revenues impacted by bottler refranchising. The company saw operating margin expansion of over 950 basis points and a 68% increase in earnings per share from continuing operations. Coca-Cola outlined its strategies for accelerating growth, including product innovation, reducing sugar content, digitizing operations, and committing to sustainability.

title: Coke Raising U.S. Soda Prices, Citing Tariffs
summary: Coca-Cola Co. is raising prices on its carbonated soft drinks in North America due to increased costs, including higher freight rates and metal prices, following U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports. This comes as the company reported rising drink volumes and a profit of $2.3 billion in its latest quarter.

title: Coca-Cola could be causing a diabetes epidemic in the Mexican town of San Cristobal
summary: Residents of San Cristóbal de las Casas, Mexico, are experiencing a severe diabetes epidemic and chronic water shortage, for which many blame a local Coca-Cola bottling plant. The plant, run by FEMSA, extracts over 300,000 gallons of water daily, while local infrastructure crumbles and residents frequently lack potable water, leading them to consume excessive amounts of Coca-Cola. This situation has sparked protests and highlights deeper issues of public health, water rights, and the impact of multinational corporations in developing regions.

title: HP Collaborates with Coca-Cola to Reinvent Relations
summary: HP Inc. partnered with Coca-Cola to bring the "Share a Coke" campaign to India, aiming to enhance personal engagement with consumers and celebrate relationships. The initiative uses HP Indigo digital printing to produce Coke cans and bottles with 20 special relationships printed in 12 languages. This collaboration highlights the growing trend of personalized marketing and the importance of unique packaging in consumer engagement.

title: José “Pepe” Martinez Joins IDC’s Board of Directors
summary: International Dispensing Corporation (IDC) announced that José “Pepe” Martinez, a former executive at The Coca-Cola Company, has joined its Board of Directors. Martinez's extensive experience in global supply chain management and the food and beverage industry, particularly with Coca-Cola's global system, is expected to significantly contribute to IDC's growth. IDC is known for its aseptic tap technology, The Answer®, which allows for the safe dispensing of UHT liquids without refrigeration.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper's first week post-merger brings a defection, an acquisition and new volleys in coffee wars
summary: In its first week post-merger, Keurig Dr Pepper experienced significant changes, including Fiji Water's departure from its distribution network and the acquisition of Big Red soda. The company also announced new coffee partnerships, highlighting the dynamic shifts within the beverage industry following the creation of this new giant. These events underscore the challenges and opportunities for Keurig Dr Pepper's "Allied Brands" strategy.

title: PepsiCo's beverage sales dip, but snack sales increase
summary: PepsiCo reported a dip in North American beverage sales volume in the second quarter despite efforts to introduce new drinks. However, higher sales from its Frito-Lay snack division helped to offset this weakness. The company's profit was impacted by a higher tax rate, though earnings per share exceeded Wall Street expectations.

title: University of Alabama and Coca-Cola Seal Refreshing Deal on Campus
summary: The University of Alabama and Coca-Cola Bottling Company United, Inc. have signed a multi-year exclusive beverage provider contract for the campus, effective July 1, 2018. This deal includes support for student scholarships, academic programs, and campus improvements, and marks the first time in two decades that the same beverage partner will serve both the university campus and its athletics program. The partnership also involves customized marketing initiatives and the provision of various Coca-Cola brands, with updated vending technology for cashless purchases.

title: Coca Cola FEMSA compra Monresa en uno de los mayores M&A de Uruguay
summary: Coca Cola FEMSA acquired Montevideo Refrescos S.R.L. (Monresa), the Uruguayan subsidiary of Coca Cola, for USD 250.7 million. This transaction represents one of the largest mergers and acquisitions in Uruguay's history. With this acquisition, Coca Cola FEMSA expands its presence and distribution network in Latin America, adding 3.4 million consumers and 26,000 points of sale in Uruguay.

title: FNE autoriza que Coca Cola compre el 100% de Guallarauco
summary: Chile's National Economic Prosecutor (FNE) has authorized Coca-Cola, Embotelladora Andina, and Embonor to acquire 100% of Comercializadora Novaverde SA, the company behind the Guallarauco brand. The transaction, valued at approximately US$79.23 million, is for Novaverde, which belongs to the Angelini group, and it includes an agreement to acquire the remaining stake from the Piwonka family. The FNE found that the operation would not pose anticompetitive risks, as it implies minimal changes in market concentration.

title: Coca-Cola to invest in, expand Cincinnati operations (Video)
summary: Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Consolidated is planning significant investments and expansions in the Cincinnati area. This move includes building a sales and distribution center in Northern Kentucky and making further investments on the Ohio side of the river. This expansion builds on previous announcements regarding Coca-Cola's operations in the region.

title: Coca-Cola FEMSA compra embotelladora en Uruguay
summary: Coca-Cola FEMSA anunció la adquisición de Montevideo Refrescos, la subsidiaria uruguaya de Coca-Cola, por 250.7 millones de dólares en efectivo. Esta compra expande la presencia de Coca-Cola FEMSA a 11 países y consolida su liderazgo en el mercado global de bebidas. Montevideo Refrescos es el productor y distribuidor exclusivo de bebidas Coca-Cola en Uruguay, sirviendo a 3.4 millones de consumidores.

title: Coca-Cola Turkey Plays Up Summer Vibe On Cans With Thermochromic Color-Changing Inks
summary: Coca-Cola Turkey partnered with Crown Holdings Inc. to launch 10 new aluminum beverage can designs featuring thermochromic color-changing inks for a summer campaign. For the first time, four separate thermochromic inks were used as a decorative tool, creating colorful patterns representing summer themes that appear when the cans are chilled. The campaign aims to enhance consumer interaction and highlight the freshness and fun of the drinks, with 70 million units projected to be produced in 2018.

title: Historian swore he'd never leave Coca-Cola — then Ford called
summary: Ford Motor Co. has hired Ted Ryan, Coca-Cola's former image historian, to sculpt Ford's story and reframe public perception of the automaker. Ryan, who previously stated he would never leave Coca-Cola after 21 years, was drawn to Ford's rich history and will focus on preserving and activating its legacy in a meaningful way to help the business. The move is part of Ford's strategy to leverage its heritage to build reputation and connect past innovations with its future in mobility.

title: Success of The Coca-Cola Company, Bambi Concern and Ahold Delhaize campaigns at the second Effie Awards Serbia
summary: McCann Beograd and UM Beograd achieved significant success at the second Effie Awards Serbia, with campaigns for The Coca-Cola Company and Concern Bambi winning Bronze awards for effectiveness. The Ahold Delhaize campaign for Maxi also reached the finals. This success underscores the value of effective creative approaches and client-agency partnerships in driving business results and increasing market share.

title: Hit By The Realities Of The Tax Act, H&R Block Closing 400 Offices 06/14/2018
summary: H&R Block is closing approximately 400 company-owned retail locations and anticipates a revenue drop in fiscal 2019 due to the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. The company's shares plunged 18% following fiscal 2018 earnings, which also revealed an increase in revenues driven by assisted and do-it-yourself businesses. H&R Block aims to modernize its brand and become a cross-channel player to compete with digital solutions like TurboTax.

title: Coke, Pepsi pour more money into Initiative 1634; measure now has $2.9 million behind it
summary: Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Dr Pepper Snapple Group, and Red Bull have collectively poured $2.9 million into Initiative 1634 in Washington State. This measure aims to prevent local jurisdictions from levying taxes on sugary beverages, exempting only Seattle. The campaign, marketed as "Yes for Affordable Groceries," is predicted by NPI to receive significantly more funding from "Big Soda" as it moves towards the November ballot.

title: Amazon is getting ready to crush LaCroix
summary: Amazon and Whole Foods are challenging popular seltzer brand LaCroix by offering steep discounts on their private label 365 Everyday Value sparkling water, particularly targeting Amazon Prime members. This move is part of Amazon's strategy to leverage Whole Foods to compete with major consumer-packaged goods brands. The article also highlights the growing sparkling water market and other competitors like Pepsi's Bubly and Coca-Cola's various brands.

title: The Coca-Cola ad that changed a marketing exec's entire career
summary: Jonathan Mildenhall's career was profoundly influenced by an early interracial Coca-Cola ad from 1969. This ad, created after significant racial tensions in the US, inspired his "Superbrand Formula" focusing on purpose-driven marketing and universal ideology. Mildenhall, now Co-Founder and CEO of TwentyFirstCenturyBrand, highlighted how this ethos guided his work, including a response to racial bias at Airbnb.

title: How Coke Spun the Public on its Water Use
summary: This investigation reveals that Coca-Cola significantly exaggerates its water conservation efforts, despite claiming to return as much water as it uses. The company's "water neutral" pledge focuses primarily on operational water, largely ignoring the vast amounts consumed in its supply chain, particularly for agricultural ingredients. Critics argue that many of the company's offset projects are questionable in their environmental benefit and serve commercial interests, while scientists have raised doubts about the credibility of Coca-Cola's water accounting methods.

title: Adobe to buy Magento Commerce for $1.68 billion
summary: Adobe Systems Inc announced its acquisition of e-commerce services provider Magento Commerce from Permira for $1.68 billion in cash, marking its largest deal in nearly a decade. This move aims to strengthen Adobe's Experience Cloud business, which offers analytics, advertising, and marketing services. Following the announcement, Adobe's shares rose, and the company also declared a stock buyback program of up to $8 billion through fiscal year 2021.

title: Campbell Soup CEO out, steel tariffs to bite soon
summary: Denise Morrison, CEO of Campbell Soup since 2011, is retiring and will be replaced by interim CEO Keith McLoughlin. The company is undergoing a strategic review as it faces declining sales, rising costs, and the impact of steel and aluminum tariffs. Campbell's also reported a third-quarter loss and lowered its full-year earnings projections.

title: The Jolly Green Giant will soon tower over Times Square
summary: B&G Foods is set to unveil two 90-foot-tall LED displays of the Jolly Green Giant in Times Square, replacing Budweiser's former ad space. This move is part of B&G Foods' strategy to reintroduce and reinvent the iconic Green Giant brand to a new generation of consumers, following a marketing push that has already resulted in significant sales increases for Green Giant frozen foods. The advertising displays represent a substantial investment, estimated at over $4 million annually, highlighting the brand's commitment to high-visibility marketing.

title: Monster Beverage’s sales and profit surge, but margin pressures haunt outlook
summary: Monster Beverage saw strong sales and profit growth in the first quarter of 2018, driven by international expansion and the Monster Energy brand. However, the company is facing concerns about future margin pressures due to higher input costs for aluminum, fuel, and freight, raising questions about its ability to pass these costs on to consumers. Analysts have expressed disappointment and are watching the situation closely given rising gas prices and their impact on convenience store shoppers.

title: How Coca-Cola Adds Fizz to its Digital Experiences
summary: This article explores how Coca-Cola is leading the way in creating digital experiences that mirror the physical enjoyment of its products, aiming for "digital fizz." It highlights Coca-Cola's innovative approach, particularly with its Freestyle vending machines, which allow for personalized drink creation and gather consumer data. The company's strategy involves integrating digital and physical experiences to maintain a seamless connection with consumers and maximize customer engagement.

title: Rafael BUSTOS Obituary (2018) - Atlanta, FL - Atlanta Journal-Constitution
summary: Rafael Thomas Bustos III, 86, passed away on April 5, 2018, in Canton, GA. He was an accomplished industrial designer, holding hundreds of patents, and a Senior Vice President at Leggett & Platt Inc. Rafael was also a US Navy veteran, a Georgia Tech graduate, and later in life, an avid painter and lover of arts.

title: Now Boarding on United Airlines: Breakfast Tacos, Barbecue Sandwiches and More
summary: United Airlines announced several new dining, snacking, and beverage options for its Choice Menu, starting May 1. New offerings include egg and chicken chorizo tacos, a barbecue chicken sandwich, craft beers like Lagunitas Sumpin' Easy Ale and New Belgium's Citradelic Tangerine IPA, and Stella Artois which United will be the first airline to serve. Premium transcontinental flights will also feature Ghirardelli sundae toppings and a new signature "Old Fashioned" cocktail.

title: FEMSA se va de compras a Guatemala
summary: Coca-Cola FEMSA, the largest bottler of Coca-Cola products by sales volume, announced the acquisition of two Guatemalan bottling companies for over $170 million. These acquisitions, Comercializadora y Distribuidora Los Volcanes and Alimentos y Bebidas del Atlántico, are part of FEMSA's strategy to expand its business in Latin America. The Mexican firm aims to strengthen its presence in the region through these strategic purchases.

title: Coke finds that Americans still love their soda after all
summary: Coca-Cola Co. saw a significant boost in first-quarter earnings, surprisingly driven by carbonated soft drinks, particularly Diet Coke and Coca-Cola Zero Sugar. Diet Coke experienced a notable comeback in North America for the first time since 2010, attributed to a major redesign and new flavors. This growth offers optimism for the company's trajectory, although a full turnaround is still anticipated.

title: Coca-Cola cosmetics launched at The Face Shop
summary: The Korean makeup brand The Face Shop has collaborated with Coca-Cola to launch a range of cosmetics including cushion compacts, powder pacts, lip tints, lipsticks, and an eyeshadow palette. These products feature Coca-Cola patterned packaging and reportedly smell like the soft drink. This follows a precedent set by Carlsberg in 2015, which launched a limited-edition men's grooming line containing beer.

title: General Trias awards top city taxpayers
summary: General Trias City Mayor Antonio A. Ferrer led the awarding of the city's top 20 corporate taxpayers for real property and business taxes in 2017. This initiative, part of the city's first investor's month celebration, aims to strengthen business relations and maintain a business-friendly environment. House Technologies, Inc. and Unilever Philippines, Inc. were among the top taxpayers recognized.

title: J&J Snack Foods Corp.'s Whole Fruit® Frozen Novelties are NOW Non-GMO Project Verified!
summary: J&J Snack Foods Corp. announced that select Whole Fruit® Fruit Bars and Organic Juice Tubes are now Non-GMO Project Verified, assuring consumers that no genetically modified ingredients are used. This move responds to growing consumer demand for non-GMO products, with the company aiming to strengthen its brand and consumer trust. The verified products, including popular fruit bar flavors and organic juice tubes, are available nationwide.

title: Chipotle Mexican Grill pledges 50% diversion by 2020
summary: Chipotle Mexican Grill announced a goal to divert 50% of its waste from landfills across all stores by 2020, building on its 40% diversion rate in 2017. This includes ensuring 100% of restaurants have recycling and 20% have composting by the same year. The company is also focusing on source reduction, food donation through its Harvest Program, and implementing "mindful prep" to reduce waste.

title: Adobe Experience Cloud to aid company digital transformation
summary: Adobe's CEO, Shantanu Narayen, emphasized that businesses should focus on customer experiences, not solely on products, during the Adobe Summit keynote. The company unveiled the revamped Adobe Experience Cloud and Experience League to support companies like Coca-Cola in their digital transformation efforts, which prioritizes personalized customer interactions. The article highlights the importance of data in achieving relevant customer experiences and how legacy systems are inadequate for this new paradigm.

title: This Sustainable, Trump-Tariff-Hiked Budweiser’s for You
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev is shifting its Budweiser brand to 100% renewable energy and will mark cans accordingly, aiming to boost sales in the U.S. Amid this sustainability effort, the company faces potential price increases for consumers due to President Trump’s 10% tariff on aluminum imports. CEO Carlos Brito anticipates a 2-3% price hike on Budweiser, which relies heavily on aluminum packaging, while also announcing global renewable energy goals by 2025.

title: Water, Waste, Energy: Lessons from Coca-Cola in Africa
summary: This article examines Coca-Cola's sustainability efforts in Africa, focusing on initiatives related to water, waste, and energy. It highlights the company's vast presence and distribution network across 54 African countries, its commitment to sustainability goals aligned with global benchmarks, and specific projects like PETCO in South Africa for plastic recycling and EKOCENTERs for providing essential services. The article also discusses lessons learned, including the importance of job creation and corporate involvement in addressing Africa's development challenges.

title: Arca Continental vs. Coca-Cola Femsa, ¿a quién le fue mejor?
summary: Arca Continental significantly increased its sales by 46.4% in 2017, largely due to new operations acquired in the United States, while Coca-Cola Femsa grew by 14.7%. Despite Arca Continental's higher growth rate, Coca-Cola Femsa maintained its leadership in the sector, though analysts expressed concern over its Q4 net loss due to an accounting change related to its Venezuelan operations. Both companies face challenges from rising sugar costs and consumer preference for healthier products but are showing growth in water and non-carbonated beverages.

title: PepsiCo takes its vending brand Hello Goodness online to woo consumers who want healthier snacks
summary: PepsiCo is extending its "better-for-you" Hello Goodness vending brand to an online platform to capture the growing market for healthier snacks. The company is offering curated boxes of Hello Goodness products on Amazon, building on the success of its vending machines which saw significant revenue increases. This move is part of PepsiCo's broader e-commerce strategy to adapt to changing consumer shopping habits and drive impulse purchases online.

title: Coca-Cola Femsa salva un año difícil y crece a doble dígito
summary: Coca-Cola Femsa reported a 14.7% increase in revenues and 9.4% growth in operating utility for 2017 despite facing challenges such as inflation, input volatility, and a loss from its Venezuelan operations. The company's growth was driven by acquisitions in Brazil and the Philippines, price increases, and volume growth in Central America, even as it recorded a significant loss in Q4 2017 due to a change in accounting methodology for Venezuela. Mexican volumes of Coca-Cola brand specifically decreased by 2.5% due to natural disasters.

title: Victory! PETA Gets Cereal Giant General Mills to End Animal Experiments!
summary: PETA announced a victory as General Mills agreed to ban all animal experiments for making health claims about its food products. This decision follows discussions with PETA highlighting the cruelty and irrelevance of animal studies to humans. General Mills joins a growing list of companies that have made similar commitments, and PETA will continue to advocate for the replacement of animal experiments with humane science.

title: The Coca-Cola Company Reports Strong Operating Results for Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2017; Achieves or Exceeds the Company's Full Year Guidance
summary: The Coca-Cola Company announced strong operating results for Q4 and the full year 2017, meeting or exceeding its guidance. While net revenues declined due to refranchising, the company achieved broad-based organic revenue growth and profit growth, driven by strategic transformation into a total beverage company. The report also highlights the impact of the U.S. Tax Cuts and Jobs Act on its financial outlook and future strategic initiatives.

title: It’s A Wrap! McDonald’s Happy Meal Menu Will Not Have Cheeseburgers Anymore
summary: McDonald's is overhauling its Happy Meal menu to offer more "balanced" options by 2022, removing cheeseburgers as a default and making other nutritional tweaks. The move aims to reduce calories, salt, sugar, and saturated fat in children's meals. The article also criticizes McDonald's for not addressing the disproportionate impact of fast food on African-American communities and the role of "food swamps."

title: Spal Indústria Brasileira de Bebidas adquiere planta de Amcor en Jundaí
summary: Spal Indústria Brasileira de Bebidas, a subsidiary of Coca-Cola FEMSA, acquired an industrial plant from Amcor Rigid Plastics do Brasil Ltda. for BRL 43.197.959 (USD 13.105.600). This acquisition will allow Spal to expand its industrial activities in Jundiaí, São Paulo. The legal advisors for the transaction were Pinheiro Neto Advogados for Spal and Veirano Advogados for Amcor.

title: JV Coca Cola del Valle New Ventures compra Novaverde por USD 80 millones en Chile
summary: Coca Cola del Valle New Ventures S.A., a joint venture among Coca Cola Company de Chile S.A., Embonor S.A., and Embotelladora Andina S.A., acquired 100% of Novaverde, a fruit and food processor, for USD 80.3 million. Novaverde, known for its Guallarauco brand, will help complement Coca Cola's product portfolio in Chile. The deal, pending approval from Chile's National Economic Prosecutor's Office, excludes Novaverde's avocado sales and General Mills representation businesses.

title: How Diet Coke’s Spontaneous Big Game Ad Came Together
summary: Diet Coke made a spontaneous return to the Super Bowl after 21 years with an ad created from an authentic, unscripted moment featuring actress Hayley Magnus. The ad, part of the "Because I Can" campaign, captured Magnus's playful personality between takes, embodying the campaign's message about doing what makes you happy. This unconventional approach highlights the brand's new campaign, emphasizing authenticity and individuality.

title: Oregon Fruit Products buys 165,000-square-foot plant in Salem
summary: Oregon Fruit Products is expanding its operations by acquiring a 165,000-square-foot former NORPAC Foods plant in southeast Salem. The company plans to have the facility operational by November and will continue to add employees as it grows. This move allows Oregon Fruit to address its increasingly crowded current facilities and remain in Salem, retaining its workforce and proximity to growers.

title: Family Dollar Shoppers Can Support Young People's Futures By Making Every Sip Count In 2018
summary: Family Dollar and Coca-Cola are partnering for the "Make Every Sip Count" campaign, aiming to raise up to $1 million for Boys & Girls Clubs of America in 2018. Through this initiative, 15 percent of purchases of participating Coca-Cola products at Family Dollar stores will be donated to support programs for young people. This collaboration continues Family Dollar's history of supporting the organization and Coca-Cola's long-standing commitment to youth development.

title: What Synergies Could the Dr Pepper Snapple–Keurig Merger Create?
summary: The article discusses the potential synergies arising from the merger between Dr Pepper Snapple and Keurig Green Mountain to form Keurig Dr Pepper. The new company is expected to have an extensive portfolio of 125 brands and strong distribution capabilities, aiming to generate $600 million in annual synergies by 2021 and reduce its net debt through strong cash flow. This strategic move positions the merged entity to better compete with beverage industry giants like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo.

title: "Dr. Pepper" and Kuroigu known as a coffee maker integrate business, sales will reach approximately 1 trillion 200 billion yen scale
summary: Dr. Pepper Snapple and Keurig Green Mountain are integrating their businesses, creating a new company named Keurig Dr Pepper with combined sales expected to reach approximately $11 billion (1.2 trillion yen). Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive 13% of the new company's shares plus a special dividend of $103.75 per share. This merger, driven by JAB Holdings, aims to expand business in the North American market.

title: The company that made coffee pods ubiquitous just dropped $18 billion on Dr. Pepper
summary: Keurig Green Mountain, known for its K-cups, has acquired an 87% stake in Dr. Pepper Snapple Group for $18.7 billion. This strategic move aims to leverage Dr. Pepper Snapple's extensive brick-and-mortar distribution network, expanding Keurig's market reach beyond online channels. The acquisition also positions Keurig to directly compete with major beverage companies like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo while challenging Starbucks' retail presence.

title: Keurig Acquires Dr Pepper Snapple; JAB Holding to be Controlling Shareholder
summary: Keurig has agreed to acquire Dr Pepper Snapple Group Inc. for over $21 billion, merging them into a new entity called Keurig Dr. Pepper (KDP) with $11 billion in annual revenue. JAB Holding will be the majority shareholder, while Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share and retain a 13 percent stake. This strategic merger aims to diversify Dr Pepper Snapple's business into the growing coffee market and expand Keurig's reach across hot and cold beverage categories.

title: A Jolt of Caffeine: Keurig Acquires Dr Pepper Snapple in $18.7 Billion Deal
summary: Keurig Green Mountain Inc. is acquiring Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc. in an $18.7 billion deal to form Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP). Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share cash dividend and retain 13% of the combined company, which will have pro forma 2017 annual revenues of approximately $11 billion. This merger aims to create a scaled beverage company with a strong brand portfolio and distribution capabilities, led by Bob Gamgort as CEO.
source: Abasto, Food and Beverage Industry News
source_domain: Abasto, Food and Beverage Industry News

title: Keurig becomes $11b drink giant after buying Dr Pepper, Snapple and others
summary: Keurig will acquire Dr Pepper Snapple Group, forming an US$11 billion beverage company named Keurig Dr Pepper. Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive a special cash dividend of US$103.75 per share and retain a 13% stake in the combined entity. This merger brings together brands like Dr Pepper, 7 Up, Snapple, and Keurig's coffee makers, though still remains smaller than PepsiCo Inc. and Coca-Cola Co.

title: Keurig to take control of Dr Pepper Snapple in $18.7 billion deal
summary: JAB Holding's Keurig Green Mountain business has agreed to acquire Dr Pepper Snapple Group in an $18.7 billion deal. This acquisition seeks to create a massive beverage distribution network in the United States, allowing the new entity, Keurig Dr Pepper, to compete with major players like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo with an estimated annual revenue of $11 billion. The merger aims to leverage the combined strengths of both companies in e-commerce and traditional retail channels to enhance market share in coffee and soft drinks.

title: Keurig buys Dr Pepper, Snapple creating $11 billion beverage behemoth
summary: Keurig Green Mountain Inc. announced its plan to acquire Dr Pepper Snapple Group, forming a new beverage company named Keurig Dr Pepper with estimated annual sales of $11 billion. Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share in cash and retain 13 percent of the combined company. The deal, which still requires shareholder approval, is expected to close later this year.

title: Dr Pepper Snapple and Keurig Green Mountain to merge
summary: Dr Pepper Snapple Group and Keurig Green Mountain are merging to form Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP), a new beverage company with an estimated $11bn in annual sales. JAB Holdings Co. will be the controlling shareholder, while Mondelez International will hold a significant stake of around 13%. This merger aims to create a scale beverage company combining hot and cold beverages with extensive distribution capabilities in North America.

title: Keurig owner snaps up Dr Pepper in $18.7 billion deal
summary: Keurig Green Mountain, Inc. announced it will acquire Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc. for $18.7 billion in cash, forming a new entity called Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP). This deal, driven by European consumer products giant JAB Holdings, will create a beverage company with approximately $11 billion in pro forma 2017 annual revenues and a diverse portfolio of hot and cold beverage brands. Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share in a special cash dividend and retain 13% of the combined company.

title: Keurig buys Dr. Pepper Snapple, creating a beverage giant
summary: Keurig Green Mountain Inc. announced its acquisition of Dr. Pepper Snapple Group, forming a new beverage giant with approximately $11 billion in annual sales. Dr. Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share in a special cash dividend and retain 13 percent of the combined company, which will be named Keurig Dr. Pepper. JAB Holding company will be the controlling shareholder following the deal, expected to close in the second quarter of 2018.

title: K-Cup maker Keurig bets big on beverages, buying Dr Pepper Snapple
